PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have encated chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 437 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 75 citizens), Durack (from 510 citizens) and Robertson (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Local Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to territorial or local government
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of territorial or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1). We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 42 citizens) and Watson (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations:

The establishment, operation, administration and accountability of bodies, which are neither departments nor statutory authorities of the Commonwealth, for which the Commonwealth is wholly or partly responsible.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent to the following Bills reported:
States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1983
Northern Territory Grant (Special Assistance) Bill 1983
Migration (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983
Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1983-84
River Murray Waters Bill 1983
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The last occasion on which there was a substantial increase in the size of the Parliament was 1948. In the 35 years since then, Australia's population has doubled approximately. The tasks of Government and of individual numbers have grown profoundly and people's expectations about what their representatives can achieve have increased markedly. It is essential that our Parliament is able to cope with these changing demands and to meet the needs of the 1980s and beyond. Past practice suggests such adjustments are rare and therefore it is necessary for legislators to consider problems in the future as well as their immediate circumstances when considering an increase in the size of the Parliament.

The importance of this principle was not lost on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. In a detailed and reasoned response to the submissions it received, the majority of the Committee recommended that the number of senators representing each original State be increased from 10 to 12, with a corresponding increase in the size of the House of Representatives of 23, and the Government has accepted that recommendation. The reasons given by the Committee for its recommendation are compelling. First and foremost is the question of our increased population. In 1947, the census year prior to the last major increase in the size of the Parliament, the population was 7.5 million-now it is over 15 million. Since 1949, average enrolments for House of Representatives divisions have risen from 39,948 to the current figure of 74,989 . But of greater significance is the fact that Commonwealth Government activity has grown enormously in the last 35 years, without a corresponding increase in the number of senators and members. There is now more legislation passed with a flow on need for more committees, and more Ministers-the Ministry has increased in size by 70 per cent since 1949. The annual volume of legislation has grown almost fourfold in the last 60 years. For example, in 1924, 65 Bills were proposed, and in 1978 the figure was 240.

There has been a great expansion of Federal Government responsibilities since World War II through the regulation of the national economy and the creation of a welfare state. The role of Parliament, the duties of parliamentarians and the expectations of the electorate have changed dramatically during this period. Today the Parliament through the ordinary back bencher is expected to be conversant with these new policy trends, and to be a watchdog holding the Government accountable to his or her constituents. In particular, Parliament has set up a wide range of committees which can only function effectively if there are sufficient parliamentarians to be called upon to perform the committee tasks . Yet the pool of members and senators available for these assignments has been eroded over the years through the increase in the size of the Ministry and shadow Ministry. Furthermore, under the present arrangements the ordinary member has difficulty coping with the flood of constituent problems which have escalated with the growth of poverty and unemployment. No wonder people become cynical about their politicians when so many of their federal representatives are placed in the position of not being able to serve their constituents let alone play an active legislative role in their national Parliament.

The increase in Government business that has occurred in recent times has significantly altered the balance between the Executive and the back bench. It has meant that Parliament's independence in relation to the Executive has suffered. It is interesting to note when considering the increase in Government business since 1949 that the numbers of those who report on it in the Parliamentary Press Gallery have increased fourfold since then. There are those who argue that Australia is already overgoverned, that there are already too many politicians. This is a simplistic view. Nevertheless, it is superficially appealing.

I reject the approach which adds up all the members of parliament in Australia and divides that number into the population and then produces some overseas country to prove that we have too many MPs. The functions of our parliamentarians differ too much from overseas to make such contrast valid. If we were to use that technique to compare ourselves with the United Kingdom then we would rationally have to ask whether local authorities and county councils which perform functions in education, social welfare and housing, here the function of State governments, should be included. For those who are fond of such comparisons, however, I should point out that in the United Kingdom, the 650 lower House representatives have on average 65,692 electors in their constituencies. In the case of the Canadian lower House, the number of electors per member is 56,349. New Zealand's 92 constituencies average only 22,117 electors each. In Australia, the 125 members of the House of Representives have on average 74,989 electors in their divisions, well ahead of the others. The real question is: Do we want the members and senators to be able to carry out their tasks, of representing their constituency and making a real contribution to the formation of national policy?

The Bill before this Senate will provide more adequate and more realistic representation for all Australians. It will redress the ludicrous situation that has developed whereby twice the population since 1949 are governed by the same number of representatives. It will allow more time to be spent by members on representing their constituents. It will train more adequately our future Ministers. It will permit the improving committee system to become more effective in improving the legislature's oversight of the Executive. It will increase the relevance, not just the numbers, of back benchers. There will always be some public opposition to increasing the number of parliamentarians. This is as inevitable as it is, in some ways, unfortunate. However, this does not constitute a valid reason for simply putting off what must eventually come. The time is appropriate to make these changes now-now that we are updating and consolidating our electoral legislation and now that we are preparing to move into the new Parliament House. As the Committee recognised, this is a matter of principle, and as such, must eventually outweigh any short term unpopularity that may attach to the legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Australia in the 19th century showed the way to the world in electoral reform in making democracy work. As early as 1856 Victoria turned away from the violence and corruption of open voting to a secret ballot for its new parliament . Four other States, South Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania, followed within three years. Western Australia dragged the chain a little, but by 1877 the secret ballot was in operation throughout the whole of Australia. We were also the leaders in abolishing the property vote and establishing payment for members of Parliament, both crucial democratic reforms which took powers away from the rich cliques and gave it to the people's representatives. In female suffrage, while New Zealand was the first to give women the vote in 1893, South Australia followed within two years. After federation women were able to vote, in the first elections under federal law in 1903. Compulsory enrolment came in 1911 and compulsory voting in 1924.

While Australia once led the world in electoral reform we have had a patchy record since. There has been no substantial overall review of Commonwealth Electoral Law in over three-quarters of a century and no major consolidation since 1918. Despite the many fundamental changes which have occurred in society since the turn of the century most Australian Governments have not attempted to amend our electoral legislation to reflect those changes. Their failure to act has usually stemmed from a perceived partisan advantage resulting from the decay of the system. One vote, one value was eroded by manipulation of electoral boundaries, people were disenfranchised by excessively complex voting systems, by rigid and complicated enrolment procedures. For example, even the introduction of proportional representation in the Senate while conceived as a stabilising, fair system has, in practice, disenfranchised up to 10 per cent of the electorate through a tendency to encourage informal voting. The size of electorates and the increasing complexity and weight of demands on members have denied the electors the services they deserve and have a right to demand. The skyrocketing costs of modern election campaigns have threatened to create a situation where the national government can be delivered to the party with the best bagman. It is essential for public confidence in the political process that no suggestion of favours returned for large donations can be sustained. However, it is not only the potential of corruption in the financing of multimillion dollar campaigns that should be a matter for concern. A serious imbalance in campaign funding threatens the health of democracy.

My party pledged itself to electoral reform before the last election. We have been anxious to work towards co-operation and agreement. All parties are diminished when democracy fails to function. It was because of this that the previous Special Minister of State, the Hon. M. J. Young M.P. moved to establish a Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and obtained the agreement of the House and the Senate in May of this year. This reflected his longstanding concern about the quality of democracy in this country. His confidence in the value of such an inquiry was well justified by the result. The inquiry was most comprehensive: there were 212 submissions considered by the committee, not only from political parties, but also from large and small organisations, academics, local government bodies and individuals. The scope of the inquiries covered not only questions of major public policy, but also topics like the problems of handicapped persons and the disenfranchisement of the members of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition, both topics to which they were able to propose solutions.

What was impressive about the deliberations of the committee was the concern of all members, of whatever political party, to produce an effective report. While inevitably there were differences, I would like to quote the chairman of the committee, the member for prospect (Dr Klugman) who stated: 'In view of the highly political questions involved, where every party would be expected to look to its own advantages, the committee's deliberations were examples of rational discussion. I especially thank the opposition members for co-operating in helping to design reasonable methods for introducing public funding of elections and in reaching a voting system designed to reduce the large number of unintended informal votes for senate elections, two questions which might have been expected to produce extreme polarisation of viewpoints.'

I believe the proposals contained in the Bill are of a non-partisan nature. The Government in considering the committee's report has been able to adopt it in full except for some largely mechanical changes in relation to the proposed electoral commission and its procedures in relation to redistributions. On our side we in the Labor party were prepared to give ground. On the question of Senate voting we accepted a compromise.

On Senate voting, the Government has accepted the recommendation of the Committee to provide firstly that a voter may mark one square indicating the adoption of his preferred party's how-to-vote ticket and secondly for the validation of any person's vote up to the point where the voter's intention remains clear. It has been a matter of notoriety that the complexity of the ticket has contributed to a substantial informal vote and also just as significantly to the throwaway vote, known as a donkey vote. The Joint Committee had before it federal material from the Australian Electoral Office which showed how the most trivial mistakes were the major factors in the Senate informal vote . The figures were taken from an analysis of the 1977 Senate and House of Representatives vote. The Senate informal vote was 9% nationwide compared to 2.5 % for the House of Representatives. Of the Senate informal votes almost 8 out of 10, 78%, had been disqualified on one of two grounds: incorrect numerical sequence or some squares left blank. This meant the disenfranchisement in that election for the Senate of almost 600,000 Australians, more than the population of Tasmania. The situation is palpably absurd and this legislation will go a long way towards correcting it. In addition never again will a political party be able to influence the destiny of a nation by cynically cluttering a state senate ticket with dummy candidates. Other reforms-party affiliations of candidates on ballot papers, mobile polling for people in remote areas and hospitals, provisions for itinerants-will restore votes for many previously disenfranchised.

So soon after the Queensland election it is hardly necessary to remind the Senate that the gerrymander is alive and flourishing in Australia. Research undertaken by the Australian Electoral Office shows that widespread cynicism about gerrymanders in Australia is a significant factor contributing to apathy and reluctance to enrol, particularly among young people. We can do something here about meeting and dispelling that scepticism at a national level. According to the Joint Select Committee, there is '. . . great merit in the existence of an Australian Electoral Commission with a statutory basis and which is seen to operate independent of political influence.'
The Bill provides for the establishment of a truly independent electoral commission to be made up of:
(i) a Judge of the Federal Court of at least 3 years standing appointed by the Governor-General in Council from a panel of three nominated by the Chief Judge;
(ii) the Electoral Commissioner (a position replacing the Chief Australian Electoral Officer); and

(iii) a Permanent Head of the Public Service or a person of equivalent status in a commonwealth statutory authority. The Electoral Commissioner would be a full-time executive officer of the commission, while the other two members would be part-time.
The Commission's areas of responsibility will be:
(i) the current functions of the Australian Electoral Office;
(ii) the conduct of educational programs for voters and potential voters;
(iii) the implementation and administration of public funding of election campaigns;
(iv) the implementation and administration of legislation governing disclosure of donations to political parties and candidates, and of electoral expenditure of candidates, parties and organisations;
(v) periodic redistribution of electoral boundaries; and
(vi) the day to day administration of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

An independent commission is needed to take the drawing of electoral boundaries and the general operation of the Electoral Act out of the control of the whims of the government of the day, whatever its political complexion. A crucial part of the legislation provides that the final determination of electoral boundaries and names is not to be subject to Parliamentary veto, but it may be reviewed by the Federal Court, through a prerogative writ, if prima facie the criteria set out in the legislation are not followed.

It will not be subject to any process of approval by Parliament or any disallowance motion by either House. This has been done quite deliberately and after the fullest consideration of the Joint Committee's recommendation. This Government is determined once and for all to establish fair and impartial procedures for honest redistributions. We owe this to the Australian people. There will be no need for any Royal Commissions on this topic in future.
Within a state the redistribution committee under the Australian Electoral Commission will consist of:
(i) the Electoral Commissioner;
(ii) the Australian Electoral Officer for the particular State;
(iii) the State Surveyor-General; and
(iv) the State Auditor-General.

Under the legislation, regular redistributions will take place. Their timing will be beyond the reach of Governments. Redistributions will, in general, occur in each State and the Australian Capital Territory at least once every 7 years, when one-third of the divisions within a State deviate from the State average enrolment by more than 10 per cent, or when population shifts require a change in the number of divisions in a State.
The Government believes that the independence of the Commission must be reinforced by a similar faith and trust in the integrity and independence of our political parties.

The cost of electioneering these days in any of the western democracies would have been unthinkable to the politicians of say 1949 let alone the founding fathers of federation. The estimated cost of the federal election campaign earlier this year was $12 million. It is simply naive to believe that no big donor is ever likely to want his reward. The price of public funding is a small insurance to pay against the possibility of corruption.

The whole process of political funding needs to be out in the open so that there can be no doubt in the public mind. Australians deserve to know who is giving money to political parties and how much. I might say that concern about potential corruption is by no means confined to members of the Labor Party. According to a final point of the joint committee even the National Party federal body 'accepted in principle that large undisclosed donations could provide the potential to corrupt the political process . . .'.

The move to public funding and disclosure is not as radical a step as has been suggested by some sectors of the community. Indeed the list of countries which have taken up public funding and disclosure shows that Australia will simply be catching up with the rest of the world in this important area of reform. Austria , West Germany, France, Finland, Denmark, Israel, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Canada and the United States of America-all have embraced this co-called radical step. It's time that Australia also recognised the essential reasons for supporting public funding.

Public funding ensures that different parties offering themselves for election have an equal opportunity to present their policies to the electorate. Without it, worthy parties and candidates might not be able to afford the considerable sums necessary to make their policies known. In this way, public funding equally contributes to the development of an informed electorate. As well, it helps counter the problem created by the mounting costs of political campaigning due to the increased use of television as a medium of communication.

It is often alleged that public funding would only serve to assist the government of the day more than those parties in opposition. Overseas evidence suggests that this is just not so. American figures show that during the 1980 presidential elections, the Republican candidate Ronald Reagan received $29.4 million by way of a government subsidy. This was exactly the same amount that the incumbent Jimmy Carter was given. In our proposal, funds will be distributed strictly in accordance with votes received. It has been a long time in Australia since one party polled more than 50 per cent of both the Senate and the House primary votes combined.

In the specific provisions for public funding, the government has been prepared to go to substantial lengths to meet the Australian Democrats and the Liberal Party. The Australian Labor Party's submission to the joint committee sought 10 per cent as the minimal formal vote target before a registered party became eligible for assistance. The Democrats proposed no threshold and the Liberals one of 5 per cent. The legislation before this House provides a figure of 4 per cent.
The rate of public funding is to be as follows:
at a double dissolution, or a combined House of Representatives and half Senate election, 60 cents per House of Representatives vote and 30 cents for each Senate vote;
for a House of Representatives election (and by-elections) 60 cents per valid first preference vote;
for a half Senate election 45 cents per valid first preference vote; and
these amounts to be indexed to the CPI.

An essential corollary of public funding is disclosure-they are two sides of the same coin. Unless there is disclosure the whole point of public funding is destroyed. The legislation lays down that donations for federal election purposes of $200 of more to a candidate and $1000 to a party be disclosed and the donor identified. Radio stations, television stations, printers and newspapers are required to report electoral expenditure to the Electoral Commission. These organisations must identify the source of the funds.

Anonymous donations above the set limits cannot be accepted by candidates or parties. If such donations are received a matching amount must be paid by the recipent to the Commonwealth. The Joint Committee on Electoral Reform will closely monitor the effectiveness of these provisions.

Mr President, the Bill before this House is the first major overhaul of our electoral legislation since 1918. Amongst other things, it seeks to consolidate the various pieces of legislation which until now have governed the electoral process; to remove or bring up-to-date many out-moded provisions; to remove certain anomalies; to extend the right, and in the case of aboriginals, the obligation to enrol and to vote; to make it easier for electors to get on the rolls and stay on the rolls; to alter polling procedures to make voting more accessible to previously disadvantaged groups and to make the voting process simpler.

For example, the Bill provides that there must be a sufficient time between the announcement of an election and the close of rolls for that election. The previous Prime Minister demonstrated only too well that without this sort of provision the cynical exercise of the strict terms of the law could effectively stop many thousands of people from enrolling and voting. There will be new provisions enabling Australians living temporarily overseas to retain their enrolment whether or not they have a current permanent address in Australia. In so doing, the Bill at last makes proper provision for the families of servicemen overseas so that they do not lose their entitlement to vote.

Special arrangements are being proposed for such handicapped people as quadriplegics; for electors in the Antarctic who previously have been disenfranchised and also for itinerant persons who up till now have not been catered for at all.

The Bill will also seek to make the voting process easier. In future, for example, electors will be able to vote as an ordinary voter at any polling booth within their division instead of only within their subdivision. Mobile polling facilities will be provided in the outback and for patients in hospitals and similar institutions. A register of postal voters will be established so that people in remote areas or people unable to attend polling booths can be sent an application for a postal vote immediately an election is announced.

I would also add that the Government has accepted the proposition that the polling hours for Federal elections should be 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. This will bring our polling arrangements in this regard into line with the majority of the states and make it less confusing for electors.

As I have mentioned, the Bill also proposes that the party affiliations of candidates can be shown on ballot papers. Additionally, new procedures are proposed for the marking of ballot papers which will make it harder for a voter inadvertently to vote informal.

It is proposed that it will be possible for an elector voting for the Senate to indicate his choice of candidates by reference to a registered party ticket. We are confident that not only are these proposals intrinsically fair and reasonable but they will act significantly to reduce the informality rate in Senate elections in the long run.

Mr President, Honourable Senators will be aware that in recent months the Government has demonstrated its concern for and interest in electoral matters. We have already taken steps to ensure that the Australian Electoral Office is provided with adequate funds and resources: provision has been made to increase significantly the Aboriginal Electoral Educations Program; funds have been provided for the development of a substantial computer installation; and just recently we provided over $3 million to enable the office to conduct an education and enrolment campaign. Honourable Senators will be well aware of the concern which the Government expressed when the results of the Electoral Office research showed how many eligible people were not on the electoral rolls.

The legislation which I am now putting before honourable senators should be considered against this background of our deep and demonstrated concern. Australia must have an electoral system designed for the people it serves. The Government believes that the changes proposed to our electoral machinery are both timely and sensible, yet at the same time they preserve the basic elements and broad principles which are already at the heart of the current system. On the other hand, the major overhaul undertaken will we believe improve the electoral administration; make the whole electoral process of enrolment and voting easier and simpler for the elector, and ensure that we have an electoral process which is modern and free from any allegations or even possibilities of corruption or political pressures.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
I have great pleasure in bringing before the Senate this Bill which will finally, after 8 years of neglect by our predecessors enable us to establish the Inter-State Commission.

It has been a long standing commitment of the Australian Labor Party to establish the ISC. We see the ISC as an important vehicle for promoting the rational development of national transport policies. The Government's action today fulfils an important election promise in the transport field.

As honourable senators know, the Inter-State Commission Act was passed with bipartisan support in 1975 but was never proclaimed by our predecessors. Proclamation of the Act was arranged by this Government and the Act came into operation on 27 September 1983.

The purpose of the Bill I bring to the Senate today is to update a number of provisions in the Inter-State Commission Act 1975 to take account of legislative developments since 1975. The proposed amendments are necessary to enable the Commission to become operational. They are essentially of a technical nature and the purpose and powers of the Commission will remain the same as those embodied in the 1975 Act.

An Inter-State Commission is provided for in Sections 101-104 of the Constitution. When the ISC we propose to establish is seen in its Constitutional context, it is clear that its purpose is to assist in the improvement of inter- state transport-and certainly not to hinder it through undue control and regulation, as has been inferred in some quarters.

Establishment of the Commission will complete the Constitutional coverage on inter-state transport matters. Section 92 of the Constitution protects freedom of trade among the States. In a complementary way, the Constitution provides for an Inter-State Commission to watch over and advise this Parliament on such matters.
The Commission we shall establish will in fact investigate and advise Government on allegations of discriminatory practices, inequalities, inefficiencies and anomalies in inter-state transport.

Governments and Parliaments have frequently been advised to establish the Commission. The most recent occasion was the Report of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania which recommended such action. A similar recommendation was made by the Commission of Inquiry into Transport to and from Tasmania in 1976.

The Commission provided for in the ISC Act is an investigatory and advisory body with Royal Commission-type powers. Its reports and recommendations will be tabled in the Parliament. It has no regulatory or judicial powers and will investigate only those inter-state transport matters referred to it by the Minister for Transport.

The ISC will be required to carry out wide ranging investigations covering economic, social, institutional and legal-constitutional issues affecting inter- state transport. There is no other existing organisation that is equipped, or empowered, to carry out such inquiries. The ISC meets the need for an ongoing independent body that performs these functions.

While in certain circumstances there will be a need for ad hoc inquiries to handle matters falling outside the scope of the ISC, in general, ad hoc Commissions and Inquiries are expensive to establish and lose all the expertise gained when they are disbanded. The ISC will accumulate and retain such expertise.

In conducting its investigations the ISC will operate, in many ways, like a transport users tribunal. It will consult with and examine the submissions and evidence of the private citizen, unions, business, the community, employees, transport users and suppliers and governments.

Users of transport have no single entity in Australia to which they can take any problems they encounter with anomalies, discriminations and inequalities that exist in our national transport system. At present they can only appeal to operator controlled organisations (both government and private) whose own interests are generally paramount.

The ISC will be a major vehicle for getting the facts out into the open when it examines inter-state transport problems. It will have a significant role in keeping each transport system ''honest'', and will develop a fund of expertise that will be invaluable to the development of national transport policies.

Let me now turn to some of the specific provisions of the Bill. Section 6 of the 1975 Act, which excluded any examination by the ISC of matters relating to the operation of the former Airline Agreements, is to be updated to exclude matters covered by the new 1981 Airlines Agreement and the related Independent Air Fares Committee Act. The objective, as previously, is to exclude the Airlines Agreement from the ambit of the ISC, together with fare determinations. However, as domestic air freight is no longer regulated through the Airlines Agreement, it will now come within the ambit of the ISC.

Other sections of the Act need amendment because of changes since 1975. The salaries of the President and Members of the Commission are adjusted to present day equivalents. Penalties are updated and sections 22, 23 and 24 are replaced to take account of legislative developments in the fields of retirement benefits and the Public Service Act since 1975. There are also a number of minor amendments included so that the ISC Act will conform with current administrative procedures and legislative drafting practices.
As I have mentioned, the powers and scope of the Commission provided for in the 1975 Act remain unchanged.

The Commission is expected to be established very early in 1984 and action is already underway to make appointments to the Commission. It is important we appoint people of the highest calibre to perform this important Constitutional role.
In accordance with its status as a national body with Constitutional authority, the Commission will be located here in the national capital.
It will have a relatively small body of supporting staff to assist in the running and administration of inquiries and to provide analytical and technical advice.

The cost of running its operations in 1983-84 is estimated to be of the order of $250,000. In a full year, when fully staffed, the amount would be approximately $1.5 to $2.0 million. More precise figures will depend on the administrative requirements of the President, when appointed, and discussions with the Public Service Board and other provisioning Departments.

It is not generally appreciated that for nearly every $10 of gross national expenditure, $1 is spent on transport infrastructure and services. The transport and storage industries employ about 350,000 people or about 5.5 per cent of the workforce. This excludes the large number of people employed on their own account, or for companies whose transport operations are incidental to their main operations. Transport is clearly a significant part of our economy. The value of benefits to be gained by transport users from the ISC's role in bringing about a more rational, effective and efficient national transport system, will vastly outweigh the very modest cost of the Commission.
Government decisions in the transport area consequently have a wide ranging effect on most areas of Australian economic and social activity.

One of the first tasks of the Commission will be a review of the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme. Before the final terms of reference are determined the Minister for Transport will be consulting with industry associations, unions , interest groups and the Tasmanian Government.

More generally, and in keeping with the Government's policy of consultation and reconciliation, the Minister for Transport will be consulting with relevant State Governments and other organisations that may be affected by any proposed reference to the Commission.

As honourable senators will be aware it is the policy of the Government to ensure that the functions and efficiency of Government authorities are regularly reviewed. It is the Government's intention that the ISC's operations will be reviewed within the first seven years of its life.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report upon the question of animal welfare in Australia, with particular reference to:
(a) interstate and overseas commerce in animals;
(b) wildlife protection and harvesting;
(c) animal experimentation;
(d) codes of practice of animal husbandry for all species; and
(e) the use of animals in sport.
(2) That provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.
I seek leave to have my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
1. REASONS FOR THE
ESTABLISHMENT OF THE COMMITTEE

The Australian Democrats, in introducing this motion, are taking a vital initiative towards the development of guidelines for the treatment of all species of animals found on the Australian continent, irrespective of the type of relationship they share with humans, and for the protection of their rights. This includes animals kept as pets, commercial animals and those still living in their natural state.
Our policy has always been to extend care and concern to all animals in a meaningful way.

Now, as a positive step to put that principle into effect, the passing of this motion will result in the establishment of a Select Committee which will look into all aspects of animal welfare and will hopefully recommend the means to overcome any deficiencies it finds.

The Democrats believe that it is important that uniformity be applied to animal welfare across the nation, and that response to pressure groups be balanced and not just an ad-hoc reaction to a particular situation.

It is also important that all aspects of animal lives are covered by the inquiry. There are many methods of handling animals which have become almost traditional and are now carried out without any thought as to the suitability of the method because 'it has always been done that way'. It is essential now to review those methods so that new methods can be evaluated and all unnecessary suffering of animals be prevented.

We feel sure that most commercial animal breeders and other people who work with animals have an affectionate regard for the animals under their care and would co-operate with reasonable controls and suggestions to reduce stress or pain inflicted on their animals. Many will welcome help in identifying procedures which can be moderated or changed to the advantage of their animals; particularly when they realise that the Select Committee is giving an evenhanded view, balancing the requests from animal liberationists with the practical considerations of animal husbandry where necessary.
2. THE PARTICULAR REFERENCES
The particular references listed in the motion ensure that the inquiry will cover the most important areas of animal concern. I would like now to make a brief statement on each of the areas involved.
2A. Overseas and Interstate Trade and Commerce in Animals
(i) Interstate Trade

Transportation of stock animals in Australia is a seriously neglected area of animal welfare. The result of this neglect is an ever-increasing incidence of cruelty to the animals involved and an ever-spiralling cost to the producer who must bear the consequential losses.

Animal production loss in each state differs, but in general there is no stipulation that animals shall only travel for a certain number of hours. There is no requirement which makes one person responsible for the animals at each point of the journey and so responsibility for injury and death is abnegated or denied. Local abattoirs are closing down with the result that stock animals are being transported further and further across state borders making the issue a federal matter. Horses, for instance, may be loaded in Queensland, travel 2 or 3 days in a truck as it is being loaded in various points, then stand two days in a sale yard at Homebush, N.S.W., without food or water, prior to being sold and trucked out. Cattle also often travel long distances and there are many instances when they arrive at their destination with their tails badly damaged from friction from rubbing up against the back of a truck, permanent sores forming on their hips from jolting around for hour after hour, and crippling foot injuries due to improper flooring. In 1975 (the latest figures I could obtain on this matter), there was a loss of $20 million from bruised carcases alone, and this does not include losses from death, weightloss, heat damage or contamination of carcases.

An inquiry is urgently needed into ways of supervising journeys of stock animals, of improving sale yard conditions, of relating the types of transport used in moving animals to prevent unnecessary injury and stress, and of defining the responsibility of sellers, transporters, buyers, auctioneers and agents.
(ii) Overseas Trade

Over the past decade there has been an increasing public outcry over the shipping of live animals overseas for slaughter. For instance, in 1981 the RSPCA stepped in over the export of over 100 live horses to Japan for fattening and killing for human consumption. There were also a large number of demonstrations that year where animal liberationists combined with trade unionists to oppose the export of 5.7 million sheep, mostly to the Middle East.
In spite of these protests the number of sheep exported increased to 6.2 million in 1982.

The British Veterinarian Association policy is that animals should be slaughtered as near as possible to the point of production. This is certainly not happening with the overseas trade in livestock here in Australia.

There is also considerable evidence that the live sheep export trade is depriving Australian firms and workers of income as our industry is shipped overseas. The Democrats believe that it would be far more economical and humane to slaughter animals in Australia.
2B Wildlife Protection and Harvesting
(i) Endangered species

It is estimated that at present about 30 Australian native species are threatened with extinction. An Endangered Species Act is needed for the protection of the habitat of these species and we urgently need scientific research to find out how much land must be set aside and what other measures are necessary for their continued survival.

Australia is a signatory to the International Agreement-C.I.T.E.S. (Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species), and as Minister for Customs I became aware of the hard work being done by customs officials in stamping out the illegal trade being done in these animals and birds. Nevertheless, there is still a lot of work necessary and we must investigate the need for additional funds and personnel in this field.
(ii) Kangaroos

Over the past two years there has been increasing pressure put on both State and Federal governments to come to grips with the need to protect endangered kangaroo species while allowing farmers and national park managers to protect their crops and environment from the damage caused by large kangaroo populations .

At the extremes of the argument are those who believe that no kangaroo should ever be shot, no matter what the circumstances, and those who believe that the kangaroo meat and fur industries should be actively promoted by government as an alternative primary industry.

There has been considerable argument over the numbers of kangaroos in Australia over the past four years. Australian Government figures are given as 32 million in 1980, 36 million in 1982 and 19 million in 1983.

These figures indicate that either the numbers of kangaroos vary incredibly from year to year according to the previaling weather conditions or that there is something wrong with the way figures are collected. In either case I believe that we must hear professional opinion on this matter so that the Government does not continue to leave itself open to criticism, as it has done recently, over the arguments it presents to counter the kangaroo lobby.

Since the election the Hawke Government has continued the line of the previous Fraser Government on this issue with the result that the United States has now lifted its ban on the import of kangaroo products. We believe that the new Government has not had an opportunity to look at the issue dispassionately yet and that if it had it might well have decided to take a different line than the one it has taken so far. We are particulary concerned for example, that the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 has not been proclaimed yet.

In the meantime the argument has taken a higher profile on the international scene, with the European Parliament considering the issue along the same lines as it considered the annual seal hunt in Canada. Given the international disrepute that Canada has gained over that issue, Australia needs to be very certain of its facts about kangaroos and make the necessary changes to current government policy as soon as possible, so that the same disrepute does not occur here.
2C Animal Experiments

Perhaps one of the most disturbing aspects of all animal welfare matters in Australia is the use of animals for experiments. Although many questions have been asked in State and Federal Parliament over the years we still have no figures available as to how many animals are being used in experiments in this country, what types of animals are being used or for what sorts of research. There is virtually no legislation to protect animals used in experiments.

The various State Acts are totally inadequate, with the result that anything can be done to a dog or a cat behind closed laboratory doors without the researcher being answerable to anyone except his or her own peers.
The National Health and Medical Research Council does have a code of practice to govern the use of animals in experiments which states that:
procedures likely to cause pain of more than a trivial extent must not be carried out without the administration of an anaesthetic.

However, this code is, we believe not being enforced. We are appreciative of honourable members (such as Ralph Jacobi) who have raised questions from time to time. We believe this is a bipartisan matter of moral and ethical concern which should not be related to party politics.

Of the five areas listed, this area is one which I am personally most concerned about. It horrifies me that in this day and age, we are so insensitive to animals that we continue to use them unnecessarily in experiments such as when testing out a new brand of lipstick. It also seems incredible to me that we continue to use animals as human substitutes where there are such strong differences between the animal being experimented on and human beings, that they make the results of the experiments worthless.

I think my series of questions concerning the use of animals in experiments addressed to Senator Ryan, as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology in the Senate, and the answers she gave, clearly illustrate the lack of action by the Government in this area. Of the 23 questions I asked her, nine received the reply ''National statistics are not collected'' and a number of others received replies like ''information not available'', and ''I am not aware of any plans''.
What is urgently needed is a system which is publicly accountable such as that in Great Britain where statistics are collected by the Home Office and it is known how many animals are used.

No animals should have to suffer pain in any experiments as modern analgesics and anaesthetics are now more sophisticated. The Government must encourage the use and development of alternative techniques and animal welfare representatives should be represented on committees involved with animal experiments within the research establishment as is the case in Sweden.
2D Codes of Practice of Animal Husbandry for all Species

Over recent years there has been much publicity about the keeping of hens in confined cages all their lives to produce eggs cheaply. Up to four hens can be crowded into a cage with a sloping wire floor where each hen has a quarto page space in which it lives virtually its whole life being jostled by its companions . Pigs are also crowded indoors on cement or slashed floors, they are fed on artificial foods, never knowing sun, fresh air or exercise. As long ago as 1965, in the Bramely Report, a committee of agricultural experts in Britain stated that even animals that were kept indoors for generation after generation, did not lose their instincts to scratch in the soil, to make a dust bath, etc.

Although this term of reference refers to ''Codes of Practice of Animal Husbandry for all Species'' it is hoped that the committee, if established, will look at the possibility of recommending uniform national legislation relating to animal husbandry for stock animals under this heading. This is because Codes of Practice have no power under the law and are therefore meaningless. No matter how cruel a farmer or grazier may be, he or she cannot be prosecuted or convicted. Codes of Practice have been used as a way of watering down legislation and a way of escaping from the responsibilities of the law. If the Committee decided to be serious about the need for animal protection, they may have to recommend proper uniform laws across Australia, not meaningless statements which cannot be enforced.

At present each State has its own animal protection Act and these vary from State to State. So long as different laws apply to different farmers in different States, some will be penalised while others will be advantaged and general confusion will reign.
2E Animals in Sport
Finally, I want to make reference to animals in sport. Senators will recall the outcry last year about rodeo events such as calf-roping.

A calf may be travelling at 30 or 40 kilometres an hour when it is tackled or suddenly thrown by a rope tightened around its neck. Overseas studies have shown a calf which has been roped even once suffers injury such as bruising of the larynx, rupturing and haemorrhaging of the muscles, and even paralysis.

Other sporting activities using animals are also of concern. The use of the whip in horse racing should be investigated and extraordinary events such as wild cow milking and greasy pig chasing ought to be assessed. There is also the problem of indiscriminate shooting of wildlife for sport. All these issues must be investigated.
3 CONCLUSION

The Democrats are not saying that every concern advanced by animal welfare organisations or every person espousing their case is justified. There are also many practices adopted by some extremists in the field which we question.

For instance, some of the more graphic literature circulated by some groups is more reminiscent of that from the discredited Right-to-life than that from the responsible conservation societies with which I normally associate animal welfare groups. In my opinion the case for better care and a more considered approach towards animals is clear. There is no need to overstate the case, and to do so can only result in responsible people questioning the validity of the case being put.
Unfortunately in this area, emotion is often confused with facts.
Animal Welfare is a highly emotional issue. With the establishment of this Committee we will have the opportunity to come to terms with the facts.
I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself briefly to the proposition that Senator Chipp has put to the Senate. I want to express the view that, whilst we would not be seen to oppose the establishment of such an inquiry, I believe that such an inquiry is premature and that it fails to take cognisance of a very widespread and in-depth inquiry that is already taking place through departments of agriculture and through the Australian Veterinary Association and in various other fields. I will address myself briefly to those areas of inquiry in a moment. There is indeed an enormous amount of in-depth research being carried out now into the welfare of animals as there has been for several years past. I suggest that the people involved in these investigations and inquiries are people basically without peers in their own particular sphere of knowledge and it seems to me somewhat unlikely that a Senate committee can assemble donors of information who are better informed in this area than the people already investigating it over the whole canvas of the Australian animal welfare area.

SPEECH.PARA: I also make the point that the welfare of animals in Australia is very significantly in the hands of the operators of primary industry. It is indeed their business to ensure that over and above their particular love and concern for animals-I am quite serious about this-the general nutrition of animals, their freedom from disease and the improvement in their breeding circumstances are improved continually and maintained at the highest possible level. That is not only in the interests of the animal husbander himself but also certainly in the interests of the Australian economy which is dependent for about 50 per cent on the earnings of the primary industrial field. Indeed, it is significant employment-wise not only to the 150,000 or so primary producers in this country but also to the 3 million to 4 million Australians who are at least indirectly, if not directly, involved in some areas of primary industry.

The other fear I have-it is only a fear and I trust that it certainly will not eventuate-is that there is a real possibility that an inquiry such as this, if not handled with care and with proper guidelines, may resolve itself into a media operation which is directed towards argument based significantly on emotion rather than logic. This, should it occur, would be a most unfortunate happening. It would be a negative contribution to the welfare of animals and, indeed, in a broader sense, to the Australian economy.

I draw attention, briefly, to the concern for animals and the evidence of it in inquiries that are already under way. Back in 1980 concern was expressed about the transport of brumbies from Northern Australia, about the pig and poultry industry and about the transport by sea of livestock. That concern has triggered off widespread inquiries and recommendations. I think it is pertinent that we should be aware of what has, in fact, been occurring and what has been achieved. A sub-committee on animal welfare was formed on the initiative of the Australian Agricultural Council through its Standing Committee on Agriculture. This sub- committee was to report on all animal welfare issues to the Standing Committee on Agriculture through the Animal Health Committee.

I will name just a few of the issues in order to identify the extent and depth of this inquiry. The inquiry covered the level of uniformity in the codes of practice and legislation in this area. It covered the question of transport of livestock. It covered the question of intensive farm practice, which is applicable more to the pig and poultry industry, perhaps, than to other livestock industries. It covered the matter of extensive livestock management which, of course, refers to the large scale or extensive grazing of cattle, sheep and other such animals, to the mustering, marketing and control of feral animals, to animal experimentation and livestock slaughter. To name those few areas is to indicate the depth and breadth of that inquiry.

I think it is pertinent also to consider the composition of the sub-committee on animal welfare because it, too, is widespread in its interests, its abilities and its skills. That sub-committee comprises representatives of the departments of agriculture in each State, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Commonwealth Department of Health, the Australian Bureau of Animal Health and the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. Finally, other committees are represented from within the Australian Agricultural Council.

Since 1980, 10 codes of practice have been drafted by this sub-committee. Four of them have already been approved by the Australian Agricultural Council. They relate to the pig industry, the domestic fowl industry and the road and rail transport of livestock. In June this year the sub-committee released, for public comment, two more codes of practice relevant to air transport of livestock and to the intensive husbandry of sheep. The other model codes which are still being developed are referable to sea transport, to humane destruction, to the capture and care of feral animals and to animals in slaughtering establishments. So I again stress the point that the investigation is intense and is widespread and is certainly responsible from the very nature of the composition of the sub- committee itself.

Mr Deputy President, it is worth mentioning that animal research is funded through the Department of Primary Industry and is now subject to ethical evaluation. Surely this is an important step that has been established. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has been responsible for the development of this ethical evaluation and such evaluation will affect a whole range of research areas-the Australian Meat Research Committee, the Australian Pig Industry Research Committee, the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee, the Australian Dairy Research Committee, the Poultry Research Advisory Committee , the Honey Research Committee and the Australian Wool Research Committee. The funding of all those areas is referable to an ethical evaluation of the proposition. All experiments must satisfy the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

I turn briefly to the subject of animals in research because this is an area of concern, and proper concern as instanced by Senator Chipp. I make the point that since 1979 the Australian Veterinary Association Ltd, New South Wales division, has been active in the field of animals in research. One Dr Margaret Rose, herself a Churchill fellow, is the convener of this group on animal experiments being carried out by the Australian Veterinary Association. I make the important point that after consultation-I mark the breadth of consultation-with universities, colleges of advanced education, departments of health, education, agriculture, national parks and wildlife, with industry groups and animal welfare groups, the sub-committee has compiled a list of recommendations. These proposals were submitted some time ago to the New South Wales Cabinet and we are waiting its views and its decisions.

I close my remarks by saying that we do not oppose the establishment of this Committee but we do consider that a widespread and responsible area of research has already been instigated, that a significant part of the results of that research have been implemented and that there is a very real concern for animal welfare in the Australian community as a whole and particularly in that part of the community, that industry, whose whole well-being, whose whole operation, is relevant to the welfare of animals. So I believe that whilst this Committee may eventually be established and may investigate this matter, it should be looking at it with very well defined guidelines. It should not become a platform for emotion rather than logic. Indeed, in my view, it should be aware of the results of the intense and widespread investigation that is already underway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is accepting the motion as moved by Senator Chipp, but I think I should add this caveat or reservation: The Senate might need to look at the number of committees that are currently established and also others which have been or are being proposed. For example, Senator Kilgariff gave notice of a motion yesterday to have a Senate committee inquire into the problem of petrol sniffing. In view of the very heavy existing demands and increasing demands being placed on not only the members of the committees, the honourable senators, but also the other resources, the Senate might need to determine the timing of this proposed inquiry and the priority which ought to be allocated to it vis-a- vis competing studies and inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move a motion relating to the membership and powers of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare, in accordance with documents circulated to honourable senators. To save the time of the Senate I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard. It is similar to all motions in relation to select committees, except that, to pick up the points mentioned by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), it calls for the appointment of four senators rather than the normal six senators. I ask that the motion dealing with the terms of membership, as circulated, be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The motion read as follows-
(1) That the Select Committee on Animal Welfare consist of four Senators, as follows:
(a) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(2) That the Committee proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(3) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(4) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(5) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(6) That the quorum of the Committee should be two members.

(7) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(8) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(9) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(10) That the Committee report to the Senate as soon as possible.

(11) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may send its report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is not available, to the Deputy-President, who is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation and, in such event, the President or Deputy-President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(12) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just conferred with the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, who is concerned. I had not seen notice of the composition of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare and I wanted to check with the shadow Minister whether a membership comprising one Opposition senator, in conjunction with one Australian Democrat senator and two Government senators, was desirable. In the light of the fact that we need time to consider it-I understand, obviously on the basis of very poor information, that it would be the usual membership of three senators from the Government and three from the Opposition-perhaps we could stand over consideration of this motion until a later hour this day. I therefore move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before the Senate deal with the income tax proposals which were announced in the May economic statement and in the Budget. A lot of debate has taken place on the provisions of these Bills both during the Budget debate and during the debate on the economic statement. I will confine my remarks to the legislation that is before us now. Of course, at the time of a Budget there are expectations that the provisions of legislation may be changed and that the circumstances of individuals may be affected by changes in the Budget. People expected to benefit from the Budget this year because of the priorities of the new Government. It was expected that changes would be made which would be of advantage to certain groups of people. I think the general mass of taxpayers had the expectation- these promises were contained in the policy speech-that there would be tax cuts for all. That matter was debated prior to the introduction of the Budget. However, it was seen in the Budget that no general tax cuts were to be made in relation to personal income tax. No account was to be taken of inflation by making adjustments for indexation so that those who reached average weekly earnings shortly after the Budget would not find themselves in a higher tax bracket. People's expectations were dashed at the time of the Budget, when they found that the Government certainly had not provided personal income tax cuts, nor was account taken of the movement into the higher tax bracket that has now occurred by those who are on average weekly earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget provided for upward indexation of excises. The Government recognised the movement that occurs as a result of inflation. It is, of course, a matter of some disappointment to those who are now in the higher tax bracket that some account was not taken of their circumstances. There were those affected by decisions made by the Government who received lump sum superannuation. The tax changes have been of some disadvantage to them.

Addressing my remarks to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1983, we can see that there are, in that, the changes that have been made to the prescribed payments tax system that had been introduced prior to the Budget by the Government. It will be recalled that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations had reviewed the prescribed payments tax system legislation and had recommended a number of changes to it. The changes that were recommended were adopted by the Government, and this Bill will make amendments to the income tax law to take those recommendations into account. Whilst it can be said that these amendments improve the prescribed payments tax system, they still leave difficulties for many of the industries affected by the tax and the difficulty in its administration by many companies is substantial. The readily available tax exemptions that were part of the former Government's proposal with regard to prescribed payments tax have still not become effective in the general way in which it had been expected that this tax would apply. So the prescribed payments tax amendments will alleviate the difficulties that were found by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and which had been highlighted by the many groups and individuals who are affected by the withholding of this tax at source.

This Bill also deals with some changes affecting rural industries. The cost to farmers under these Bills will be about $23m. As we look to the changes that have been made to the income equalisation deposit scheme and the abolition of the 10-year write off of capital expenditure for land clearing and swamp drainage, these matters will affect the rural sector. It could be claimed that in some cases there had not been a great deal of consultation prior to making the changes. Changes that are to the detriment of any income earners are of concern to them.

The change that has been made with regard to reserve forces pay is another matter of concern to those who give this service and who receive what is really a small payment for it. They have found that under the provisions of the Budget they will now pay tax on 50 per cent of the income that they receive. This is a change from the 100 per cent that was to be taxed, but it still means that members of reserve forces who receive this pay for their service are under the disadvantage of having it added to their income. In some cases it could put them into a higher tax bracket for that portion of their income. It is extraordinary that the description of the Bill says that it exempts from income tax only 50 per cent of the pay. What it really ought to say is that the Bill introduces tax on 50 per cent of the pay, because that is the effect on the part-time members of the reserve defence forces on income that they receive after 1 December this year.

I welcome some provisions in the Budget, particularly those concerning additional payments made in some circumstances to social security recipients and repatriation beneficiaries. The payments to carers for spouses, and provisions of that sort that are to be dealt with under the legislation, are of benefit. I have no argument with those. I think that it was a considerable decision that was taken to abolish the rebate of the standard rate of tax on up to $1,000 of dividends. This measure was introduced by the former Government in the 1982-83 Budget to give an incentive to Australians to invest, particularly those on limited incomes or lower incomes. An investment in shares in their own country can become more attractive if there is a tax concession or a recognition of that investment within the tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a cheap political stunt designed to buy a few votes for a premature election, as you very well know.

—Senator Walsh might suggest that it was that, but I think other people would suggest that it was an incentive to the small investor to invest in shares in companies in his own country and to participate in the investment program that we would all want to see. Although very often proposals are put forward claiming that it is just foreign investors who have incentives, I think this was a genuine introduction in the 1982-83 Budget to encourage the small Australian investor to invest and to have that incentive through the tax system. That incentive has been removed. Again, that probably reflects a priority of the government of the day, one that does not want to encourage individual investment or incentive. It was abolished with one sweep in this particular Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The change that was made also with regard to the minors' tax threshold from $1, 040 to $416 means that people who have a small income will now be put in the position of needing to lodge a tax return. In most cases they will need to make returns for children who have a small savings bank account and a very limited amount of income coming from that. It ought to be recognised that many children have gifts or savings placed in bank accounts for them for their education as they reach mature years. Recognition of this fact by having that low threshold of $1,040 was one encouragement for that sort of saving to be built up on behalf of children. I do not know that the Government has made any case that there was any abuse of this incentive or that it was something that it felt had to be reduced. It just seemed that it was a means of reducing again an incentive for savings and the benefit the tax system can give to encourage those savings, particularly as much of it was used for educational purposes by children.
