I stress the educational purposes use of this because, as we see, with the Government's education funding proposals there will be many who, in their educational expenditure, face the future with some doubt and some concern as to whether there will be the same sort of support for education that has been given in the past and whether it will be necessary for them to build up education funding for their children to take care of the future. That again is another change that was made. I think a small number of people who had planned for their futures will find that it makes a difference to them. Of course, when that occurs, we will find that there are people who will show their concern about tax changes and changes in their expectations.

There is also the modification of the tax averaging provisions with regard to primary producers. Again, this will be of concern to that sector. Changes have been made with regard to a number of other things, including the threshold on expenditure before the concessional rebate is able to be claimed. It has been raised to $2,000, but again there are those with educational expenditure in mind of which this measure will become a part who will feel some threat with regard to that type of assistance under the Income Tax Assessment Act.

All of these matters, as I said earlier, have been dealt with on a number of occasions in debates in this Budget session of parliament. The Opposition is not opposing any of the tax proposals in the sense of wishing to divide against the Bills or to make any amendments to them. We regard them as quite a fundamental part of the Government's Budget. When a Budget is introduced, the priorities of a government are shown. I think that the Government can be judged on the way in which it has established its priorities and the way in which it has cast the collection of revenue from the Australian people in this 1983-84 Budget. For these reasons, I simply draw attention to debates that have been held on the many changes that have been made in the tax area and to the philosophy of the Government that has flowed through to its own tax proposals. On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate that the Bills are not opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats compliment the Government on several aspects of these income tax Bills. At the same time we feel there is justifiable criticism of some shortcomings and changes of direction which do not fit either the Democrats' approach or, as I understand it, the Australian Labor Party's approach, not just to the tax system but also to the incentives, inducements and benefits that can flow from the tax system to indicate the Government's policies. In the first instance praise is due to the Government for adopting virtually in toto the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations report on the problems which had arisen from the withholding tax, the prescribed payments tax. As a result of that Committee's investigations the Government, through the Committee hearings stages and subsequently, has taken steps both legislatively through these Bills and administratively through the Australian Taxation Office to make life a little easier for those who have been caught up in the net of the prescribed payments tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Government acknowledged that the system was not very well introduced or administered in the early stages and that it did not take into account the great hardships that would be imposed on a number of small businesses, in particular, which suddenly found that they had a massive amount of paper work to cope with and, in many instances, on top of that, found that their cash budgets were literally tossed out the window and they had to revise their methods so that they could survive with this new, virtually instantaneous, cash collection system when previously they had been paying tax on an annual basis. In some cases they had not been paying tax at all. Of course, that was the reason for the new system. Congratulations are due to the Government for accepting the recomendations of the Senate Committee and for introducing and implementing them in this legislation.

Further commendation, although this is perhaps damning with feint praise, is due to the Government for reducing by 50 per cent the reserve defence forces income tax. It is only feint praise because many people believe that it is not very wise for the Government suddenly to impose a tax on a segment of the community which is acting in voluntary manner to protect this country and which is entitled to some additional benefits above and beyond the normal Service rates of pay. At least the Government has listened to representations made by the Australian Democrats and many other concerned and interested organisations, including the Opposition parties, for reducing that tax by 50 per cent, thereby at least ameliorating the situation and hopefully retrieving the situation to the point where a lot of people who may have considered withdrawing from the reserve defence forces will now change their minds and at least recognise that the Government does see value in their staying in the reserve defence forces. Hopefully a lot of other people will still be induced to take part and attracted to taking part in that very important facet of Australia's defence system.

One of the regrets I express on behalf of the Australian Democrats-this has already been expressed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle-is the abolition of the rebate of up to $1,000 on dividend income. This rebate was introduced by the previous Government-credit is due to it for that-as a means of getting small investors into the Australian corporate sector. Undoubtedly thousands of people who had saved up a little nest-egg and were about to retire had decided to take a bit of a risk and invest in Australian enterprise instead of putting their money into a savings account. I believe and the Australian Democrats believe that this was a worthwhile means of showing the people of Australia that we are a free enterprise nation and that we do want Australian ownership of Australian corporations. The Government, in setting this sort of lead, was indicating to the people of Australia that it encouraged Australians to be the owners of corporations. Perhaps there was even an opportunity of regaining some of the ownership of Australian corporations from overseas investors. As a result, they received not just the dividend which normally would be taxable, but had the first $1,000 of that dividend untaxed. That was not a very expensive thing, but it was a pointer to the way that this country sees the ownership of Australian enterprise.

It is disappointing to me and to the Democrats that the Government-perhaps it is caught up with some budgetary problems, but I suspect it is caught up more with ideological problems-does not want to give any encouragement to people to invest in Australian enterprises in this way and it obviously regards even that first $1,000 of dividend income as an important part of its tax revenue. Therefore, the Government will not discourage people but will take away some of the encouragement to people to invest in Australian enterprises. We feel so strongly about this matter that I wish to move an amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. I move:
At end of motion, add:

', but the Senate is of the opinion that the abolition of the rebate on up to $1 ,000 of dividend income of individual taxpayers will remove an inducement to middle income Australians to invest in Australian corporations which assisted in restoring corporate ownership of Australian companies into the hands of the Australian people'.

I wish also to place on record the very serious concern that the Australian Democrats have at the withdrawal of the deductibility of the cost of a taxpayer insulating his or her first home. Surely this Government came into government with a policy of encouraging the conservation of energy resources in this country. Before the election it was very closely associated with environmental movements which are dedicated to the replacement of fossil fuel energy resources by renewable energy resources. It just does not make sense for a government with that sort of an approach to energy conservation to now withdraw the one incentive that there is for people in Australia. It is not a massive incentive, but again it is a pointer to what the Government of Australia would like to see happen. It is the one incentive to conserve the fossil fuels, the energy sources , of this country. It was a simple matter of allowing tax deductibility for people who put appropriate insulation in their first home.

In this continent, which has massive energy consumptions caused by the excesses of heat in most parts of the country at certain times of the year, I cannot understand why this Government would suddenly say that it is no longer interested in helping people to conserve energy through this method of insulation. The Government is no longer willing to provide some sort of inducement or encouragement for this. Instead it intends to withdraw tax deductibility in respect of the cost of insulating a taxpayer's first home. I hope to goodness that this is not an indication that the Government is gung ho on pulling up all the coal that it can, on dragging out all the oil and gas that it can and on using all the non-renewable energy resources that this country has in the short term. If that is the case, God help future generations in terms of their energy needs.

It is time that we as a nation and this Government woke up to the fact that the greatest saving can be made through energy conservation methods. The Americans have proven that. At the time when there appeared to be a massive problem looming on the horizon for the people of America they pulled in their belts. They got into energy conservation. As a result they were able to minimise the effects of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries oil price rises and the threatened oil shortages. Of course, we have seen a reversal of the situation in the oil market throughout the world. This had occurred as a direct result of energy conservation in America and in other countries. I appeal to the Government: Please reconsider the decision. Have another look at it. Perhaps in next year's Budget the Government will come up with something even more exciting , even more attractive, for people to get into energy conservation. I indicate to the Government that the Australian Democrats feel so strongly about this that we will be voting against that part of these Bills.

Turning now to another conservation area, the Democrats do applaud the termination of the deductibility of land clearing expenditure for tax purposes. This practice has occurred over the years. I pay a great tribute to Senator Colin Mason. I am sure the Government will equally recognise and acknowledge Senator Colin Mason's initiative in this part of this tax package. It was Senator Colin Mason who introduced a Bill to remove the incentives which were resulting, in certain areas, in the destruction of forest and some of the natural growth of Australia. It was not necessary for those areas to be cleared and the Government was paying for it. Of course, this was quite unacceptable in many areas. It made no sense at all in a country barren of trees for the Government to provide an inducement to people to cut them down. So I applaud the Government for terminating the deductibility of land clearing expenditure.

Primary producers may not be very happy with the change to the tax averaging system which is part of this package of Bills. I think there are arguments for an against the system. The tax averaging system really does not accord with the original legislation. In terms of all taxpayers, the new legislation probably does provide for a more equitable system. I believe primary producers are entitled to a tax averaging system because of the potential for farmers to have very good or very bad seasons. In their very good seasons they have to pay optimum tax and the following year, if they have losses, there is no catch-up provision available for them under the normal tax system. The tax averaging system does, to a degree, overcome that problem for farmers. The Australian Democrats have applauded that system since its introduction. However, we are concerned that now we have a genuine, realistic and equitable tax averaging system, only one section of our community, one section of industry, will benefit from that system.

I should like the Government to consider prior to the next Budget the potential for this modified tax averaging system to be applied to small businesses. In many areas the scope for tax averaging just to allow small businesses to survive is great. Let me use as an illustration small business in rural areas, which suffer exactly the same highs and lows, the same peaks and troughs, as do the farmers in their community. The farmers benefit to a degree from the tax averaging system, but the very people who service the farmers in that community are denied the same system. I believe that is inequitable. I believe it is something that the Government could take on board, even if the system were applied only to rural areas. However, I would far rather see it applied to small businesses right across Australia because there are other reasons and other times when tax averaging is absolutely essential if businesses are to grow and, in some cases, to survive. We could simply say: 'Right, as step one let us move the system into rural areas, where there is an obvious correlation with the peaks and troughs of primary producers. Let us accept that small businesses suffer from those peaks and troughs and should be allowed into the tax averaging system. Then, as the second step let us bring into the system those many other areas of small business which tax averaging would allow to survive the troughs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you agree that it ought to apply to miners as well?

—Miners are given other tax benefits, and I have not considered the matter from that point of view. It is certainly one that is well worth investigating. However, tax averaging needs to be looked at in the context of the total package of tax benefits that apply to the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the Australian Democrats in the first instance applaud the introduction of the tax averaging system. We acknowledge the reasonable modification that is being made to the scheme. However, we believe that it is most appropriate for the modification to be applied to small businesses right across the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to make a few global comments on the Bills that are before the Senate and the reasons for them. The Bills embody most of the changes to the taxation system which were decided by the Government and announced both in the May statement and in the Budget. The Bills are heavily aimed at cancelling tax expenditures. When Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle made the point that they are an indicator of the direction of this Government and of its objectives, she was to that extent correct. This Government recognises that the fiscal effects of a concession through the taxation system and through additional government expenditure are identical. The previous Government, and particularly the previous Prime Minister, seemed to have some cargo-cultish belief that appropriating public moneys to spend in a Budget was innately wrong but that providing concessions through the taxtion system, which had exactly the same effect, on balance, on government revenues was something that was highly desirable and ought to be encouraged. I think that reflected the philosophical or intellectual shortcomings and the prejudices of the previous Prime Minister. I am distressed at the implication of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's remarks that hangover of Fraserism, that legacy of Fraserism, is still with the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the question of fiscal drag, lack of indexation, or whatever one wants to call it, on the personal income tax schedule, it is correct that the schedule which was applied for eight months-I stress for eight months only-of the previous financial year has been retained for this year. This important point is relevant to the suggestion Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle made that because some people will be moving into higher tax brackets the proportion of income paid in tax will increase. That is not so when one compares the present financial year with the past financial year. I have a few specific examples which cover both the single taxpayer and the taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children, whether on average weekly earnings or at 85 per cent of average weekly earnings, which is around the median level of earnings. That is, about half the people are below 85 per cent of average weekly earnings and about half are above. In all cases the single taxpayer and the taxpayer with a dependent spouse will pay a lower proportion of total income in tax this financial year than they paid in the previous financial year. I will not bother to read out the figures, but that is a fact with those examples and without doubt applies to the overwhelming majority of taxpayers as a whole. The reason, of course, is that for four months of last year a significantly higher tax rate was applied.

I will deal with just a few other specific matters which have been raised. Firstly, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said that the $1,000 exemption from taxation of dividend income provided in the 1982-83 Budget by the previous Government was provided to give an incentive to small investors. I want to make several comments on that. Firstly, on the basis of a dividend payment of 10 per cent a person would need to have $10,000 available for investment to take advantage of this provision. Whether that makes one a particularly small investor or not I suppose is a question of the point in the spectrum from which one views it. More importantly, somebody who is a relatively small investor, and even somebody who has a relatively low income, is not necessarily a person in poverty. Indeed, they may be, and very often are, relatives of quite rich people and the so-called incentive would be exploited.

Whether it ought to be regarded as an incentive or as a cheap electoral stunt which was one of a rag-bag of promises designed to buy up a sufficient number of pressure groups to win a premature election and was included in the 1982-83 Budget is for that reason to some extent, I suppose, a matter for judgment. But when one looks at the Fraser Government's 1982-83 Budget in toto, what becomes perfectly clear is that there was no economic strategy in it, there was a political strategy aimed at winning a premature election. That strategy failed.

The greater part of the rag-bag of promises contained in the 1982-83 Budget were tax expenditures. A significant fact about such tax expenditures was that the revenue cost was almost entirely deferred into the next financial year. As a result of that $1,000 tax rebate and a number of other measures introduced in the 1982-83 Budget, potential revenue or revenue which would have otherwise been available in this financial year was reduced by approximately $1.5 billion. In other words, this Government on taking office inherited from the previous Administration the bill for the rag-bag of promises designed to buy up a number of pressure groups with an assortment of tax expenditures which the previous Government had introduced in the 1982-83 Budget.

If the Opposition or the Australian Democrats are seriously interested in the question of the taxation of both corporate income and of dividends paid to individuals from corporate income, I suggest to them that this superficial, slick, and seemingly attractive $1,000 tax rebate is certainly not the way to proceed. If they are seriously interested in that question and particularly if they are interested in equity between taxpayers-it would be amazing, if the Liberal Party, given its record, were seriously interested in that question-I suggest that they look at the interaction of corporate taxation, the degree to which corporate profits are retained within companies and not distributed to shareholders and the personal tax system.

Such an analysis has been done. There may have been others, but one such analysis of which I am aware was carried out by Peter Swan a couple of years ago . It showed that with the combination of taxation laws and business practices then prevailing and I do not imagine that they would have changed substantially, a higher proportion of tax was levied on lower income shareholders than was levied on higher income shareholders. Peter Swan proposed that all corporate income in the hands of a company ought to be subject to a tax rate of 60 per cent and that a portion of the tax already paid to the company ought to be distributed to shareholders if their marginal tax rate were less than 60 per cent. If honourable senators opposite are seriously interested in equity, they should proceed along that line and not do what the Fraser Government did in 1982 . For that reason the Government will not accept the second reading amendment proposed by Senator Jack Evans.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Jack Evans also referred to tax averaging and to the provision introduced post-Budget in 1977 under which primary producers could opt in or out of averaging, depending on whether their actual income was above or below the five year average. I stress that that provision was introduced post-Budget in 1977 and it is to be removed by this Bill. The history of this provision is worth noting because it tells us something about the current thinking of the Liberal Party of Australia and the story is sordid and distressing. The tax schedules and the four step scales, if one wants to count the zero rate as well, were introduced by the Fraser Government in 1977. Following that introduction it became apparent that there would be little if any advantage to primary producers in the tax averaging system as it then existed.

Of course, the 1977 Budget was another one of those cynical Budgets brought in with the intention not of pursuing any rational or long term economic strategy but of setting up the requirements for a premature Federal election. That is what ultimately happened. The Government of the day, because of those changes and their effects on the previously existing tax averaging system, received some complaints from farmer organisations. It then in its characteristic knee-jerk manner introduced what became known as the in/out provision wherein primary producers could take advantage of tax averaging in years when their income was above the five year average, but on years when their income was below the five year average, they paid tax and were assessed on the actual income. The effect of that was described by no less a person than the now President and then Treasurer/Secretary of the Agricultural Outlook Conference in 1979 as a system under which heads, farmers win, tails, all other taxpayers lose. What I find disturbing is that in implicitly endorsing that system of heads, farmers win, tails, all other taxpayers lose, and in recommitting the Liberal Party to that system, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has shown that the Party is still locked into Fraserism and above all is locked into craven subservience in policy matters to the National Party.

In regard to Senator Jack Evans's comments on the same subject and his suggestion that the averaging system should be extended to all taxpayers, I have two comments to make. Firstly, the averaging system could have some perverse effects on taxpayers' current liability. For example, in the year when income is below the five year average the actual assessment received by a taxpayer will be higher than it would have been if he had been taxed on that current year average . This is because the rate is determined by the average and not the actual income. That can be further complicated by the delay between the actual tax liability incurred and the collection of tax liability from provisional taxpayers. That is the first comment. But the averaging system does not necessarily overcome the problems which some individuals may face and to which Senator Jack Evans addressed his comments.

Secondly, even with the removal of the illogical and ill-considered in/out provisions introduced post-Budget and in pre-electoral haste by the Fraser Government in 1977, and while inflation continues at any rate but more importantly at a rate which is reasonably high, the tax averaging provisions do provide quite a significant concession because they effectively apply indexation retrospectively. This is because the nominal income or the income on which the rate is assessed is the five-year average, which is of course on average the income of about two and a half years ago rather than the present income. It carries with it an element of retrospective application of indexation on a personal scale. It is a complex matter and I do not propose to discuss it any further at this stage. There are alternative systems which may be both more rational and more equitable but the Labor Party has been in Government for only eight months and we have not had time to clean out the stable entirely. There are two proposed amendments-one contains a typographical error and the other to which Senator Jack Evans has referred is more substantive-which I propose to move during the Committee stage. As I said, the Government does not accept the second reading amendment moved by Senator Jack Evans.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question in relation to clause 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1983. This clause deals with the tax concessions for the clearing of trees and other native vegetation from the land. It appears that this clause will remove section 75A from the Income Tax Assessment Act, which provided for an equalisation over 10 years of this deduction, but it will not touch section 75 of the parent Act which indeed allows a deduction in the current year. This is to be regretted, especially since the community at large was given the impression in the Budget that the Government was providing conservationists with something of a win, giving a major concession, by in effect making clearing of land and trees not a taxable deduction. That now appears not to be the case, although I would like the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) to give me information if I have misunderstood the matter. It seems to me that section 75A is to be removed whereas section 75, which covers the current year of income, has not been removed. As the Minister and honourable senators will know, I have a private member's Bill current to this effect; it would remove that deduction completely. I intend to persist with that Bill because I think it is more proper for me to do that than to move an amendment at this stage in Committee which would not have support. I would like to have the Minister's statement on whether my understanding is correct and whether in fact, when this Bill is passed, the situation will still remain that people can clear native vegetation, trees or undergrowth from the land and claim it as a tax deduction in the current year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, Senator Mason beat me; I was about to move the Government amendments but I will answer his question first. No, it is not a tax deduction in the current year. That provision was removed in 1973. Until 1973 such expenditure had been immediately and fully deductible from taxable income. In 1973 the previous Labor Government amendment extended the period over which that deduction may be claimed from the current year to a 10-year period. The present amendment removes it as a tax deduction altogether unless some contract was entered into prior to Budget day, 23 August. I now seek leave to move together two amendments to Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 4, lines 9 to 27 (inclusive), leave out the clause, substitute the following clause:

Exemptions ''4. (1) Section 23 of the principal Act is amended- (a) by inserting after paragraph (kb) the following paragraph: '(kba) payments by way of an open employment incentive bonus under Part VIIIA of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974;';
(b) by inserting in paragraph (s) 'one-half of' before 'the pay and allowances' ;
(c) by inserting in paragraph (sa) 'one-half of' before 'the pay and allowances '; and
(d) by inserting in paragraph (sa) 'one-half of' before 'any gratuity'.
''(2) The amendment made by paragraph (1) (a) applies to payments made on or after 1 October 1983.
''(3) The amendments made by paragraphs (1) (b), (c) and (d) apply to pay and allowances in respect of service, and a gratuity in respect of a calling out, on or after 1 December 1983.''.
(2) Page 9, clause 19, line 36, leave out ''a first instalment'', substitute '' no prescribed''.

One of the amendments is of substance and one is of a formal kind. It may be convenient if I speak now to both of them. The substantial amendment concerns clause 4 which proposes to phase withdrawal of the tax exemption for pay of part time members of the reserve defence forces. One-half of payments in respect of service on or after 1 December 1983 and before 1 December 1984 was to remain exempt while payments for service on or after 1 December 1984 was to be taxable in full. Following representations on the matter, the Government has reconsidered the proposal with a view to modifying the impact that the application of full marginal tax rates would have had on the pay of members with income from other sources, typically their regular employment. The main amendment to the Bill will have the effect that the second stage of the exemption withdrawal will not proceed. As a result, members of the Reserves will be taxed on one-half of all pay and allowances for service on or after 1 December 1983. This will mean that remuneration for service in the reserve forces is effectively to be taxed at half the marginal rates of tax applying to other income.

There is also a formal amemdment to clause 19 which is necessary to correct a previously undetected printing error in proposed new sub-section 221YHAA (1) which occurred after the draft of the Bill had been settled and approved for introduction. The explanatory memorandum which has been circulated correctly explains the conditions for the operation of this proposed new sub-section, taking this amendment into account.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise with the Committee and with the Government the question of the abolition of the rebate of up to $1,000 of dividend income of individual taxpayers. I must say that this provision is the direct result of many years of negotiation and fight by people who have been concerned about the double dipping by governments into taxpayers' pockets. Certainly for the six years that I was in the Senate prior to 1982, in the run up to the Budget discussions I constantly put to the then Government that it ought to do something about this double dipping. There is no doubt that it is double dipping. I see Senator Button laugh at the suggestion that the Government is double dipping into the taxpayers' pockets, but that happens to be the situation. The truth is that what happens is that companies are taxed on company profits at a very substantial rate of 46c in the dollar. Then, when a company declares a dividend-in other words gives to the people who own the company a share of those profits which after all are their own profits-and the money comes back into the pockets of the shareholders the Government has another go and taxes the individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fascinating that this double dipping provision has in fact been restored by a Government which gets very cross about citizens in the nation who, according to them, double dip against the Government; by that I mean taxpayers and pensioners who this Government claims are always double dipping against this Government. But here is a situation where the Government has restored a provision whereby it double dips against the taxpayers of this nation.

This matter is of grave concern in all areas of companies. Firstly, there is the public company. Let me say right from the word go that this $1,000 was in no way a concession. It was just trying to give back to people what they were entitled to. What is the situation with a public company? What has been the result of this? I think the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, will agree with me that the figures clearly disclose a massive withdrawal of shareholding in public companies by ordinary shareholders. What has happened is that investment organisations, insurance companies and such people have moved into the Australian share market to replace the ordinary shareholders who have withdrawn in very large numbers from the holding of shares in public companies.

That is the first step. The second step as a result of this double taxation has been that companies have tried to reorganise their affairs so as to increase the value of their shares on the share market so that there is a capital gain instead of a dividend income to those people who have the courage to buy their shares, who, as I have said, are usually finance companies, investment companies or insurance companies which are going in to the share market seeking some sort of capital gain, not seeking a dividend gain. For many years those of us who have been desperately concerned about this matter have been putting to governments that they ought to encourage the ordinary shareholder to go back into the share market by giving them the opportunity to get back what they are entitled to. That is in regard to public companies.

Let us now look at the situation in relation to private companies. Let us take, for example, an organisation from my area such as Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd. Fletcher Jones desires to have its employees as owners of the organisation. But, of course, on any application of the present system, once that private company declares a dividend to its employee shareholders, what happens is that the Government has two goes at the profits. Therefore, if a company which, for example, has a whole range of employee shareholders decides to declare a dividend of, say, $100,000 in favour of the employee shareholders, it firstly has to pay $46,000 to the Government out of the $100,000. The employee shareholders end up with $54,000 instead of the $100,000 to which they were entitled. Of course, there is a way around it by the use of clever advisers such as lawyers and accountants. What can happen is that that sort of company can reorganise its affairs so that the employees appear to lend the company the money that should be in it as share capital and then have their shares paid up to a cent or some such figure instead of being fully paid up. The company can then pay interest to its employee shareholders and it can pay the whole $100,000 to those employee shareholders. That is the sort of shenanigans companies have to get up to to try to avoid double taxation on those sorts of moneys in the hands of employee shareholders.

The terrible thing about it, of course, with private companies is that not only is the company taxed first but also the company tax legislation requires the company to declare a dividend in favour of shareholders and then it has a second go at the shareholders. I say to Senator Walsh that I recognise the Government has decided to abandon this provision for this Budget, but there are many ways of restoring this equity to shareholders in the nation. There are all sorts of ideas that I, and others, put up to the former Government as to ways in which it could restore some equity to the shareholders of the nation. I am sure that Senator Walsh can think of a number of those, as well as I can.

This provision of $1,000 of dividend income of individual taxpayers being a rebate was a decision of the last Government. I think it was a fair and reasonable solution to the problem. If this Government does not accept that-by this legislation it clearly does not accept it-I ask it to think up some such device for its next Budget which will provide some equity to the shareholders of this country and provide some inducement to the people of the nation to reinvest in the shares of this country. After all, we keep talking about Australia buying back the farm and about our concerns about foreign investment in the nation. Yet this Government-I do not mean only this Labor Government, I mean the Federal government-over all these years has constantly used this taxation device in order to encourage shareholders in Australia to get out of public companies and to invest their money in some other form of investment which will provide them with a tax free capital gain instead of investing in the big shares of this country, which they ought to be doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague's remarks prompt me to say something about this matter too, because I think the Government's action of introducing this income tax legislation demonstrates a great deal of muddled thinking by the Labor Government in this whole area. The fact is that, very clearly, this incentive-that is what it is-of $1,000 of the first part of dividend income being exempt from tax provides a clear opportunity for people who have their moneys locked up in high interest deposites in loans of some kind or in some other secure investment of that type, to get out and take the extra risk of putting their money into Australian enterprise. It is there that we can create more jobs and opportunities arise for people to take part in the growing wealth of this country, rather than their having their investments locked into very secure investments such as mortgage investments and things of that kind which have no capital appreciation in them. For that reason this matter raises a very big matter of principle and I believe the Opposition will support the Australian Democrats' amendment on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: There are one or two other matters to which I would like to refer and to which Senator Lewis brought our attention. There is, of course, a very clear question of equity in this matter. The result of the Government's measure to restrict this exemption will be to force the bigger investors, such as companies, investment trusts, superannuation funds and life assurance companies, to take an even greater part in investing in the share market than they do already. We know that that activity on the part of those companies has already excluded, to a very large extent, the smaller investor. Of course, this legislation will only increase that trend. It is pretty clear that public companies that invest in other public companies on the stock exchange have a very clear advantage over the individual in that they can take advantage of section 46 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and not pay tax on the dividends of their company until they, in turn, distribute the dividends to their shareholders. Secondly, life assurance companies have a very clear advantage, tax wise, compared with the individual. Thirdly, investment trusts pay tax only at very significantly lower rates than the marginal rate of tax that would apply to individuals who have to pay tax on dividends at rates on top of that applicable for other incomes such as salary. The question of superannuation funds arises. Those are mainly tax exempt bodies, so they do not pay tax on their dividends either.

So there are clear advantages for the bigger operators in the Australian capital markets to take up shareholdings and so concentrate them in their hands. The opportunities that are available to this Government to try to diversify that investment into the hands of the smaller, average investor will be lost by this amendment which the Government has seen fit to bring in. We disagree with it in principle. We believe that the greatest advantage to the Australian population arises from a diversity of shareholdings in our great investments, such as mining and other Australian enterprises, and we encourage people to so invest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be, as Senator Lewis suggested, that the previous Government, in its last Budget introduced in 1982, finally took heed of the representations being made by him and a number of other people about what he called double dipping in taxation. I suspect, however, that it had a great deal more to do with the fact that, when framing the 1982 Budget, the former Government was planning to have a premature election and knew that, by adopting tax expenditure of this type, it could increase its appeal to a section of the electorate and, moreover, do so at no cost to current year revenue; in other words, it could send on the bill for that tax expenditure to this Government, which in fact it has done.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned earlier that I think a very substantial case can be made for comprehensive reform of the interaction of personal and company income tax. But I do not believe and the Government does not believe, that the one-off, very limited change that was made by the previous Government last year is the way to approach that. It is probably correct, as Senator Lewis said, that the trend has been for individual shareholders to withdraw from public companies and for there to be a greater degree of participation in public companies through institutions . From memory, that is correct. But other factors have influenced that as well, one of which, of course, would be the growth of superannuation and the tax treatment of income earned within superannuation funds. Again, what he said in relation to private companies is correct. But the requirement to distribute dividends is now down to, I think, 20 per cent. So his point is correct, but I think it is less substantive than his comments would have suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously you do not have any shares in a private company.

—They are not required to distribute a very high proportion of their profits without incurring Division 7 penalties. The honourable senator is quite right; I do not have any shares in private companies. He has probably had a look at my declaration of pecuniary interests to confirm that.
—It was the Doodlakine Farmers Co-op.

—That is not a private company. I can assure the honourable senator that they are also worthless. I have just one final comment: I do not dispute for a moment that the exemption of the first $1,000 of income from dividends provides an incentive for some people at least to buy shares, but there is a difference between buying shares and actual investment in the economic sense. The act of purchasing shares in an established company simply transfers ownership from one person to another. A different, and qualitatively different, step is required before actual investment takes place. It does seem to have been assumed by speakers on the other side that buying shares is the same thing as actually investing in the economic sense, and that is a very important distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter relates to an incident which I understand occurred early yesterday morning when a tent on the lawns of Parliament House is said to have collapsed after 'four people cut supporting ropes'. I am quoting from a report in the Australian this morning. That same report comments:

SPEECH.PARA: A Federal Police spokesman said officers had tried to find a blue car reported in the area at the time of the incident, but had caught no one.
I have just been given a copy of a Press release from the 'Peace Embassy, The Lawns' of today's date in which this incident is referred to, and this statement is made:
However, the Number plate was recorded by one of the same fast-movers who was here in '81--
I gather this is some sort of group among the protesters. It continues:

. . . this information was then offered to the Federal Police Officer on 'duty' . He laughed and refused to accept the information so this morning this information was given to Sergeant Cameron and we believe, it was suggested by M. P. Colin Mason (Democrats) that he act upon it. So far no policeman has come to inspect the damage or to make official enquiries.

I merely wish to say to the Senate, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I do not know a Sergeant Cameron and I have made no suggestion of any kind to him at any time. I would not do so because it is plainly the duty of members of the Australian Federal Police to act on information supplied to them and it is a reasonable assumption that they would do so.

DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE AND STATUTORY AUTHORITIES AMENDMENT BILL 1983COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (REDEPLOYMENT AND RETIREMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1983COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS) REPEAL BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —These three Bills seek to repeal legislation concerning Public Service employment which was passed during the life of the Fraser Government. Two of them in particular, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill 1983 and the Commonwealth Employees ( Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill 1983, deal with a development which had occurred during the period when that Government was in office concerning new methods of industrial action being pursued by public servants and Commonwealth employees. The other Bill, the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1983, seeks to amend the Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Act which was part of a scheme to enable redeployment of public servants in certain cases under certain procedures and for earlier retirement and declarations of redundancy. (Quorum formed) Mr Acting Deputy President, I was just opening my remarks in relation to these Bills, which seek to repeal some important legislation of the previous Government in regard to the Commonwealth Public Service and Commonwealth employment. The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill deals with redeployment and early retirement and declarations of redundancy in certain cases.

SPEECH.PARA: The mischief this legislation sought to deal with, and hopefully to correct, was a tendency which developed for certain groups of public servants-I hasten to state that it was very much a minority of public servants-to take a new form of industrial action which was short of absolutely striking or ceasing work. They refused to perform certain aspects of their work. It was believed that in that case there was a common law rule which prevented an employee from obtaining payment for work which was only partially performed. That was a principle known as 'no work as directed, no pay'. That has been a principle of the relationship between employer and employee at common law, although under some awards it may have been modified to some extent. Basically, that is a rule which applied to an employee's contract of employment, and it was assumed that it would apply also to the Public Service. In an event of that kind, where employees refused to perform work which was part of their duties and which they were directed to perform, then there could be refusal to pay their salaries. However, in a case before the Supreme Court in New South Wales in 1980 it was found, somewhat to everyone's surprise, that in fact the principle of no work as directed, no pay did not apply in the Public Service because of the elaborate provisions of Public Service legislation. So that fairly simple and, I think, basically sensible principle of common law could not be used to meet that situation, and that was the reason for the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill. It simply restored, by statutory force, that common law principle and applied it to public servants and to employees of a number of statutory authorities that were included in the legislation.

This Government is seeking to repeal that legislation, presumably on the ground of the industrial policy that this Government will pursue, namely, that matters should be dealt with by the arbitration system. Although there may be some awards which qualify this right in some way, nevertheless it is a basic principle of a contract of employment. There does not seem to be any reason why public servants should not be governed by its provisions. Even more important than that is the fact that public servants enjoy considerable privileges in relation to their employment, I think much greater privileges than are enjoyed by ordinary employees in private employment, even taking into account our elaborate system of awards and industrial relations. Public servants and other Commonwealth employees have considerable advantages, as I have said, in relation to their method of selection, permanency of employment, methods of promotion, rights of appeal in regard to many of these matters, rights of appeal against various managerial decisions, and so on. Of course, these days in many cases public servants receive very much higher and more generous salaries than the private sector and very beneficial superannuation benefits.

It is reasonable in the view of the Opposition-this was its view when in government-that people who enjoy all these advantages should have correlative duties imposed on them to perform the work they are directed to do and which form part of their duties anyway. They should not be able to take industrial action by performing part of their duties and yet receive full pay for doing so. Their employer-the authority, the Public Service Board and so on-is still obliged to pay them full salaries and is prevented from taking what seems to be a reasonable and effective step of simply refusing to pay them when they are at work but not performing the full duties for which they are employed. That very basic principle is at stake. A very sensible way of resolving that sort of issue is not to pay them. Indeed, as I have said, historically it has been part and parcel of the contract of employment. That principle apparently will now be swept away by the Government. It seeks to repeal provisions in the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Act which are designed to enable and facilitate the Public Service Board and other employing statutory authorities to take action against employees who are not doing their jobs properly and certainly not doing them fully. The Public Service Board in its annual report indicated that it has found this legislation useful. That seems to confirm the view the Opposition has taken, which, as I said, it took in government.

The second Bill before us, the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1983, will repeal some provisions of the Act which were inserted by the previous Government to deal with a particular situation which arose after the Act had been passed. This Act sets down a scheme under which additional powers can be exercised in relation to certain Commonwealth employees in order to achieve redeployment, early retirement or, in some cases, redundancy. The Act lays down quite elaborate procedures to protect the rights of employees affected by it. After the Act came into operation proceedings were instituted before the Public Service Arbitrator and a determination was given by the Arbitrator which qualified in some way the procedures which were laid down by the Act and the regulations under it. This Act was intended to be a code applying to this problem and to these sorts of situations and the decision of the Arbitration authority cut across the provisions of this statutory code. It did so in a way which was unforeseen and which was not regarded by the previous Government as within the comtemplation of the Parliament-certainly of the Government-in passing legislation in the form it did.

The amendment to the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act was passed. It prevented the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from hearing applications of that kind and making decisions on them, in that way qualifying the statutory provisions. The second Bill now before us will enable the Government to repeal those amending provisions. It will enable the arbitration authorities to qualify the statutory scheme for redeployment and retirement of public servants and Commonwealth employees. Again, it is doing this presumably because of the principle of the overriding authority of the arbitration system in regard to public employment. As I have said, the Opposition does not believe that that is the case. We believe that public servants and public employees hold special privileges. As a result of that and as a result of the statutory benefits they enjoy they should also be governed by some statutory obligations and duties. We believe it was perfectly reasonable that these provisions were inserted in the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. For that reason the Opposition also opposes the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1983 which seeks to repeal those provisions.

The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill is probably the most controversial of all these pieces of legislation. It seeks to repeal the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act holus-bolus, in line with the attitude that the Government, when it was in opposition, has always taken towards it. This legislation was introduced as a measure of last resort in certain very difficult situations in regard to industrial action by Commonwealth employees. It was passed in 1977 in the aftermath of the very severe air traffic controllers strike which occurred in, I think, May 1977.

Many of us will remember that the most disruptive character of that strike was that it went on for some time. It revealed the inadequate powers of the Government and of the Public Service Board to deal with a situation of that kind . Obviously there are the ordinary arbitration provisions available. But it was the view of the then Government, and it is still the view of the Opposition, on the same principles as I have been enunciating in this debate, that public servants have a special responsibility not only to their employers, the Government and the Public Service Board, but also to the community. That responsibility is not to create industrial mayhem and the type of utter disruption which has sometimes occurred, as it occurred during the air traffic controllers strike and as it occurred subsequently, and to which the Act was applied, in the Department of Social Security when Senator Chaney was the Minister. I think we all vividly remember that period when a relatively small group in that Department was very severely restricting by virtue of its quite unjustified type of industrial action the public service which was provided to such a large section of the public, the pensioners of this country.

As I have said, this legislation was introduced to be used only in last resort situations, when other forms of conciliation and arbitration had failed to achieve a result. It enables suspension of those engaged in industrial action and ultimately their dismissal-although I am not aware that it has ever been used to that extent, but only to suspend. Also, power is given under the legislation to stand down those employees who cannot be usefully or gainfully employed as a result of the industrial action of their fellow workers, which is a long-standing principle in industrial law. It is true that under private employment applications have to be made to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to apply stand down clauses, although there are some automatic stand down clauses included in a number of awards. It was the previous Government's policy that there should be an automatic power to stand down in these circumstances, although legislation to achieve that was held up and ultimately was not passed by the Senate. The attitude when we were in government was not to make distinctions between private and public employment in that regard but to give effect to a wide principle that where employees cannot be usefully employed as a result of industrial action, the employer should have the right to stand them down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that should be the case with private employment?

—That was the legislation that we introduced to enable that to be done in private employment. Some awards permit automatic stand down, as I understand it. But that was the policy that we sought to apply to private employment as well as to public employment and that was provided for in the legislation which the Government now seeks to repeal. The legislation was used most sparingly during the period it was in operation. It was passed in 1977. It was not even proclaimed until it was first used in 1979. Mr Fife, at that time a Minister in the previous Government, gave particulars of the use of this legislation in an answer to a question in the House of Representatives on 8 December 1982. I seek leave to incorporate the answer that Mr Fife gave. I have not had an opportunity of referring it to the Minister at the table, but if he will give leave, I should like to have incorporated in Hansard the answer given to Mr Les McMahon.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) and (2) The Public Service Board, having consulted with the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, has informed me that the suspension provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1977 have been used nine times in Commonwealth employment. The details of the use of the Act are as follows:

(a) Some 120 members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees' Association employed in the Australian Telecommunications Commission, were suspended from duty for the period 13-17 July 1979 for implementing work bans in support of a wage claim.

(b) 1132 Transport Workers' Union members were suspended in the period 21-31 July 1981 in the Departments of Administrative Services, Capital Territory, Defence, Housing and Construction, National Development and Energy, and Transport. The suspensions, which were issued over industrial action taken in support of a pay claim, were subsequently cancelled.

(c) 638 members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association and 343 members of the Australian Public Service Association (Fourth Division Officers) employed in the Australian Telecommunications Commission were suspended from duty for the period 22-26 July 1981 in connection with the implementation of work bans in support of a pay claim.

(d) 480 members of the Licensed Aircraft Engineers' Association employed in Trans-Australia Airlines were suspended from duty for the period 14-17 August 1981 in connection with strike action taken in support of a pay claim.

(e) Approximately 90 broadcasting engineering officers employed in the Australian Broadcasting Commission were suspended from 14 to 17 August 1981 for engaging in strike action over a pay claim. In addition, some 230 other employees in the Australian Broadcasting Commission were stood down during the course of the dispute because they could not be gainfully employed.

(f) 26 members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees' Association employed in the Australian Telecommunications Commission at the Haymarket Exchange were suspended from 2-14 December 1981 for implementing work bans in connection with a staffing dispute. 13 other staff at the Exchange were stood down during the course of the dispute.

(g) During the period 7-17 December 1981, a total of 451 members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association employed in the Department of Social Security were suspended for implementing work bans in support of staffing claims. Suspensions were progressively lifted from 11 December and the final 414 were lifted on 17 December 1981.

(h) Some 640 Transport Workers' Union members were suspended from duty in the period 11-24 December 1981 for engaging in industrial action in support of a pay claim. The Departments of the Capital Territory, Administrative Services and Housing and Construction were affected, as were the Australan Capital Territory Electricity Authority and the Capital Territory Health Commission.

(i) Approximately 2240 members of the Australian Capital Territory Teachers' Federation employed in the Commonwealth Teaching Service were suspended from duty during the period 12-17 March 1982 for engaging in industrial action in support of a pay claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —For all those reasons, the Opposition opposes the attempts to repeal these pieces of legislation. It reaffirms the policy behind these pieces of legislation, which were, as I have said, all introduced when we were in government. We believe this is perfectly consistent with the obligations of people in public employment, and it does not affect their rights to have access to the arbitral tribunals if there are disputes. It deals simply with industrial action of one sort or another which is really impermissible for people with those duties and with the privileges and benefits that they have as public employees. As I have said, in the case of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act, that legislation was intended to be only a measure of last resort and it was only applied thus. It is an effective piece of legislation. It is important that it should be available to the public employers in certain situations which have not been able to be resolved by the ordinary industrial conciliation and arbitration methods. The Opposition believes that this legislation should be retained and used in that way, and only in that way. This Government will regret its decision to seek to repeal the legislation, if it is successful in doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating three Bills, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill, the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill, which are designed to bring an end to a number of punitive measures introduced by the former Government. These Bills constitute an important part of the Hawke Government's consensus approach to industrial relations in that they repeal three very draconian pieces of legislation. They represent a genuine attempt by this Government to restore equity and common sense to the handling of industrial relations matters, particularly in the public sector. Over the last seven years, under the former Government, Commonwealth employees experienced a gradual erosion of their rights in the work place, which led to some of the most bitter disputes ever witnessed in our public sector. The previous Government knew exactly what would be the consequences of enacting these pieces of legislation. That Government knew that it was completely against the International Labour Organisation principles. Such was the hypocrisy of the former Government that, on the one hand, it would stand up in support of the Polish trade union movement, Solidarity, and yet, on the other hand, it was in the business of denying its own employees rights to which workers in the private sector were entitled under the accepted democratic processes.

SPEECH.PARA: I will look at each of these Bills in turn, because I think there have been some misconceptions within the Opposition about their purposes. The Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill 1983 has as its main aim the repeal of the no work as directed no pay provisions in the Public Service Act. These punitive provisions were introduced in 1980 and gave the Public Service Board and six Commonwealth authorities the power to declare that staff who failed to comply with an authorised direction relating to the performance of their duties were not to be paid their salaries. No appeal mechanism was provided within this legislation. As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) pointed out in his second reading speech, the Act specifically prohibited the making of awards or determinations by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the Public Service Arbitrator which were inconsistent with the provisions of the legislation. In other words, employees had no access to the normal arbitration processes. Of course, it was claimed by the former Government that this was merely bringing public sector employees into line with those in the private sector. The fact of the matter is that it went much further than that because in the private sector the ability of employers to apply this no work as directed no pay principle is automatically constrained by the terms of the various awards. Therefore, the Government is seeking to force the Public Service Board and the various Commonwealth authorities to go to an industrial tribunal-either the Public Service Arbitrator or the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-to obtain such an order. It needs to be emphasised for the benefit of honourable senators opposite that we are not removing the right of these public sector employers to make use of the no work as directed no pay provisions. We are merely saying that any such decision must have the consent of the appropriate industrial tribunal. It seems to me that this is a fairer and more democratic way of applying such a power. The previous Government obviously took a more authoritarian stand on such matters. It saw fit to bypass the accepted means of arbitration which have served this country so well for so many years.

Another example of the previous Government's authoritarian approach to industrial relations was the introduction of the Commonwealth Employees ( Employment Provisions) Act in 1977. This Act provided for the direct suspension or dismissal of Commonwealth employees engaged in industrial action or the direct standing down of Commonwealth employees affected by such industrial action without referring it to any industrial tribunal. The introduction of this legislation created a lot of animosity within the Public Service and was very vigorously opposed by both the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and the Australian Public Service Association. It led to a situation of unparalleled confrontation within the Public Service. By its very nature, it created ill-feeling between management and other staff. Names were taken of people who went to strike meetings and, allegedly, those names were recorded for posible future action. I wonder whether that Government, supposedly so concerned with the efficiency of the Public Service, ever stopped to count the man hours wasted in all these name-taking exercises and so forth.

As the Minister so rightly pointed out, all of this nonsense was so easily avoidable because the CE(EP) Act in itself was unnecessary. It has always been open to the Public Service Board or various Commonwealth authorities to apply to the Public Service Arbitrator under the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920 or to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for the right to stand down employees engaged in industrial action. The rights which the previous Government granted itself in respect of the CE(EP) Act were condemned by the International Labour Organisation, particularly in that they went completely against the democratic rights and principles advocated by that body. Again, it is worth pointing out to honourable senators opposite who have not done their homework that this option to approach the appropriate tribunal for stand-down orders will remain. In effect, we are therefore merely reverting to the pre-1977 arrangements. We believe that this is the best way to conduct industrial relations in this country. We totally reject the jackboot approach advocated by the Opposition.

I turn now to the third Bill which forms part of this cognate debate. The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill seeks to repeal sub-sections 3 to 7 inclusive of section 24 of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. These provisions were made to exclude redeployment and matters relating to termination of employment from the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As with the other Bills, we are restoring the jurisdiction of these tribunals to make determinations on these matters. Again, we are merely saying that any decision to redeploy or terminate employment must be initially referred to an appropriate industrial tribunal. We are not taking away the right of the Commonwealth to make such decisions.

I believe these Bills will go a long way towards restoring some sanity in the industrial relations framework within the public sector. We are saying that any decision, whether it be no work as directed no pay, redeployment, stand-downs and so on, must be justified before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the Public Service Arbitrator. In large part, this is what private sector employers are required to do. Therefore, we are restoring some balance to the situation. As the Minister has pointed out, many private employers simply do not have the common law right to order no work as directed no pay. This is particularly so when a set of award conditions apply. Under this legislation all parties will be given the fairest possible treatment. This approach is totally consistent with our prices and income accord and with the prevailing attitudes throughout the industry today. The Opposition is living in yesterday's land in its approach to industrial relations. That is clearly why its members are on the Opposition benches and will be there for some time. It is quite obvious that they do not have a coherent wages or industrial relations policy. All they seem to be able to come up with is a wages freeze, which has been the case to date.

In this debate it has emerged that the Opposition has a complete disregard for the accepted processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which has served this country well over many years. Indeed, some members of the Opposition would get rid of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. People like Mr Howard would prefer to see a complete free-for-all in the industrial relations area. The national Parliament originally created the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for the purpose of settling industrial disputes. We believe that it will continue to serve us well in the difficult times ahead.

This Government is not in the business of union bashing, as were our predecessors. We are not in the business of introducing draconian legislation which goes against the ideals and principles laid down by the International Labour Organisation. Unlike the discredited former Government, we believe in equity and fairness in the handling of industrial disputes. No doubt that is why the latest figures on industrial disputes show a marked downturn in the level of disputation in Australia since we took office. In July this year the number of working days lost due to industrial disputes was 27 per cent less than it was a year earlier. In that month 58,200 workers were involved in disputes compared with 105,200 in July 1982. It is certainly no coincidence that the largest reductions in the level of industrial disputation occurred in the Labor States of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, especially given the nature of the regimes governing Queensland and Tasmania. Certainly a government that takes power with less than 40 per cent of the vote will not be too worried about the use of jackboot tactics when handling industrial relations matters.

In conclusion, I congratulate the Minister on introducing these Bills. They honour an important part of our prices and incomes accord. They recognise the very important role played by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in settling industrial disputes and no doubt will lead to a period of relative calm in the public sector. I commend the Bills to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from Senator Foreman. It is very obvious from his speech that he was not here when the Public Service and Commonwealth employees Bills originally went through the Senate because he knows little, if anything, of the reasons of the Government of the day for passing that legislation. At that time we had tremendous problems with the Public Service in various areas, and I will come to that later in my speech. As Senator Foreman said, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities amendment Bill, the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill are part of a promise to the unions to repeal the previous Government's legislation which gave the government of the day control over its own employees. I believe that is tremendously important. If an employer has no control at all over what the employees are liable to do, or indeed in regard to what the employer has asked them to do, the situation can be chaotic.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Durack has already said, public servants belong to a very protected section of the work force. They have security of tenure, they have very generous superannuation provisions and they have rights of appeal that workers in the private sector would not have in a month of Sundays. But in return we, as governments and taxpayers paying the bill, do expect some sort of responsibility . Public servants serve the public and as a result the public pays their wages. If they withhold their service the public can be disadvantaged in the most stringent fashion. An example is the financial plight of pensioners during the strike by Department of Social Security staff, I think in 1981. I believe that when those strikes occur the taxpayer has every reason to demand of the Government some form of redress. Nothing in any of the Acts being repealed prohibits public servants going to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Indeed, that is where all good industrial relations should take place.

The Government has given us the wages accord and the National Economic Summit Conference. The Government made many promises to the unions at the wages accord discussions. We were supposed to have a summit at which some of the hard decisions on the economy of this country were meant to be taken. But what happened? All the soft options were considered and no attempt was made even to discuss any of the hard options. The unions said: 'One thing that is not debatable is a return to a centralised wage system. We will not even talk about it'. Some summit! Some consensus! They said that matter was undebatable. If we had had agreement from both the employers and the unions that, on returning to a centralised wage system, the arbitration system was where industrial relations should be conducted, where any dispute should be worked out, and that the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission would be final, we would have had something constructive from the Summit. But that was put in the 'too hard' basket.

Of course the employers always abide by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision. If they do not abide by the awards made there they are fined. It is as simple as that. The militant unions do not abide by the Commission's decisions. The Commission can come down with any decision it likes and if the militant union concerned decides that it does not like the decision there is no way it will abide by it. What happened at the Summit? The Australian Council of Trade Unions would give no guarantee that the unions would abide by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decisions. The Government now dares to criticise the legislation that we brought in to try to overcome that tremendous problem.

I shall go through some of the Acts that are being repealed. I refer first to the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill. The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act empowered the Commonwealth government of the day, whichever party happened to be in power, to stand down, suspend or dismiss its own employees if a job was not able to be done because of strike action by some of their colleagues. I quote from the second reading speech of the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis):
The Government does not consider it appropriate that as an employer it should have statutory powers of the type found in the CEEP Act which are not available to employers in the private sector.
The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, interjected during Senator Durack's speech and said:
Do you consider that that is the case with private employment?

That comment is very out of place in the Senate because he knows only too well that stand-down clauses are provided in many awards for private employment. He was on the same committee that I was on in October 1982-the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation-which discussed this matter in full. I shall quote from page 71 of the report of that Committee to underline the stupidity of Senator Button's interjection. Under the heading 'The Present Position' it says of the stand-down clauses:

In June 1982 a survey conducted by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations disclosed that 352 federal awards contained stand-down clauses. This figure represented some 37% of all awards.
I repeat, 37 per cent of all awards, but despite this Senator Button asks whether we believe that our stand-down legislation would be permitted in private enterprise. The report continues:
The survey found that 67% of stand-down clauses were similar to clause 19 (b) of the Metal Trades Award which enables an employer

. . . to deduct payment for any day the employee cannot be usefully employed because of any strike or through any breakdown in machinery or any stoppage of work by any cause for which the employer cannot be reasonably held responsible.
That was the most common stand-down clause. There were others. The report went on:
The next most common form of stand-down clause is typified by clause 10 of the Transport Workers (Airlines) Award.
That clause stated:

Notwithstanding anything elsewhere contained in the award, an employer may deduct payment for any day or part of a day that an employee cannot be usefully employed because of any strike, ban or limitation upon the performance of work or for any other cause for which the employer cannot reasonably be held responsible.
