Senator Button was on that Committee with me. I am quite sure he is well aware that those awards are also made in the private sector. The private sector should not have those clauses if the Government is not willing to have them in its legislation. The former Government introduced this Act because of the prolonged dispute involving Telecom Australia. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be well aware that that dispute was conducted in a most intricate fashion. Small sections of Telecom Australia went on strike one after the other. That strike action meant that many Telecom employees were not able to carry out their duties . Because of that prolonged strike the former Government decided to bring in this legislation which enabled it to stand down people who were not able to work because their colleagues were on strike. The legislation provided that the employees could be dismissed if the strike continued for no good reason after the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had made its decision.

Senator Foreman has said that there is no right of appeal in this area. That is not true. There is a right of appeal to the Administrative Review Tribunal. This Act was used nine times. Its most famous use was in settling the strike in the social welfare area to which I have already referred. That strike went on for some considerable time. The strike made it very difficult for pensioners and for the Minister of day. It was very difficult for pensioners to receive their pension cheques in time to enable them to meet their financial liabilities and to look after themselves.

The next Act that is being amended is the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Act. This is the Act containing the 'no work as directed-no pay' provision. What on earth does the Government expect of any employee? When the former Government brought in the original legislation Commonwealth employees were refusing to comply with the directions of the Minister of the day. Some public servants were refusing to answer the questions which the Minister had asked. Of course, they were still being paid. They were only refusing to do certain sections of their work. The situation was ridiculous. If they were prepared to work for only 50 per cent of their working day or to carry out only 50 per cent of their work, surely to heavens they deserved to receive only 50 per cent of their pay. They had a signed contract. The terms of that contract had to be carried out. Taxpayers do expect their employees to work for the pay which they receive. As Senator Durack has said, the pay is really quite generous . There is also a method of appeal in this area. The then Minister said in his second reading speech in 1980:

The . . . Act gives any person affected by an administrative decision of the government of the Commonwealth the right to go to the Administrative Review Tribunal to challenge the lawfulness of the decision that has been made.

Members of the Government have said that there is no right of appeal in the Acts . That is completely wrong. I do not think anyone in Australia who is not protected as public servants are could imagine why public servants who refuse to work or refuse to answer questions that the Minister puts to them should receive any pay at all.

I now turn to the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill. Again, this relates to a piece of legislation that our Government put through. I believe that today this Government is working a swiftie on public servants. The Government believes in this Act completely. There is no way in which it does not agree with what our Government did, but because of the wages accord it wishes to withdraw the legislation. The Opposition does not have the numbers in the Senate to defeat that action. Page 4 of the Minister's second reading speech states:

It is the Government's view that the retention of an effective, but fair, system for dealing with staff who are surplus, inefficient or incapacitated or who have lost essential qualifications is critical to the effective operation of the Service.
He went on:
Consequently, a review will be held . . .

All our Act did was give the Government an effective, but fair, system for dealing with staff who were surplus, inefficient or incapacitated or who had lost the essential qualifications for the effective operation of the Public Service. That is exactly what our Act did. The Government is in the process of repealing that provision and is now saying: 'But let it be clear that we really agree with it'. The Minister went on:
Consequently,-
that is, because the Government agrees with it--

a review will be held into those areas of the Act which deal with management- initiated early retirement. This review will be conducted by a working group comprising representatives of the Public Service Board, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the ACTU and the Council of Professional Associations.

At the conclusion of the review, which I envisage being early 1984, I will receive a report from the working party concerning possible amendments to the Act. Pending this review, the Public Service Board had, at the Government's request, advised that it will not take action to implement the provisions of the regulation.
The Minister reinforced that by saying:

I must stress, however, the Government's commitment to an effective, but fair, system for dealing with staff who are surplus, inefficient or incapacitated or who have lost an essential qualification. It is the Government's intention that the review should be conducted in this light and should be directed at the best means of establishing such a system.

Our Act provided such a system. Perhaps the introduction of new technology reduced the required number of public servants and they became surplus. The physical or mental capacity of public servants to carry out their duties may necessitate them being shifted and retrained. Only if they are not able to be shifted and retrained should there be a compulsory retirement. Let us consider a person who, for whatever reason, perhaps through inefficiency or loss of ability , is unable to carry out his or her job. An example would be that of a truck or bus driver who has lost his driver's licence and, therefore, is unable to carry out his job. If at all possible, that person should be moved and retrained. Otherwise, he should be compulsorily retired.

Compulsory retirement surely is the prerogative of any employer. I believe it is the prerogative of the government of the day. It is not right that taxpayers should be asked to pay for public servants who are sitting around doing nothing. Should people who have not been able to be retrained after having been shifted to other areas be kept on and not retrenched for no other reason than that they are public servants?

TALK.START.PARA: —How long are you going to keep this up?

—I ask the honourable senator to look at the second reading speech of his Minister, who agrees entirely with the legislation. He has made that very obvious. He has underlined and stressed his position. He has agreed to repeal our legislation to fit in with the wages accord, but in fact he agrees with it and he is having the matter reviewed. He wants to make sure that the committee of review comes up with similar decisions to those that the previous Government put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Foreman talked about the punitive measures that were used by our Government. There is never any need for punitive measures. We have a system of arbitration and conciliation. Any disagreement can be taken before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If such matters are correctly dealt with we will have the sort of industrial relations that I am sure both sides of this chamber would want. I believe the most important thing that is lacking is the commitment of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on behalf of its members to abide by the decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If we could have got only that one agreement on the wages accord at the National Economic Summit Conference the situation would be different. Of course, the Government will not press the unions. It will not ask them to abide by the decisions of the Commission. It has backed off in that regard. I believe there would be no need for the type of legislation that is before us today if we could get such agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is very little doubt that our industrial relations record in this country is quite deplorable. If one looks at this country from outside, say from the Philippines or Japan, we as a nation would seem to have everything going for us-a well educated and homogeneous population, great natural resources, and strategic invulnerability. We have a great future if only we can overcome our long tradition of poisonous and damaging industrial disputes.
—Oh, come on. That is over-exaggeration. You just spoiled your argument.

—I think Senator Georges underestimates the damage we are doing to our international trading relations by the disputes that are running, for example in the iron ore mines of the north-west. Disputes in our coal mines and on the waterfront are doing great damage to our international trading position and to the future of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is the biggest single employer of labour in the country. It is most important that we set an example of fairness, reason and efficiency in our relations with our own employees and those of our statutory authorities. That is a very important role for the Federal Government. I hope that we have got away from the days of Clyde Cameron, a Minister in the former Whitlam Labor Government, who tried to use the Public Service as a pace setter in conditions of employment and industrial affairs. He at least woke up to the damage he was doing to our whole community and later on in his career he started to describe public servants as fat cats. I would say that that was probably an exaggeration. We had an understanding under the previous Government that the pay and conditions of public servants, except at the very highest levels, should be comparable with those of equivalent positions in the private sector, and that, in my view, is fair and reasonable.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs whether in funding any State programs in which the Minister desires that equal opportunities be available to persons of either sex she will set out what will be required of the States in relation to, for example, engineering where males predominate or nursing where females predominate. Will it be required that States achieve equal opportunity for both sexes or equal participation by both sexes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Referring to the last part of Senator Sir John Carrick's question, it will be required that the States achieve equal opportunity not equal participation. Equal participation, of course, is a long term goal where equal participation is sought. What will be required is for the States to give assurances to the Commonwealth that in Commonwealth funded programs no properly qualified person will be refused access to a course on the basis of sex alone. So in the example of engineering, I would expect universities to be able to assure the Tertiary Education Commission that there are no entrance criteria which exclude women seeking to undertake engineering simply on the basis of the fact that they are women.

ANSWER.PARA: No entrance criteria will be interfered with. It is up to each university faculty to decide how it selects its students, but we would want a general assurance that a properly qualified woman would not be refused entrance to an engineering course simply on the basis that she was a woman. If a woman did not have the appropriate tertiary entrance score or if males had a higher score and if that score were the way in which a faculty determined how to pick its students, that faculty would continue to do that. Our seeking assurances will prevent, we hope, a case where a woman with a higher score is refused entrance although males with lower scores are accepted because there is a preference for male students. That is the only case in which tertiary institutions would be required to give an undertaking. Basically, the assurances will be just that. They will be assurances. The Tertiary Education Commission will seek assurances and I am sure that individual institutions will be anxious to provide such assurances since most of them in recent years have shown a consciousness of the need to be equal and fair in regard to the entrance criteria that they use in the selection of their students.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General heard media reports that Mr David Combe is out of pocket by $30,000 for legal costs incurred due to his involvement in the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies? Does the Government regard this as fair and will it reconsider the level of assistance being provided?

—It is not my understanding that anything of the kind is the case. The Government approved assistance towards legal costs for Mr Combe for both senior and junior counsel and for his solicitor. The rate for counsel was the same rate as counsel for the Commonwealth were paid. It is my clear understanding that Mr Combe's counsel and his solicitor agreed not to charge Mr Combe above the rate approved by the Commonwealth for its own counsel, and indeed the rate which was operating in respect of most other witnesses before the Commission who were financially assisted. I might add that Mr Combe's lawyers have presented accounts which have been paid and the total amount paid to date is $173,827. I do not know what the additional expenses are which have been incurred by Mr Combe and which have given rise to media reports, but I understand they do include such additional expenses as the air fares of a witness from the United States, which he chose to pay. Apart from matters of that kind, there does not seem to be any foundation whatsoever for any suggestion that Mr Combe was involved in incurring legal expenses for his counsel or solicitor of a kind which have not been met by the Commonwealth and as a result there would not appear to be any basis for the Commonwealth to reconsider the level of assistance which so far has been provided.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs how she can claim to be promoting higher participation in tertiary education when the Vice-Chancellor of Sydney University declared today that she was:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . failing altogether to provide the increased funds really needed to sustain the present high level of enrolments.

Does not her participation objective require the funding of qualified students into every presently available campus place? If that is the case, will the Minister provide funds sufficient to allow Macquarie University, for example, to reconsider its decision to cut first year enrolments for 1984 by more than 25 per cent? Finally, will the Minister ensure that adequate funds are available to maintain in 1984 new enrolments at New South Wales universities at least to 1983 levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that Senator Peter Baume should quote the words of Professor Ward concerning Commonwealth funding for education, because the situation with regard to funds for participation at Sydney University about which Professor Ward is complaining is a culmination of eight years of neglect under the Fraser Administration. Let us have a look at the funding situation for institutions of higher education and at the situation which we have inherited before we can assess and put into context the comments of Professor Ward. In 1975 when the Australian Labor Party was in office the approved Commonwealth grants for higher education amounted to $1,740m. Two years later in 1977 higher education received $1,839m. Two years later again there was a reduction and the grants amounted to only $1,710m. In 1981 higher education received only $1,668m and in 1982 it received $1,662m. So in that period there had actually been a real reduction of funds going to institutions of higher education. Between 1975 and 1982, the period in which the Fraser Government was in office-for a short time Senator Peter Baume was Minister for Education, so he will be only all too well aware of these facts-Commonwealth grants for higher education fell by $72m or nearly 5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: What have we done with respect to the funding of higher education? In contrast, our Government will be providing over $18m more in 1984, which is a one per cent real increase in funding for higher education. Included in this increase is the sum of $10m which will provide an additional 3,000 student places in universities and colleges of advanced education in 1984. In addition to this, as Professor Ward is well aware and for which he has expressed gratitude, the Government has restored retrospective cost supplementation to help restore stability and national planning to higher education after the years of uncertainty brought about by the policies of the previous Government. So there is an extra $10m alone for 3,000 extra places, as well as an overall increase. In the light of that Sydney University, an autonomous institution, has made particular decisions. It has decided that its targets for this year will be the same in real terms as they were for last year. Last year the university under- targeted. It set a target and got more enrolments than it had actually aimed for . This year it is reducing its expectations of growth because it has a more realistic appreciation of how many students it will get.

I should make it clear, Mr President, that our commitment to increase participation in higher education of course does not mean that there should be an increase in every faculty in every institution of higher education throughout the country. Clearly in some faculties, for example the faculty of medicine, there is no particular need for increased numbers. We have no particular demand for vast increases in the number of qualified doctors coming out of universities , even if some of them do end up in politics. In some institutions there is both a capacity for increased participation and a need for increased participation. Those institutions may not be institutions in inner city areas such as Sydney University which, according to the advice of the Tertiary Education Commission, is operating at maximum capacity.

It may be preferable in terms of our increased participation objective to see increases in institutions of higher education in the western suburbs. Milperra College of Advanced Education, for example, has been targeted by the Tertiary Education Commission as a growth institution. I have before me, and I will be tabling very soon, the report of the Tertiary Education Commission on the participation program. I can assure the Senate that the 3,000 places have been taken up. They have been bid for by institutions of higher education throughout Australia so that overall there will be an increase of at least 3,000 places in higher education. Of course, there will be a higher increase than that.

With regard to Macquarie University, I will not take the time of the Senate to go over the same grounds, but Senator Peter Baume will be aware that universities work out the target of what they expect to achieve in terms of increased participation. Sometimes they are over target and sometimes they are under target. Macquarie University has a history of not hitting the target. Other universities are more precise in terms of bringing their planned increase into line with what their real increase turns out to be. Of course, that is a matter for the governing bodies of those institutions to address. I can assure the Senate that our specific aim of 3,000 extra places will be met. I have the report on my desk, preparing for tabling, which sets out which institutions have decided to co-operate and increase their participation rates. Of course, apart from those extra 3,000 places, there will be other increases stemming from the real increase in Commonwealth funding that we have provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. What has been the response by beneficiaries of his Department to the Government' s initiatives announced in the May economic statement to encourage conversion of pensions from payment by cheque to direct credit with financial institutions such as banks and building societies, and to change the mode of payment from 12- weekly in arrears to fortnightly in advance? Is consideration being given to making the direct credit mode of payment universal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response to the Government's decision in May to take the first steps towards the payment of pensions into credit accounts has been overwhelming. In fact my Department has been converting pension payments at the rate of 13,000 a week which means something like 200,000 persons have taken advantage of this system to have their pensions paid into credit unions or bank accounts. This represents some 40 per cent of all such payments. I should point out to the Senate that the Government, in taking this step, had in mind not only the question of saving money but also of providing a better service to those in receipt of pensions. Of course, that has been realised insofar as there has been a very favourable response to the proposal. Far from the Government's estimate of savings of something like $600,000, in the financial year 1983-84 it will represent a saving of something like $1.5m. The other point that the Department, and the Department of Social Security when finally its system is incorporated, will have to look at will be how to overcome the negative aspects of the system. For instance, there is not always a sufficiently prompt advice of when pensioners change their address or die.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst there is no doubt that the service has been a very popular one, we do have to examine arrangements to ensure that money is not wasted through being misdirected to pensioners who have moved or died. I assure the Senate that the system is popular and one which we will keep under review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the paper from which he was quoting.
—I will.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate because it concerns a matter of government policy. I begin by drawing to the attention of the Leader of the Government a survey publicised at the weekend conducted by the Medical Association for Prevention of War which asked children between 10 and 12 at two Sydney primary schools to explain their views of the future of the world. Of the replies, 78 per cent expect the world to be destroyed by a world war within 15 years and 48 per cent believe they will not live to have a family. The children have a deeply pessimistic view of the future and some say they would rather die than live to see a nuclear holocaust. In the light of those comments, which I do not really feel members of the Opposition should see as an occasion for mirth--
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question.

—Indeed, Mr President. Has the Government considered the effect of these appalling expectations on the national morale and will into the future? Does the Government appreciate the intimate association of proliferation of nuclear weapons with its decision to sanction the world's largest uranium mine at Roxby Downs? Will the Government consider seriously the large and positive effect it could have in averting future proliferation of nuclear weapons and in remedying and improving the morale of the nation, and indeed of the world, in future by deciding to take the courageous step of ending the mining and export of Australian uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the survey to which Senator Mason referred, although those survey findings are consistent, I think, with a number of other surveys that have been conducted amongst young people in higher age groups, in their teens. The results would probably be fairly consistent with surveys, if they were to be conducted, amongst older age groups. Of course, there is tremendous concern about these matters and indeed a number of associated matters . The questions need not have been confined to the possibility of nuclear war to draw some of the same pessimistic conclusions which these surveys show.

ANSWER.PARA: In the context of that survey I am asked to comment on what is an implicit argument in Senator Mason's question, namely, that national morale would be restored if the Government were to see the nexus between the proliferation of nuclear weapons in the rest of the world and the development of the Roxby Downs uranium mine, and we are invited to have the courage to see that nexus and to close the Roxby Downs uranium mine. First, let me say that I have more confidence and faith in the children of Australia in respect of their general concerns than the question implies that Senator Mason has. Throughout the world there are children who are entitled perhaps to be much more concerned and I do not think that we can attribute any special concern to Australian children or any special role for Australia in alleviating what is a world concern about this problem. I should say that in the general policy considerations which the Government made in relation to uranium mining, the nexus between the peaceful use of uranium for domestic electricity generation and the proliferation of nuclear weapons seemed to me, and I believe to other Ministers, to be an extremely tenuous one. Nuclear weapons were developed well before the peaceful use of nuclear power. The product, as I understand it, of domestic nuclear power stations is not necessarily or generally regarded as suitable in a technical sense for nuclear weapons purposes. There are a number of other factors which make, I believe, that nexus extremely tenuous.

To express a personal view, I think that perhaps the debate on the importance of Australia playing a role in the prevention of nuclear war has been, in some ways, diverted from its purpose by the deliberate and considerable efforts of some very well intentioned people to wrap that debate up entirely with the question of whether Australia should mine uranium. In spite of comments to the contrary, the Government's views on these problems were arrived at after careful consideration of many of the issues raised in Senator Mason's question. Without in any way wishing to be offensive, I think the question draws something of a long bow on these issues. I do not think the implications of the honourable senator's question add to the provision of a serious answer based on a very serious survey to a very important problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims being made by some groups in the community that the Government in its funding allocation discriminates against the profoundly disabled in favour of those who are capable of more independent living? Is there any truth in these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not heard reports that this Government in its funding discriminates against the profoundly disabled. I do not know how such reports could arise. This Government has been in power for only eight months and there has been very little funding in this area from this Government because of the nature of funding, which is usually done a year ahead.
—There are some programs not accessible by definition.

—Sure. In response to Senator Chaney's interjection, I think the situation has arisen whereby this Government has announced officially that it will be considering, in our funding provisions, particularly those organisations which provide for what is known as the least restricted alternative in their programs for disabled people. We have asked organisations which are already receiving funding or which already have applications in that they also take into account this provision. Some organisations have traditionally provided just institutional care, particularly institutional care associated with training facilities on one site, and are resistant to any change in this direction. I understand that, having practised in this way for many years, they may be somewhat unsettled by such a suggestion. I point out, however, that the previous Government-certainly I was in agreement with it-was moving in this direction also.

ANSWER.PARA: For many years there has been a bipartisan policy in this place that what we need to provide for the disabled is, as much as possible, the opportunity to live as normal lives as possible in the community. If some organisations are disturbed by this I believe that they are unnecessarily so. All it means is that we will concentrate in the future, as much as possible, on those organisations providing non-institutional care or restricted institutional care and less on those which provide full institutional care. That does not mean that this Government or any member of this Government believes that there is no place in the future for institutions of various types which deal with the profoundly disabled. All we are saying is that we believe that in the past too many institutions have unnecessarily put people into institutional care. In the future we want to get away from that. So this Government has not discriminated and will not discriminate between different sorts of disabilities or different degrees of disability. What we will attempt to do is provide funding in a balanced way so that in the future all disabled get a fair go from this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs acknowledge the fact that, in addition to the 41 schools on the hit list, all group 1 and group 2 non-government schools will receive less funds in 1984 than they would have received under the previous percentage link formula? Will the Minister agree that the parents of children at schools she calls wealthy schools are not all well off and are not all wealthy? Will she acknowledge that if any parents are forced by the Labor-induced fee increases to remove children from a school they will be the least well off of the parents with children at that school?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The schools in group 1 received for their recurrent funding the same in real terms as they received last year, that is, the same money indexed for inflation. The schools in group 2 received a one per cent real increase over what they received last year. I will have to seek further information about how that ties up with what they received under the percentage link. I think it is roughly the same. Certainly I have not claimed that they received any increase as a result of that formula, unlike the category 3 schools, of course, which have received $7m more than they would have received under the previous Government's formula. The amount of funding may be less in real terms under the percentage link in relation to group 1. My understanding is that it is about the same. But I will certainly provide additional information.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of whether all parents who choose group 1 schools are well off is not really one about which I have information. I do not have information about the income of parents. I do not know whether Senator Teague is suggesting that we should try to emulate the Australian Taxation Office and investigate the private incomes of parents who make individual choices. It is certainly not the intention of this Government to go snooping around trying to find out what the private incomes of individual parents are. However, I do not have information available to me about the incomes of parents who pay fees of $3,000 a year or more. That is information which I presume the school has but it is not information I have. However, I assume that, even with category 1 schools, there would be some range in income; there would be parents from the wealthiest groups in society as there would be parents from the not so wealthy groups who have made that choice about what to do with their incomes.

Senator Teague finally asked what our attitude would be to children whose parents withdrew them from these schools because of fee increases. I would like to say this and to say it very clearly: The reduction in the Commonwealth grant to 41 schools in category 1 would mean that if those schools chose to increase their fees to regain from fees what they lost as a result of the slight reduction in the Commonwealth grant, they would have to increase their fees by $ 2 per week in primary schools and $3.40 per week in secondary schools. If the 41 schools increase their fees beyond that they must offer the parents some explanation other than the reduction in their Commonwealth grant otherwise they will be guilty of grossly misleading the parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to acknowledge that if government schools have a 2 to 2.5 per cent real increase, group 1 has a zero increase in real terms, group 2 a one per cent increase and group 3 a 3 per cent increase, the only non-government schools better off than the percentage link formula would have made them are those in group 3. So all group 1 and group 2 schools are worse off now than under the percentage link formula. I ask the Minister to acknowledge that.

—I will seek information to see whether I can confirm that. But let me say this to the Senate: It was the intention of the Hawke Labor Government, at a time of economic hardship, to redistribute funds available to schools in the private sector so that the vast majority of those schools which serve children from a wide range of backgrounds would be better off. We have achieved that and we are proud of it.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to reports that a rally held in Perth on the weekend, allegedly of tax victims, drew 300 participants? Can the Minister say whether protest rallies such as this will have any effect on the Government's determination to act on tax avoidance and tax evasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Sibraa that it will have no effect on the Government's determination to crack down on tax evaders insofar as the numbers lined up against the Government in the Senate allow it to. I will return in a moment to whether it will influence the attitude of those people. I have seen those reports. The meeting was organised by Mr W. W. Mitchell who is an extremely good friend of the Australian Labor Party. In fact I cannot think of anyone to whom the Labor Party in Western Australia owes more than it owes to Mr W. W. Mitchell. He was an adviser to Sir Charles Court and a Liberal Party candidate in the last State election, but he is best known for being the champion of the Western Australian tax dodgers. Largely because of Mr Mitchell's efforts-I think nobody should underestimate Mr Mitchell's efforts in this area- the Labor Party in the last Federal election recorded in Western Australia--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has been asked a simple question as to whether the holding of a meeting will affect the Government's attitude to certain tax matters. He is now proceeding to give information about an individual. It is typical of the way in which Question Time and other forms of the Parliament are used to try to blacken people's names. I draw your attention to the fact that the answer being given is irrelevant. I also suggest that he is debating the matter. Certainly, this has nothing to do with the question.
—At this stage I regard the Minister's remarks as relevant to the question and I will allow him to proceed.

—I was just about to say that largely because of Mr Mitchell's efforts the Labor vote in Western Australia at the last Federal election was the highest of all States. That has never happened before. The fact that he is publicly perceived-indeed, I do not think he runs away from the charge-as being the defender of what he calls the victims of the legislation of the last Government and the intended legislation of this Government is related to the damage that he did to the Liberal Party and the assistance he has given to the Labor Party. He is seen as being a representative of the dominant faction of the Western Australian Liberal Party, which of course is very closely aligned to tax evaders. Indeed, at one stage, about half the members of its finance committee--
—Order! I suggest to the Minister that he is getting away from the question.

—Very well, Mr President. There are a couple of other matters arising from the report of that meeting which are relevant. It appears the meeting was told that shareholders in public companies which sank subsidiaries which were either proprietary or public companies to the bottom of the harbour have received assessments. With the exception of those shareholders who have been selected by the Commissioner of Taxation as members of a representative class, that is not true. No shareholders in public companies have received assessments pursuant to the last Government's legislation. It appears from the Press report that that fact was misrepresented at that meeting, as it has been misrepresented in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the future effect of that meeting and similar meetings, I have one comment to make: The legislation passed last year empowered the Commissioner to make a judgment as to whether a shareholder in either a private or a public company had benefited as a result of the sale of that company at a price which reflected the intention not to pay the tax which was due. As the legislation now stands the Commissioner has the discretion of issuing an assessment proportional to the shareholding held by the shareholder, or issuing no assessment at all. In other words, there is no provision within the existing legislation for the Commissioner to issue an assessment commensurate to the benefit actually gained by the shareholder through the tax evaded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise another point of order. This is very interesting information and I am sure it is utterly factual information, but again it seems to bear no relation to the question of whether a meeting would affect the attitude of the Government.

—As I understand it, Senator Walsh is relating his remarks to a report arising from the meeting about which Senator Sibraa asked. In that respect I will allow the Minister to continue his answer, but I suggest he relate his remarks merely to the question asked by Senator Sibraa.
—It is, as I will show very shortly, Mr President, directly related to the question that Senator Sibraa has asked because the Government is introducing--
— Mr President, I raise a point of order. I suggest that the matter now being referred to by Senator Walsh is a matter which is in the legislation before the Parliament.
—I will allow Senator Walsh to continue but I ask him to restrict his remarks to the question.

—The Government has introduced legislation which will allow an assessment to be made commensurate to the benefit actually gained. That is part of a package which includes the repeal of a section which was inserted in last year's legislation by the previous Government after it was first introduced. That is a package deal. So insofar as Mr Mitchell or any of the people who attended that meeting, or anyone in the Senate, are genuinely concerned--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 99 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions shall not anticipate discussion upon an Order of the Day or other matter which appears on the Notice Paper.
The Minister is now addressing himself to a Bill which is on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I uphold the point of order and ask the Minister to restrict his answer.
—All of those people will have the opportunity to display their attitude to those who may be genuine victims of the legislation passed last year .

—I ask the Minister for Education a question following the decision by the New South Wales Government to switch nurse education from hospital based to college based training. Firstly, can the Minister say whether the change will require the Commonwealth to fund the new places in colleges of advanced education? Secondly, what provision has been made to cover the costs of large numbers of new college places for nurse training in 1984?

—Once people become students at a tertiary institution they are funded in that way, but special arrangements have been made by the Government of New South Wales because it was keen to move ahead with this transfer while awaiting the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's report to our Government on the implementation of the transfer of nurses from hospital based to college based education throughout Australia. That report is well in hand but it is not available. The New South Wales Government has decided to go ahead and make that transfer itself. It has worked out on a contract basis the payment of the CAEs for taking the nurses over in the first instance. The New South Wales Government is aware that I have asked the Tertiary Education Commission to prepare options on the future development of basic nurse training for consideration by the Commonwealth Government as part of the planning for the 1985-1987 triennium and that will cover nurse training throughout Australia. Courses at universities, colleges of advanced education and colleges of technical and further education receive automatic tertiary education assistance scheme approval only if they receive funding from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. The question of TEAS eligibility will be a matter to be taken up in the context of the Government's consideration of the development of basic nurse training following receipt of the Commission's advice. The short answer is that, in the short term, the costs are being borne by the New South Wales Government. In the longer term, they will be borne by the Federal Government.
—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister mentioned contractual arrangements with colleges of advanced education. Can she spell out the details of those contractual arrangements?

—I do not have the details of those contractual relationships because they are within the State Government. They are between the New South Wales Minister for Health and the institutions involved. I will see what information the State Minister for Health is prepared to provide. This is a unilateral initiative of the State Minister for Health. He has made these arrangements. As I said, in future years it will become a matter for Commonwealth funding, but the initial arrangement is one between the New South Wales Minister for Health and the institutions. I will see what details he is prepared to make available to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of statements made the weekend before last by the Chief Executive of Peko-Wallsend Ltd, Mr Charles Copeman, regarding the centralised wage fixing system? Can the Minister indicate whether these views are consistent with the views held by other business leaders? Can he also outline the main advantages of the approach taken by the Government in relation to the wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements made by Mr Copeman of Peko-Wallsend Ltd. They have been drawn to my attention. I should like to say that the views expressed by Mr Copeman are his own views and that they are inconsistent with the views expressed by most business leaders in Australia. I need scarcely remind the Senate that at the National Economic Summit Conference a number of business leaders spoke on the question of centralised wage fixation. I refer to people such as Mr Graham Spurling, the President of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, who indicated very strong support for a centralised system and made the point that, if such a system fails, 'we Australians cannot afford that failure'. I think that comment of Mr Spurling is important for all parties involved in industrial relations to remember. We cannot afford that failure. Mr Brian Kelman of CSR Ltd made very strong comments in support of the centralised wage fixation system as the most preferable system because of its equitable and simultaneous application to wage and salary earners. A number of other members of the Economic Summit spoke from a business point of view on the same lines.

ANSWER.PARA: In a more contemporaneous sense, however, I remind the Senate that during the national wage case hearings which took place between June and August of this year all parties had the opportunity to put submissions to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on this question. All parties supported the centralised wage fixing system and no employer organisation opposed it. The Commission concluded, on the basis of the arguments put before it and the views expressed by the parties, that a centralised wage fixation system was in the public interest. That view was expressed by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission without dissent. I should like to take the opportunity which Senator Foreman afforded me in asking about the advantages of the system as the Government sees them. I do not wish to--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I refer to standing order 99, which relates to the asking of questions in this place and which suggests that one should not ask for opinions in questions. The advantages of any particular course can be only a matter of opinion. I submit that this part of the question was not within the Standing Orders.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. However, I draw the attention of Ministers to a ruling given by a former President, Senator Sir Magnus Cormack , in 1973 when he said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . a Minister cannot be required to answer a question. But if he does, the Minister should confine himself to points contained in the question with such explanation only as will render the answer intelligible. In all cases an answer must be relevant to the question.
I draw that to the attention of all Ministers. At the same time, I draw the following sentence to the attention of all questioners:
Within reasonable limits I shall allow supplementary questions in order to elucidate an answer.
There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend my answer to be intelligible. If it hurts at the same time, I apologise for that. The fact of the matter is that if Question Time were to be conducted on that basis it would be as sterile as an operating theatre, which would not be in the best interests of this chamber. There are a number of advantages-I should have thought these were matters of importance to the Opposition as well as to the Government-in a centralised wage fixation system. The first is, as Mr Kelman pointed out at the Summit, that employees are treated equally. The second is that anticipatory wage claims based on alleged levels of inflation can be avoided. The third is that it better enables the Government to relate its economic objectives to the wage fixation procedures.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate of a period in which there was no centralised wage fixation system in Australia and wages were set on a case by case basis-a decentralised basis-as is currently advocated by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the discredited former Treasurer, Mr John Howard. In the period between 1981 and 30 September 1982 average weekly earnings in Australia rose by 17 per cent. The consumer price index in the September quarter of 1982 was 10.5 per cent higher than it was in the previous year. Unemployment over the period rose by 195,000. I should not have thought they were unimportant statistics. They are certainly not unimportant statistics to this Government when it considers the economic mess it inherited from the previous Government. Those statistics will not be readily forgotten. In the previous period, prior to the abandonment of wage fixation, the general situation of the Australian economy was much steadier. I do not wish to burden the Senate with the figures for that period, but there was a much steadier period in respect of the growth in average weekly earnings, unemployment and so on when the previous wage fixation system was in existence.

It is not only the Government that takes this view; it is, of course, the view of the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Ian Macphee. Mr Macphee in my view, if I might express an opinion at this stage, is probably the only Opposition spokesman who knows anything at all about industrial relations and the relationship between industrial relations and economic management in this country. Mr Macphee, on 7 October, spoke of the importance of the traditional development of the wage system in Australia and the importance of centralised wage fixation. Of course, that is not necessarily the view of the Opposition. The view of the Opposition is spoken with a forked tongue. Mr Macphee's view represents one part of the argument and the other part is expressed by that desiccated calculating machine, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the other place, Mr Howard, who really has no appreciation of the very serious and important issues involved in industrial relations and the relationship of those issues with the management of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: Has the Caucus dispute over the assets test to be introduced for pensioners yet been resolved? Is the dispute indicative of the wider concern in the community about the anomalies and inequities in the new measure? When is the legislation to be introduced? Is the Minister aware of calls by the Combined Pensioners Association and the Australian Pensioners Federation for the legislation to be laid on the table after its introduction so that detailed examination and discussion can take place? If so, what is his attitude to those calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unaware of the dispute within the Caucus to which Senator Messner refers. The matter has not been discussed at a Caucus meeting yet, so perhaps Senator Messner is anticipating something. I certainly do not discuss in this place what may or may not happen in the Caucus. Secondly, I have spoken to the Combined Pensioners Association, the Australian Pensioners Federation and many other pensioners organisations in the last three months. I spoke with some representatives of the Combined Pensioners Association for two hours this morning. Certainly they have been concerned about what they have perceived might be anomalies and inequities in an assets test. Most of what they perceived to be anomalies and inequities were not there. Secondly, the whole legislation for the assets test is not in front of this Parliament as yet, and some aspects of it are not finalised. Part of the consultation process has been to make sure that such anomalies and inequities did not arise.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, yes, I have noted a call by the Combined Pensioners Association that it would like this legislation introduced and left on the table for 12 months for discussion. What is happening is that the intention to introduce the legislation was announced in August, and we intend to introduce it and have it passed before the end of this session. After that, it takes another 12 months before the assets test applies. In that 12 months, added to the three months that we have already had, I should have thought there was ample time to discuss what people thought were inequities and anomalies. If the legislation were to be brought into this place and laid on the table for 12 months, it would mean that such a test could not be put into operation for another two years. That is not in line with the Government's budgetary planning. It is not in line with the Government's intention to introduce as soon as possible an equitable and rational retirement incomes program in this community. The Government's actions in allowing discussion and consultation and then allowing that period before the legislation comes in would have enabled people, including members of the Opposition, to look at the program and the legislation and to make constructive suggestions.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are nit-picking.

—As Senator Primmer says, one of the problems is that some members of the Opposition are nit-picking. I should have thought that any incomes test, assets test or means test which provided for a married couple still to get a part pension if they were under the age of 65 while still receiving an income of up to $300 and up to $400 if they were over the age of 70 was a pretty generous test. The problem is that people such as the honourable senator who was nit-picking, as Senator Primmer says, proceed around the community telling people that they will lose their pension if their income is $ 40 or $50 a week. That is not only untrue and deliberately mischievous, but also it is very distressing to people who are misled in that way.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer. I noted that he intends to introduce the legislation in this session. Will he assure the Senate, then, that it will not be introduced after the Northern Territory election and, therefore, rushed through in the last dying hours of the session?
—The legislation will be introduced and the Opposition will be given ample time to discuss it.
—How long?

—The Opposition will certainly be given very much longer then we were given when in opposition when about 19 Bills were gagged through this place . We have had three months to discuss the principle of assets testing. After the legislation is introduced, we shall have about 12 months or more before the test comes into effect. I do not know what more a government can do to ensure that there is reasonable scrutiny and reasonable application of the test.
—Resign.
—If Senator Chaney had had the courage to do what he wanted to do two and a half years ago in relation to introducing an assets test he might still be on this side of the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the moratorium which was allowed for those who had been unemployed for periods which would have made them eligible for jobs under the community employment program but had not previously registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service, usually because they did not qualify for unemployment benefits. That period of grace was to have expired on 31 October. In view of the fact that this type of information is disseminated slowly, despite the best efforts of the Department and of parliamentarians, could consideration be given to exending the time for enrolment for another three months?

—Senator Giles is correct in saying that for the first three months of the community employment program, to October 1983, there was a moratorium during which it was expected that people not registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service would immediately register and sign a statutory declaration to the effect that they had been actively seeking work for three months. Three months registration with the CES is the basis of the eligibility criteria for assistance under the community employment program. The moratorium for the first three months, as was suggested in Senator Giles's question, was particularly aimed to assist people who had not actually registered with the CES although they were in fact actively seeking work. The possible extension of the moratorium, as was suggested by Senator Giles, has been raised with the Government by others in addition to the honourable senator. It has been given favourable consideration, and a decision will be announced very shortly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows a question that I asked him yesterday about the Commonwealth Government's lack of consultation with the Northern Territory Government over the decision to hand the Uluru National Park to an Aboriginal land trust. The Minister will recall that he gave an answer at the end of Question Time and referred to a letter of 3 June from the Chief Minister of the Territory to support the Leader of the Government's claim that the Commonwealth's position and intentions were well known to the Territory Government. I ask the Minister whether he agrees that the part of the letter concerning Uluru expressed a willingness to agree to perpetual Aboriginal title to the National Park under Territory law, provided that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . provision is made for the National Park to continue under Northern Territory management.
I further ask the Minister whether he agrees that this proposition is well removed from the unilateral statement by the Prime Minister last Friday, when the best that he offered was:
. . . an opportunity for Northern Territory participation in the management of the Park.

Will the Minister now concede that the Commonwealth has acted in a high-handed and arbitrary way in its decision on the future of the National Park in that it has very substantially changed what was proposed without any consultation and without giving proper notice to the Northern Territory?

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether the Commonwealth has acted in a high-handed way on this matter is a question of subjective judgment, about which Senator Chaney clearly has a view and the Government clearly has a view. I do not know whether Senator Chaney will be taking a point of order against me, as he did earlier at Question Time, but I am about to express a view-unless he would prefer that I did not do so. It is the Government's view that we did not take a high-handed attitude on this matter. I certainly agree with Senator Chaney that the letter of 3 June from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to the Prime Minister advanced a totally different proposition in terms of ownership and control of the relevant area from the proposition which the Commonwealth Government has now adopted. There is no doubt about that. The Northern Territory wanted it for itself. It was Commonwealth land and the Commonwealth Government made a decision about Commonwealth land. The fact that the Commonwealth was likely to make such a decision was well in the knowledge and contemplation of the Northern Territory .
—Consensus! Really!

—The difference between the Northern Territory Government and the Government of the Commonwealth was well in the knowledge and contemplation of the Northern Territory. If Senator Walters bothered to listen, instead of interjecting, it might even sink into her consciousness as well. I agree with the first part of Senator Chaney's question, namely, that there is not much relationship between the two propositions, the one advanced in the letter and the Commonwealth's position. I do not agree that the Commonwealth has acted high -handedly in this matter. Yesterday, Senator Chaney asked me whether a telex was sent at such and such a time on 11 November. I agree that a telex was sent at that time and the announcement was made in the afternoon. Insofar as the financial notification is concerned, if I am asked for a comment on it, I would certainly agree that it was brief notice, but I take it no further than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have Paper No. 9, the Government response to the Senate Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee report on East Timor, incorporated in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—Is the paper still to be considered in its order on the list as we come to it, or will I now move that the Senate take note of the paper?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government response to the report is listed as paper No. 9. The papers will be taken seriatim as is the normal custom and practice.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE COMMITTEE REPORT ON EAST TIMOR

On 8 September, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence tabled its report on the Human Rights and Conditions of the People of East Timor . This included a dissenting report signed by three of the six members, or by half of the Committee.

The inquiry began in November 1981, and under its terms of reference, the Committee was charged with reporting not only on the human rights and conditions of the people of East Timor, but also on the actions taken by the United Nations and on appropriate policies that might be adopted by an Australian Government.

Few international issues have aroused the same intensity of feeling or had a greater impact on Australian foreign policy in recent years, than events in East Timor. This is understandable. East Timor is only 1,000 kms from Australia and Australians can hardly be expected to be indifferent to the fate of a territory so close to their own shores.

It is not my intention to go over the past in detail but there are several points that need to be made in order to put the issue into perspective. For several centuries, East Timor was one of the most neglected parts of the Portuguese colonial empire. The decolonisation process was resisted by Portugal and firm Portuguese control prevented the emergence of any significant independence movement or even embryonic political parties.

It was not until the overthrow of the Caetano regime in Portugal in April 1974 that formal political parties were allowed to be established in East Timor. After that, the collapse of Portuguese rule and turmoil and chaos of civil war, led ultimately to Indonesian intervention. There was no gradual process of political development in East Timor, and no preparation for possible independence under Portuguese tutelage, within a framework of general international agreement.

These basic facts are covered in the Committee's Report. They are also fully recorded in the report of the visit to Indonesia of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation which was tabled in Parliament on 6 September, two days before the Senate Committee report. It must be accepted that the proximity of these reports and the fact that they deal with much the same subject matter, means that consideration of one cannot preclude consideration of the other. They must be considered together.

The Senate Committee's report was largely prepared from evidence given by refugees, much of it relating to the immediate aftermath of the Indonesian invasion. The Report of the Parliamentary Delegation on the other hand, was compiled from first hand experience and observation as a result of the Delegation's actual visit to East Timor from 28 July to 1 August 1983.
Apart from the background to the situation in East Timor that I have already mentioned, the Senate report covers four broad areas of interest. I should like to comment on each of these.
The first is human rights.

The suggestion that there was some semblance of normal political freedom in East Timor at the end of Portuguese rule overlooks the extreme social and political backwardness of the East Timor at that time. There is little doubt, however, that during the period of civil war, the takeover by Indonesian military forces and during the military operations that followed, atrocities and abuses of human rights took place on both sides. The then Australian Government, and this House, is on record in condemning the abuses which occurred.

In November 1980, the Indonesian Government informed the UN Commission on Human Rights that it was doing its best to prevent excesses in the province and that it would continue to do so. While this assurance is welcome, the Australian Government has a strong and continuing interest in seeing internationally accepted human rights observed and respected, in East Timor, as elsewhere. It has made its views known to the Government of Indonesia on a number of occasions , most recently on 1 September 1983, in connection with the renewed fighting in the province.
Another major concern in the Senate report is current conditions in East Timor.
There is general agreement, as stated in the report, that the invasion of East Timor and subsequent military action had a serious impact on the predominantly agricultural economy of the territory.

I think it should be noted that during its visit in July and August the Parliamentary Delegation considered the food situation in the province to be generally satisfactory. This conclusion is in keeping with the findings of the international relief agencies working in East Timor. The Delegation also found that the relief programs run by the International Committee of the Red Cross and UNICEF, to which Australia has contributed a total of $6.9m, have played an important part in alleviating the effects of shortages and malnutrition.

It should be noted in this respect that food shortages have long been a feature of life in East Timor, and cannot be attributed solely to the dislocations caused by the events of 1975-76. While considerable difficulties continue to be posed by East Timor's poor soils, limited arable land and limited infrastructure , the prospect now exists for the province to become self-sufficient in rice and possibly other staples within a few years. This is commendable progress, and as noted by the Parliamentary Delegation has been matched by progress in the areas of health, education and the provision of economic infrastructure.
United Nations resolutions and actions are another major subject of the Senate report. As this section is largely a matter of historical record, I do not think it warrants detailed comment now.

Let me limit my remarks to the observation that on 21 September, the General Commitee of the United Nations which determines the agenda for the General Assembly, unanimously agreed to a proposal from Norway to defer consideration of the East Timor question until the next session of the General Assembly in 1984.

The decision to defer accords with the Note issued by the UN Secretary-General on 19 August in which he stated that in view of recent developments regarding East Timor, he did not consider it opportune at this time to submit a substantive report to the General Assembly on his efforts to contribute to a comprehensive settlement of the problem. He proposed instead to submit a report next year.
I now come to the last and most important part of the Senate report, Australian Policy towards East Timor, which leads us to the conclusions and recommendations . I shall take these together:
The first recommendation is:

That in developing its policy towards East Timor the Australian Government should make formal recognition of the incorporation of East Timor into the Republic of Indonesia conditional on the holding of an internationally recognised act of self-determination which indicates that integration does in fact represent the will of the majority of the people of East Timor.

Honourable Senators will know that when the Government came into office, the first overseas vist undertaken by Mr Hayden as Foreign Minister was to Indonesia . In a statement issued at the conclusion of his visit, Mr Hayden reaffirmed the need to maintain friendly and co-opeative relations with Indonesia. He acknowledged that the Australian Government had never sought to evade the obvious fact that there have been differences between Australia and Indonesia over East Timor. He also noted that Indonesia has incorporated East Timor into the Republic of Indonesia but expressed the Government's deep concern that an internationally supervised act of self-determination has not taken place in East Timor. At the same time, Mr Hayden made it clear that the Government's primary concern was to ensure that Australia did all it properly and reasonably could to help the East Timorese.
The second recommendation is:
That until such an act of self-determination is held in East Timor, Australia should oppose the Indonesian position on the subject in the United Nations.

As I have mentioned, on 21 September the General Committee took a decision to defer consideration of East Timor until the 1984 General Assembly. I would point out that as Australia was not a member of the General Committee, it took no part in the deferral decision. The Government hopes, however, that deferral will produce a less divisive and more co-operative atmosphere in which the interest of the East Timorese people will be promoted.
The third recommendation is:

That in the absence of a genuine act of self-determination, the Australian Government oppose any action or statement which implies endorsement of the legality of the incorporation of the territory of East Timor into the Republic of Indonesia.

I have already made clear the Government's position on East Timor. Let me simply add that Australian policy towards East Timor is indivisible from the policy that Australia must adopt towards Indonesia as a whole.
The fourth recommendation is:

That the Australian Government use its influence in the United Nations and other international fora to maintain pressure on the Indonesian Government to redress the legitimate grievances of the people of East Timor.

As I have already said, the Indonesian Government is well aware of the Australian Government's position on human rights issues and its commitment to doing whatever it reasonably can to assist the people of East Timor.
Lastly, the report recommends:
That Australia encourages Indonesia to permit the free movement of East- Timorese out of Indonesia and East Timor and that Australia continue its family reunion program for East Timorese.

I think Honourable Senators will agree with me that this issue, on which the Committee was unanimous, raises another point that needs to be made. That the only way in which the Australian Government can directly assist the East Timorese is by working through the Indonesian authorities.

The Family Reunion Program is a good example. When Mr Hayden was in Jakarta in April, he received assurances that the Family Reunion Program would proceed at a rate of 20 to 30 a month until the list was cleared. In fact, this was the first time that an assurance from such a level had been given to any Australian Government. Since April the Program has almost been completed and only 13 persons are still formally listed as wanting to come to Australia from East Timor. The Government's ultimate objective is to reach a situation where people wishing to migrate from East Timor to Australia can be considered for migration purposes in accordance with the same criteria applied to applicants elsewhere in Indonesia.

Lastly, let me say that the Australian Government has attached importance to establishing a sound and productive relationship with Indonesia. This was reflected in the early visits to Indonesia by the Prime Minister and Mr Hayden. At the same time, the Government has never sought to evade the fact that there have been differences between the two countries over East Timor. The Government believes, however, that the best way to proceed over East Timor is through patient diplomacy, and that it can best assist the East Timorese by working through the Indonesian authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I so move because I think it would be useful if in the not too distant future we had an opportunity for a debate on matters relating to Aboriginal affairs in this chamber. For some time the Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs have been from this chamber, but now the Minister is in the other place. For that reason, there is less opportunity to debate this very important element of our national affairs. It remains true, as I look quickly around both sides of the Senate chamber, that there are many honourable senators with a particular interest in this area of government administration. It is quite clear that there is a series of matters which warrant the attention of the national Parliament and which could, I think, be debated before the Government goes too far down the track of final decision-making. I refer, for example, to the view which has been put forward by the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, that there should be national legislation in a number of areas. In this respect, he has mentioned land rights, the protection of sites and a couple of other areas such as health which he believes might usefully be addressed in that way.

As a one-time Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I say that those sorts of ambitions need to be looked at very carefully because of the substantial legal and administrative difficulties which add to the difficulties on the ground with which the policy is trying to deal. We live in a country which is governed under a Federal system of six States and a Territory which is self-governing and in which there are very important areas of State responsibility in matters which are vital to the Aboriginal population of Australia; for example, in the fields of housing, health, law enforcement and so on. I believe that the experience of the past, including that of the three years of Labor Government under Mr Whitlam and of the three Labor Ministers of that time, suggests that it is of very great importance to maintain, as far as possible, co-operative attitudes and co- operative programs which ensure that there is not administrative conflict, making more difficult the very real problems that many of the Aboriginal people of Australia face. In the few minutes in which one is permitted to look at these reports, I merely wish to give some notice to the Senate that the fact that this report has been put before us provides us with what has become a fairly rare opportunity to deal with a matter of very great public interest. I hope that at an early time we might be able to find the opportunity for more extensive debate on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree, in part, with Senator Chaney . One of the biggest problems has always been that prior to 1967 we had specific problems as far as Aboriginal people were concerned and since 1967 we have had specific problems. It is just that the emphasis has changed. One of the things that I wanted to pick up in the annual report of the Aboriginal Affairs Department was the indictment under the section entitled 'Employment and Training'. In that section the following statement is made:

SPEECH.PARA: On an Australia-wide basis, the Aboriginal unemployment rate was more than four times the rate for non-Aboriginals. In addition, the labour force participation rate (the proportion of persons, aged 15 years and over, who were employed, or unemployed) for Aboriginals (47.3 per cent) was well below that for non- Aboriginals (61.8 per cent).

I understand the difficulties of Aboriginal people in gaining employment. A number of schemes have been operating for some years which provide them with an opportunity, for instance in the offices of members and senators under the national employment strategy for Aboriginals and through various community schemes. But it is disturbing to see in black and white that since the last census was conducted, unemployment rates have risen considerably. In April 1983 the rate for all Australians had doubled to 10.2 per cent. It is not unreasonable to assume that the Aboriginal unemployment rate could now be 50 per cent or more in some States. One has to recognise that in Western Australia, which has a high population of Aboriginal people, the rate may be even more because of the amount of territory in that State.

One of the other areas covered in the report-I recognise the constraints of time-is most important. It arises in the section headed 'Government and Legal' and is the problem of human rights. One has to be concerned about the number of Aboriginal people in gaols throughout Australia. There have been a number of newspaper articles and a number of theses done on this. I suppose one could say that there has been a consciousness of the problem for many years. Comparisons are always made, but very little appears to be done about the problem. In fact, as a person who has been involved with Aboriginal communities for many years, I wonder what can be done about it.

Leaving that aside for the moment, I wish to comment on actions that are being taken in Australia at the moment which will mean that Aboriginal people will have less opportunity than at any other time to have human rights or civil liberties available to them. I refer briefly to the Northern Territory Criminal Code. I have had a number of discussions with lawyers who are extremely concerned about what that Criminal Code will do as far as Aboriginal people are concerned. I know that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is aware of it because I have expressed my concern about it to him as have others. I think Senator Tate one night in the adjournment debate expressed his grave concern about the contents of the Northern Territory Criminal Code. I know that he will be considering appropriate action in this regard in the future. One would hope that it will not be too long before he does so because if one allows legislation to come into effect it is always much more difficult to have it changed.

The only other thing that I want to touch upon is the need for training of Aboriginals, a need which I believe is much greater for Aboriginals, and perhaps covers a much broader area, than for many other groups in our community. There is a real need in this area. For example, it is not possible simply to pluck out a person who has only local Aboriginal community experience and ask him to participate as a counsellor, for instance, at community, regional, State or even national level conferences. That is creating a problem. I know that the Aboriginal Cultural and Training Institute in Sydney has a training program. I hope that the review being undertaken at this stage is a fairly quick one and that adequate funding will be given for people to be able to avail themselves of the benefits of such an institute. Briefly, I concur with Senator Chaney in that there is a great need for a more comprehensive debate in relation to all things concerning Aboriginal affairs. I look forward to participating in such a debate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
