DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT FISHING VENTURE OFF NORTHERN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Agreement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I certainly welcome the tabling of the KKFC Pty Ltd gillnet agreement. Whilst an inordinate time was taken in producing the agreement, it is hard to put forward any real criticism of its content. I had many discussions with KKFC and the Kaohsiung Commercial Fishing Boat Guild members during the somewhat lengthy formulation of the agreement. It is a very mature agreement, I believe the best agreement that we have yet had concerning foreign fishing in Australian waters. I am also happy to say that it is very closely in line with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce following its inquiry into the development of the Australian fishing industry. I appreciate that some notice has been taken of that report or that coincidentally we moved along parallel paths.

This agreement is a real move towards the Australianisation of the industry and it puts the onus on both KKFC, on the one hand, and the Australian industry on the other. I hope that such an agreement can be extended into other fisheries around Australia in order to get them established, built up and Australianised. The agreement provides initially for eight vessels and a three-year term of operation to fish in the area between 128 degrees and 141 degrees east. It also provides for the operation of carrier boats and trans-shipments, for sales to the Australian domestic market, and for KKFC to purchase up to 300 tonnes of fish from Australian fishermen. I believe this to be a very good idea. The agreement provides for progressive participation by Australians, but the Australians themselves have to realise that they must participate and that they can learn and take over if they wish to. I believe that the onus is very largely on them to establish not only that they can but also that they wish to participate. The agreement also provides that there should be a greater use of Australian supplies and materials in the fishing operations and it is hoped to progress to Australian processing as well. The agreement is a most important document in fisheries management and development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer and I served on the same committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce, which looked into the fishing industry and brought down its report earlier this year. I am in total agreement with all he had to say, but I believe we have to go a little further in the area of Australian participation. Whilst under this agreement eight foreign vessels are to be licensed, that number is to decrease over the period of the agreement, which is only three years. Those licences will then be issued to Australian vessels.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee kept on coming up against a few problems during the fishing inquiry. One was that Australian fisherman have a general lack of knowledge or care about the way they handle fish once they have caught them, which means that a large number of fish will not be selected by the Australian consumer. Other people tend to handle their fish much more gently and as a result do not have the same amount of bruising, loss and rottage that perhaps we get in fish from the majority of Australian fishermen. One of the other problems was the lack of knowledge of just what fish are available in the Australian fishing zone. That is of great concern to me. I believe that off the coast of Western Australia, for instance, we have tremendous potential, but no one has done a great deal to find out just what is there. I understand the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation vessel has gone to that area. I will be interested in the final report on what they actually found is available, in what quantities they assess it is available and what can be done with the fish that can be caught. But one of the problems at the moment is that we do not know, and no one really seems to care. There does not seem to be sufficient interest or sufficient funds available for Australian fishermen to make a contribution in this area, given that it means that they have to have much larger vessels capable of staying out more than one, two or three nights, mother ships have to be available to them so that their catches can be taken back to the shore and all those things.

Mr President, you would be aware that the report brought down earlier this year was an extremely comprehensive one. I believe that the fact that this agrement has now been drawn up, containing some of the matters that were raised with us during the inquiry, is an indication of the work of the members of the Committee . I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I wish to speak very briefly, not to the content of this statement but to the procedure which has been followed in this case. I must say that I was wrong- footed slightly by the matter coming up at the beginning of the presentation of papers as well as in respect of item No. 9. In retrospect I am sorry that I granted leave for the incorporation of the statement but not because I am generally against incorporating things which are formal. I wish to put the view on behalf of the Opposition that when the Government is responding to a Senate committee report I think it would be much more appropriate if the response could be made by way of a ministerial statement delivered by a Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —With two hours' notice.

—In response to Senator Baume's interjection, two hours' notice is normally afforded for statements. I do not in any sense carp at the fact that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, obtained the incorporation because he only did so by leave which I gave on behalf of the Opposition. The Opposition thinks that if we get a parliamentary committee report and the Government gives it consideration, it becomes a rather peculiar use of the forms of this place if the response is not put down in a way which enables the Senate to respond and to deal with the matter which has been put before it.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on East Timor, it is well known that the issue is one of very considerable sensitivity and importance. It is important to Australia because it affects our relations with our nearest neighbour. It is important in a domestic political sense because there are some sharp differences of view within the Parliament and, of course, in the community about what is the most appropriate course to take. I do feel that on such a sensitive matter when some concentrated work has been done by the Parliament-in this case by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the Senate-it would be very desirable if the more formal approach were followed and there was a better opportunity for an intelligent response from the Senate immediately.

The Government's response to this report has not been heard by honourable senators. It has not been read by us because it has not been distributed. Only a minority of honourable senators are familiar with the Government's response. They are, of course, the members of the Committee. I give the Government notice that in the future we will not be prepared to give leave for the incorporation of statements of this particular type. Indeed, we request the Government to follow the formal procedure of making a ministerial statement of which two hours ' notice is given so that all of us will have an opportunity to respond in an intelligent and intelligible way on an issue of very great sensitivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. If Senator Chaney wants to respond to the statement in more detail at some later time, I am quite willing to give him leave to continue his remarks. I am willing to give leave to make a statement to anyone else who wants to say a few words now.

—Mr President, it is my understanding that because of the nature of the order under which we are operating I would not be precluded from debating the matter when it comes back before us, assuming that it is moved-as I understand it will be-that it be made an order of the day under General Business . I appreciate the offer made by the Minister. As I say, I am not complaining about the fact that on this occasion the statement was incorporated because he did so with my express leave on behalf of the Opposition. Members of the Opposition will take the opportunity at a later time to debate the matter fully.
—I wish to speak to the point of order--
—It was an offer rather than a point of order.

—Nonetheless, it was accepted as a point of order and I am speaking to the matter. It seems to me that what has been raised by the Leader of the Opposition concerns the way other members of the Senate feel about the method of dealing with these reports. I suggest that it is about time the Standing Orders Committee had another look at this method of speaking to these reports because the system is not at all satisfactory. The business sheet indicates that other substantial reports are to be dealt with, including a statement on medifraud and overservicing. This means that no substantial debate can take place. I suggest that the Standing Orders Committee, at the earliest opportunity, take another look at the procedures that the Senate seems to have adopted.
—Along with honourable senators who have spoken previously, I too take up this issue. At the moment Senator McIntosh is in America as a representative of this Government before the United Nations--
—Senator Primmer, are you speaking to the point of order?

—No. I am speaking to the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I happen to be the Acting Chairman of that Committee. I became somewhat perturbed when the business sheet appeared on our desks this morning because I, as the Acting Chairman of the Committee, had not been privileged to receive a copy of that response. So, in essence, to debate the response would be to debate it in a vaccum. I do not know where the responsibility lies. The Committee went through blood, sweat and tears from witnesses who appeared before us in relation to the East Timor issue for 12 months. Someone has fallen down somewhere within the administration of this Government when that response to the Committee's recommendation is not before members of that Committee at least. The list which has been circulated states that it is a Government response to the Senate Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee report on East Timor. The Government's response has never been discussed in Caucus. It has never been discussed by the Caucus Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee. I do not know from where the Government's response has come. I have not seen it. Perhaps when I see it I will understand, but there is something wrong. I repeat--
—Fishy.

—We dealt with fish earlier, Senator. There is something wrong when at least I, as the Acting Chairman of the Committee, have not been privileged to receive a copy of this response. I repeat: Unless something is done about this Senate committees may as well go into limbo and drop dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that Senator Primmer and I have identical views. On this occasion we do. We were divided on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. We are united on the Government's response to it or, rather, the Government's lack of response to it. I think I can soothe Senator Primmer by telling him that, when we were in government, government responses were always considered by our party meetings before they were tabled in the Parliament. It might be good for the new Government to look at our procedures and smarten itself up a bit.
—Not approved.

—No, they were not approved. I too wish to protest at the way in which the matter has been handled and make some suggestions for changes. To incorporate a document such as this and expect to have debate on it when none of us have seen it and none of us know what is in it is quite absurd. We cannot usefully debate it. We can, of course-as will be done-defer it until tomorrow when it can be considered under General Business, but that makes this debate a farce. I should make a further point. If we debate the matter today-even if the Government's response had been given to us in advance-we would have only five minutes in which to discuss an issue of great political importance. This was one of the very few times in the history of the Senate when members of the Senate Committee were totally divided-they were split three-three-on an issue of fundamental importance. It is obviously a highly contentious issue. I suspect that the Government has been attempting to stifle debate by introducing debate on this matter in a rather hole-in-the-corner fashion. I suspect, because of the nature of the report and the consequential Government reaction to it, that the people whom the Government is frightened of are not members of the Opposition but members on its own side. The Government would rather not have this issue debated seriously in the Parliament. What will happen now is that we will have 10 minutes each to discuss it tomorrow. That is quite inadequate for a paper of this nature. We will not have a chance to read the Government's statement. The Government should make a ministerial statement on an issue such as this and it should be read to the Parliament. That is how issues like this should be handled . SPEECH.PARA: I thought the way in which one issue was dealt with this morning reduced the proceedings of the Senate almost to a farce. The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, moved a motion relating to animal welfare. He incorporated a statement in Hansard so no one knew what was in it. Then we had debate on the matter. If people intend to move motions of that nature we must have a system whereby a Minister makes a statement to the Senate, with prior notice of the content, so that there can be sensible debate. Then we can have a proper debate. If necessary, the debate can be adjourned and brought on later. We should be able to speak for a sensible length of time. Thirty minutes seems to me to be adequate on this issue. However, I think the debate at the moment is a waste of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to enter this debate briefly. I have been listening to what has been said. This extraordinary situation is bringing to a head the very unsatisfactory way in which we are treating reports from committees and responses from the Government. I was very interested to hear what Senator Primmer had to say about the way in which this response apparently comes without any proper parentage. Apparently it has not been considered even by the Caucus, which I understood was one of the most powerful bodies in this Parliament. It seems that members of the Caucus are not made privy to Government responses. I will say for the previous Government that responses when considered were brought into our party room. I disclose the inner secrets of our party room by saying that these matters were brought to the notice of the committees that were responsible and were brought into the party room so that members could have some idea of what was happening. I am surprised to see that this Government is adopting an attitude apparently whereby it does not allow even its own members to know what its proposed responses are.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with Senator Hamer and others in saying that it is totally unsatisfactory to expect honourable senators to make five minute mini-speeches on reports, whether important or unimportant, and responses by government, whether important or unimportant. All speeches are limited to five minutes. It is a whole hour--

TALK.START.PARA: —All reports are important.

—All reports are important but some have greater significance and much more debate is expected on some than on others. Some of the reports listed on the business sheet are probably not reports that will evoke a great deal of discussion in Parliament but others will. We know that debate on them has gone on week after week, that only a small amount of time has been devoted to them and that adequate debate on them does not take place in Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I likewise agree with what my colleague Senator Hamer has said. I agree that a document or statement that is put down ought to be available to us all before we are expected actually to respond to it. We should not have to read it in Hansard the next day. We are reaching a state of absurdity. I suggest that the Standing Orders Committee or the Government itself ought to look at this practice. This House is turned into a farce when we cannot properly debate these matters because we do not know what we are dealing with.

It seems to me from what I have heard of this debate, and I was not here when it started, that there are two sets of complaints. The first complaint is the way reports are dealt with in the Senate, the lack of notice that members-on both sides of the Senate on this occasion, I gather-have received of the reports which have been presented, and the fact that they have not had time to consider the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. —I rise to order.
—Let me finish my statement.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition wishes to raise a point of order.

—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, the point I was making was that there was a general complaint from Senator Missen and Senator Hamer about the way in which reports and statements are generally dealt with in this place. That is what was said. I have said it before. If we want to change this practice, we should.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether this matter should have been debated today, I merely say to the Senate that there was agreement at the Whips' meeting this morning that this matter be debated tomorrow, which would have given everyone in this place plenty of time to read the report and join in the debate in a considered way.

The third matter concerns this Government's reponse to the Committee report. I was under the impression that in fact the response had been considered by our party room. If that is not right I am certainly not happy with the situation and I will take up the matter. However, before those on the other side take this holier than thou attitude, I point out that the difference between the way things are supposed to be done-I make this point very clearly-on both sides is that when the Liberal Party is in government the Prime Minister comes in and says: 'This is what we are going to say: cop it or not'; when we are in government we decide whether we agree with a response or not and we all have a vote. If this response was presented without the correct procedures being followed I would be as unhappy about the situation as anybody else and I will make sure that we find out what happened. If we want to sort out the way we deal with things in this place so that everybody gets a proper chance to read things in depth before they debate them in depth, that is fair enough. I used to whinge enough about that when I was in opposition. I will look at what changes can be made. Maybe the Standing Orders Committee should look at it. I will take up the matter with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to see how this matter arose. However, I again make the point that arrangements were made for this matter to be debated tomorrow. That would have given honourable senators 24 hours to consider it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not want it broadcast.

—We do not mind whether it is on air or not. The only people who worry about the alleged millions out there listening to parliamentary broadcasts are people like Senator Walters. It is nonsense to suggest that there is some conspiracy, that we believed, or anyone else in this place believed, we could get away with something. There is an old saying in this place that if one has the choice between a conspiracy and a muck-up, pick a muck-up every time, and that is dead right.

-by leave-Mr President, I wish to ask a question of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). At the present time, whilst this matter is listed for presentation with a notation saying that copies of the report will not be available prior to tabling, I understand that once discussion on the papers is commenced the papers are considered to have been tabled. I still do not have a copy of the report. I am just curious. Can the Minister tell me when I am likely to get a copy of it? I would like to have 24 hours to peruse the report if I am going to debate it.

—by leave-The report should obviously be on the honourable senator's table now. It should have been distributed when it was tabled. I am afraid I am not responsible for the individual handing out of reports, but I will make sure that the honourable senator will get it in the next five or 10 minutes. We will extend the time tomorrow for another five or 10 minutes so that the honourable senator will get the full 24 hours.

—Order! I point out that under the practice which has developed in the handling of these reports, the debate on the East Timor statement having been interrupted the matter will be listed automatically for debate tomorrow.
