DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE AND STATUTORY AUTHORITIES AMENDMENT BILL 1983COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (REDEPLOYMENT AND RETIREMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1983COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS) REPEAL BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating three allied Bills. The Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill repeals the no work as directed -no pay provisions for public servants and employees of statutory authorities. The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill removes the provision that the rules laid down by this Parliament for the redeployment and retirement of Government's employees may not be altered by the arbitration system. The Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill removes the power, subject to ministerial direction, of dismissal of Commonwealth employees engaged in industrial action and of standing down employees who cannot be usefully employed because of strike action.

SPEECH.PARA: All these three Bills weaken the position of the Government as an employer in relation to its employees and strengthen the ability of public servants to harm the interests of the public they are supposed to be serving. As I pointed out before the suspension of sitting for lunch, we have by world standards a deplorable record of industrial relations and the most regrettable international reputation for lack of industrial discipline. The Government, which is by far the biggest employer in this country, has a duty to set an example to the rest of the community, apart from the fact that a public servant is an especially advantaged type of employee. I will return to that point in a moment.

Let us look at these three Bills in turn. The Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill gives an arbitrator power to alter the rules for the redeployment and retirement of public servants. It gives power to an arbitrator to alter rules set by Parliament, rules that were established by this Parliament after considerable debate. If the Government does not like these rules, which in my opinion lean over backwards to be fair to public servants, it should propose changes to this Parliament or amend the regulations which are subject to disallowance by the Senate. It should not abdicate its responsibility in this craven way. The whole Bill is a cop out by the Government in an area of great importance. If we want to have an efficient and responsive Public Service capable of meeting the rapidly changing needs of this nation, we must have effective arrangements for using public servants in the most efficient way and, on fair grounds, for getting rid of those who cannot perform effectively.

The Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill takes away an important disciplinary power which the Commonwealth has, and needs as an employer. There has been a pernicious development in industrial relations in recent years. Instead of going on strike, employees disrupt proceedings by refusing to do certain types of vital work, but continue to draw full pay. To give an example, a strike is going on at the moment in the Australia Council. There the employees refuse to give any information about any new program, to the considerable disadvantage of the groups they are supposed to be servicing.

I think this power is one the Commonwealth should and must have, and to give it up in this spineless way is a ridiculous capitulation to union pressure. The trouble is, as the Victoria Government has discovered, that capitulating in this way does not even achieve the objectives which the Government sought. I instance the Victorian Government. It gave a 25 per cent pay rise to school teachers because of their support in the last election campaign in Victoria, hoping that that would keep them on side. Now the Victorian Government is engaged in a bitter dispute with those same school teachers.

The third Bill is the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill, which does two things. Its removal of the power to stand down employees who cannot be usefully employed because of strike action puts the Commonwealth Government at a disadvantage when compared with many other employers who have stand-down provisions in their awards. I understand that 37 per cent of awards contain stand-down provisions. Because of the way in which strikes are being oganised these days when a small key group goes out-for example, the signal men in the rail system-it totally stops the operation of the whole system. The vast bulk of the employees are not on strike although in many cases they are co- conspirators with those on strike. Stand-down provisions for people who cannot be employed usefully are an important weapon in settling this sort of dispute and one the Government is being extremely foolish in giving up.

The other part of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill relates to the dismissal of public servants who are on strike. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has suggested that this is unnecessary and I am inclined to agree with him. Section 66 of the Public Service Act, forbids, on pain of summary dismissal, any strike which interferes with or prevents the carrying on of any part of the public services of the Commonwealth. Although section 66 has been in the Act since 1922, the power has never been invoked. In 1976 the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration recommended that it should be deleted on the grounds that in the current industrial climate, section 66 is not viable and that time lost due to industrial action was considerably less in the Public Service than in the remainder of the civilian work force. These are specious grounds.

The question is surely: Why are there any industrial actions in the Public Service? Public servants are a special type of employee who should expect on joining the Public Service that they will not be permitted to take industrial action against the public they are supposed to be serving. They are not alone in this. It is the position in the United States public service as honourable senators will remember from the highly successful and effective action taken by President Reagan against air traffic controllers. There is a move in sections of the British Civil Service to agree not to strike in any circumstances. Of course , people joining our Defence Force understand that they may not strike or mutiny . They accept this limitation when they join and surely that is or should be the situation with our public servants.

An essential ingredient of becoming a servant of the public, a public servant, is the implicit undertaking that one will not take strike action which will harm that public in pursuit of one's personal gain. In compensation for the loss of a right which most other sections of the work force enjoy, our public servants have considerable benefits. They have, despite the Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Act, much greater security of tenure than almost anyone else in the work force. They have a superannuation scheme which is far more generous than any in private industry. I will take an interesting example: One has only to look at Trans Australia Airlines which was forced by the Whitlam Government to give its then employees the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. It has never been able to afford that scheme. If it had attempted to pay it, or had accepted the liability for paying it, it would be technically bankrupt. Ansett Airlines of Australia has a superannuation scheme but it could not remotely afford for its employees the Commonwealth superannuation scheme which our public servants have. In my view it is a compensation for the limitation of their rights in some other direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not acknowledged by a lot of the beneficiaries in the statutory authorities, is it?

—I am suggesting that these rules apply to employees of the Commonwealth, both public servants and the employees of statutory bodies. They have these privileges and in return they owe something to the community which pays heavily for giving them these special privileges. Even in the area of pay and conditions they have an understanding with the Government that their pay and conditions are to be equivalent to those of comparable positions in the private sector, except perhaps in the most senior positions. These are considerable compensations indeed. Undoubtedly it would be difficult suddenly to start enforcing section 66 even though it could be argued that all existing public servants have, by voluntarily joining the Public Service, accepted the terms of the Act in the same way as someone voluntarily joining the Defence Force accepts the provisions of the Defence Act. But I agree that it would be difficult suddenly to start enforcing this.

SPEECH.PARA: What I suggest we should do is to obtain from all new Public Service recruits a signed undertaking of acceptance of section 66. Any breach by them of its terms would of course result, under section 66, in summary dismissal. I think we should also give existing public servants the opportunity to sign acceptance of section 66. If they agreed to do so-all of them joined while that section was in the Act, and I think most of them would agree because the overwhelming majority of them really believe that public servants and statutory authority employees do not strike-they would then be legally and morally entitled to receive the compensations for this loss of a so-called right. They would receive the compensations of security of tenure, superannuation and generous pay in return for a right which they had given up.

But, in my view, those who are not prepared to accept that public servants do not strike, those who wish to be able to use their industrial muscle against the public they are supposed to be serving, should not have these compensations. They should not be permitted to have it both ways. They should therefore lose the special tenure and superannuation provisions now given to public servants and instead have security of tenure and a superannuation system similar to those in private industry. I do not think it is reasonable for them to attempt to have it both ways. For those in the latter category, those who are not prepared to accept the existing provisions of section 66, in my view it would be necessary to retain the stand-down provisions in the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act.

Two further points need to be made. The first is that, if we enforce the existing rules and deprive public servants of the right to strike, we must be sure that the arrangements for maintaining their pay and conditions work properly and that reasonable public servants are satisfied that they are being fairly treated. I suggest that we should consider points such as these: The Public Service Board should initiate regular action to ensure that Public Service pay and conditions maintain reasonable relativity with those in private industry, without waiting for a union log of claims and the Public Service Board should make it clear that this is the way it will operate. Secondly, the Public Service Board should ensure that all groups in the Public Service are fairly treated. At the moment there are some groups which seem to be too small for either the union or the Public Service Board to be concerned about. An efficient Public Service Board would surely see that anomalies such as this are promptly spotted and rectified.

I believe that the importance of the Government as an employer and the not very impressive record of the Public Service Board may justify the appointment of a full time Minister to oversee Public Service activities. I have some alarming stories of the absurd way in which staff ceilings have been implemented, for instance. The Government was anxious to restrain the growth of the Public Service and applied staff ceilings. But the consequence was that, although the numbers were held, the gradings of almost all positions rose to absurd levels. I realise that at the very highest levels of the Public Service officers are probably paid less than those in comparable positions in private industry. But at the lower levels, we find that a department section consists of a Class 11, a Class 9, a Class 7-all bosses with no subordinates-and a typist. What they have done is to upgrade the level of positions. This has reached an absurd level and can be effectively controlled only by a Public Service Board which is able, willing and powerful enough to go into these sorts of things and, of course, which has both the direction and the will to achieve the results we are looking for. After all, our reputation with the Public Service as a fair and sensible employer is very much in the hands of the Public Service Board, and its reputation is not very high at the moment.

But, important though these matters are, they are separate from the issue I was raising about Public Service strikes. A point raised about Public Service strikes is that the 'no strike' provision may be contrary to a convention of the International Labour Organisation. I do not think this is a valid objection. Article 4 of ILO Convention 151 states:

Employees shall enjoy adequate protection against acts of anti-union discrimination in respect of their employment and particularly if it causes the dismissal of, or otherwise prejudices, a public employee because of his participation in the normal activities of such an organisation.

This Convention has not been ratified by Australia. When the proposed Article 4 was discussed at the ILO Conference, a number of member countries pointed out that government employment involved a different relationship from that of employment elsewhere, and that it could not be expected that all rights enjoyed in the private sector could be extended to public employees-the very point I was making earlier. It was also pointed out that the right to strike could not be considered a normal activity of public employee organisations because any recognition of the right to strike by public servants could cast doubt upon their political neutrality and undermine public faith in the civil service.

Our Public Service is one of our great national assets. We do not always recognise that we are one of the very few countries that have an efficient, non- political, non-corrupt Public Service. I am sure the overwhelming proportion of the Public Service has no desire to strike and injure the public it is supposed to be serving. We have the duty to see that public servants are fairly treated, but the implicit encouragement these Bills give them to take industrial action is contrary to the interests of both the Public Service and the nation as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three Bills which deal with employment provisions of Commonwealth public servants. The purpose of the first Bill, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill, is to repeal the no work as directed-no pay provisions introduced in 1980 for legislation applying to the Public Service and to the six Commonwealth authorities, including the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The second of these Bills, the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill, is to repeal the legislation which was seen by the former Liberal-National Party Government as legislation which was to be used only in extreme circumstances when the public interest demanded it as an essential area of government activity , as a means of urgently resolving a dispute. The third Bill, the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill, again is to permit determinations and awards to be made by the Public Service Arbitrator and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of staff matters arising under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, a jurisdiction removed by amendments in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a great pity that the Australian Labor Party, in government, has decided to make those alterations to the employment arrangements for Commonwealth employees clearly on the basis of emotional nonsense spoken about those Bills when they were originally passed by the Liberal-National Party Government. It seems to be a great pity that when we get a change of government people in the new government tend to do things because of emotions aroused during the time of the previous government instead of for sensible reasons. There is no doubt that governments pass legislation which is of benefit. What should happen is that new governments should assess all the former Government's legislation on the basis of its merits rather than on the basis of emotions and recognise that Liberal-National Party governments can pass certain legislation which Labor governments could never get through without losing the basis of their support, just as my parties must remember that Labor governments can pass legislation which we would never be able to get through when we get back to government. I recognise that. It is one of those things.

In fact, the ALP, in government, frequently seems able to exercise a greater degree of control over the trade union movement than can the Liberal and National parties in government. We saw evidence of that during the time of the Labor Government of 1972-75. It did not happen in the initial stages, but by 1975 people such as Mr Clyde Cameron had had it up to the neck with the Public Service and were introducing legislation and adopting procedures to make sure public servants behaved in the manner in which he believed they should behave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cameron, in 1973, encouraged their irresponsibility.

—I agree with my colleague Senator Peter Rae from Tasmania. There is not the slightest doubt that in 1973 Mr Cameron encouraged public servants to act in a manner which was most irresponsible. Frankly, that is what this Government is doing with the legislation that is before the Senate at the moment . This legislation will ultimately encourage Commonwealth servants to proceed with abandon in regard to strike action. When the union leaders decide that the time has come to take those steps they will be able to do so with impunity. There is no doubt that these three Bills very substantially weaken the position of government and strengthen the position of government employee unions to hold the Government of this nation to ransom.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been significant changes in the techniques used by unions in industrial disputations in this country. What is happening frequently is that the labour of key employees only is being withdrawn. It is no longer one out all out in the old tradition of what unionism was all about. That, of course, leaves the remainder in the position where they expect to be paid even though useful work may not be available. One of the changes included in these Bills is that that will be open to the unions and the counter to it will not be available to the Government. I know that the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, will get up in a few minutes and tell us that the Liberal-National parties do not know anything at all about industrial affairs and unions and all the rest of it. But Senator Button, who has just walked into the chamber and is thinking about his speech to follow me, will live to regret the day that this legislation was passed by this Parliament.

It is interesting to note that both in public and private enterprise there is an increasing unwillingness to abide by decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission unless they are to the unions' advantage. For evidence of that one has only to look at what happened recently with the decision of the Commission to grant a wage rise of 4.3 per cent across the board. In the light of the present economic situation and the present unemployment situation, and with business enterprise and the depression certainly at the lowest ebb that they have been since the 1930s, there is no way that the workers of this country should have bargained for a wage rise. In fact, everyone knows that there ought to be a reduction in real wages across the board. The Senate will recall that both my colleague Senator Hamer and I publicly recommended in this place that what the Liberal-National parties in government should have done at the time of the wage pause was to have top public servants take a salary cut of 10 per cent and middle level public servants take a cut of 5 per cent. We recommended that the Government should then have gone to the nation and asked others to take similar cuts across the board. That did not happen. One of the results of that has been the very substantial increase in unemployment in the last 15 months or so.

Anyone who applies his mind to the economic situation of this country at the moment knows that a wage rise at this time is an absolute nonsense. A wage rise of 4.3 per cent at the moment will inevitably lead to much more shedding of labour as private enterprise cannot afford to pay that sort of increase. The unions must have known this. Instead of the unions trying to bargain with employers to get an increase in wages they went to the Government and said: ' Well, this is part of the accord; we have to get indexation.' The Government fell for that line and went before the Commission with the unions. And what have we got? We have a 4.3 per cent wage rise.

Let there be no doubt that when this economy starts to recover the unions will step outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, just as the building unions have already stepped outside the Commission's decisions, and will endeavour to use their muscle in order to push this nation into a worse situation than it is in at present by insisting on massive wage rises. Those wage rises will be on top of the high level of wages that they will receive as a result of the 4.3 per cent wage rise. So when the economy recovers, instead of wage rises being put on top of perhaps a lowered wage in real terms, they will be able to jump off from the higher level. The unions are unwilling to abide by the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission unless it is to their advantage. We see the increasing willingness of unions, even unions not normally involving themselves in industrial action, to bring industrial action, all encouraged by the results of this system of ours which seems to have gone right off the rails. I am talking about ship masters and pilots. Of course the teachers have become more and more militant over the years. I also include nurses, air traffic controllers and other such people. Less and less is strike action being seen as a weapon of last resort and more and more as a weapon of first resort.

We have to look at what has gone wrong with our system. When this system was set up it was thought that if disputes were taken before a court, the court might be able to bring about a more equitable decision than if the parties endeavoured to settle the dispute at the work place. At that time the union movement was not strong, employees were not strong and there was a lot of merit in that situation. But unions have now created monopoly situations. Unions are in the situation in which free enterprise and private enterprise were in 100 years ago. Although I know Senator Button will try to tell me that unions do not create a monopoly situation, when those unions want to act together they do have a monopoly effect. In Western Australia, for example, where there are I think nine unions involved in the mining industry, one could say they do not have a monopoly situation, but as soon as those nine unions put their heads together-if this Government can ever persuade them to do that-they would certainly create a position of monopoly. Unions are using this weapon in a way which is unfair to the people of Australia. Do not worry about whether it is unfair to the employers or unfair even to the Government; it is unfair to fellow citizens of this nation.

I turn to the situation of the Public Service in this country. I agree with my colleague Senator Hamer that public servants should not be allowed to withdraw their labour. That ought to be a fundamental principle of becoming a servant of the public. In return for that provision, for abandoning the right to strike, I agree that public servants should receive security of tenure, superannuation and all those other benefits which they now receive. I think there is much more merit in Senator Hamer's proposal. I would be interested to see this Government pick it up. No doubt it will not at this stage. But as difficulties arise it may ultimately decide to pick up Senator Hamer's proposal that new public servants, as they come on to the payroll, should be asked to sign an undertaking not to strike and that existing public servants ought to be offered the opportunity to sign an undertaking not to strike. I am sure many public servants would agree to sign such an undertaking. The others who refused to sign such an undertaking should have it made perfectly clear to them that their positions would be as for non-public servants; that they would lose their security of tenure. No doubt one could not take away their enormous superannuation benefits, but at least one could take away their security of tenure.

Public servants are employed to serve the government of the day and the people of the nation. In return they get these very special rewards which many of us-I am talking about many parliamentarians at this stage-frequently have to go out and defend in our electorates. Time after time we attend meetings at which we are attacked because of the very generous superannuation provisions which are granted to public servants and we have to explain why they are entitled to them. In return one is unable to say that they have abandoned the right to strike, which would be the perfect answer to these criticisms. Many of the services of these people reach right into the fabric of our society-postal services, communications of all kinds, the payment of pensions and other benefits around the country, rail and air transport, and fuel supplies. All of those things are part of the very fabric of our society.

Mr Acting Deputy President, one of the things that interests me is the development of proper industrial relations. I am disappointed that Senator Peter Cook from Western Australia apparently is not here today and is not speaking on these Bills because I know that he has views about the development of industrial relations which interest me considerably. Many of them are along the lines of my own thinking on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not smear him behind his back, Senator. That is very unkind.
—Senator Button is suggesting that I am smearing Senator Cook behind his back by saying that he and I have a number of views in common in regard to industrial relations.
—You said: 'We think along the same lines'. My point is that you do not think at all; he does.

—I have no intention of smearing Senator Cook by reference to our having similar ideas. There are a number of people in this Parliament who believe that one of the major problems of this nation is that relations between our employers and employees are at a very low level, and for that I blame many of the employers. I know that many of my supporters believe that the only people who are responsible for this are union officials who use their industrial muscle regularly, repeatedly and unnecessarily. I know that that is a fact on many occasions. But on the other hand I openly acknowledge that many employers, especially those in the giant organisations-again it is giantism; I talked about the monopoly of the unions and I talk now about giant industries-have much to learn. For example, they could take their lessons from the Japanese and look at Mitsubishi Australia Ltd and the industrial relations it has developed. That is an example of the sort of thing that can be done if only employers and employees will get together and resolve their disputes at the work place. Together they can decide how the company can become profitable so that benefits can be paid to both the owners of the business and the employees, commensurate with the sort of work they are doing.

SPEECH.PARA: There are methods whereby this can happen. I hope that this Government will endeavour to implement some of those methods in the Public Service. I hope that the Government will adopt procedures which will enable the Public Service to become much more efficient and will enable public servants to make a genuine and valid contribution to the improvement and efficiency of the services they provide. That is something which an Australian Labor Party government might be able to do better than a Liberal-National party government. I do not know, but I shall certainly be watching what this Government does along those lines in the hope that we see real improvements in the efficiency of the Public Service. Until now we have not been given any indication that this Government will lead the way towards any improvement in industrial relations. In fact, quite the contrary applies. What it seems to be doing is encouraging the public servants of the Commonwealth to take industrial action at will, knowing that the Government will not take any steps to counteract their action.

I draw attention to the recent Canberra mail strike. I do not know whether the people of Australia are aware that for a period of four weeks there was a strike over a nonsense matter with regard to Canberra mail. Government Ministers demonstrated that they were not prepared to do anything about that strike by adopting the very simple method of using other means of getting their mail to and from Canberra. Government Ministers arranged for their outwards mail to be posted in New South Wales and for their incoming mail to be brought by their staff to Canberra from the capital cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just silly and you know it.

—Senator Button says that that is silly. Senator Button knows that it is true. A post office just out of Canberra had never had so much mail in all the years it had been in existence. It was absolutely inundated with mail. Government Ministers were quite desperate to ensure that they did nothing to upset the union which was holding the capital of this country to ransom. It held it to ransom for four weeks over an absolute nothing. What happened then? The people who had been on strike wanted to be paid for the time they had been on strike. The Government said: 'We cannot just pay them. We will have to find some method of paying them'. The Government sent the matter to an arbitrator who came out, believe it or not, and said that it was a proper strike and that those people were entitled to receive their pay. The Government then gave those people their pay. This Government is clearly giving the unionists anything and everything they want. That will not help industrial relations in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to the Senate that these Bills and the revocation of these powers is a clear indication that the Government is seeking an excuse to avoid taking any action in the future. The Government will be able to say: 'We have no power to do anything'. If the Government had kept these Bills alive then it would have had the power to act. I suggest to the Government that this is just a cop out and that the very special relationship which this Government claims with the employees of the nation simply means that the Government gives in on every issue . Let us look at some examples of what has occurred in recent times. I refer to a case which involved an Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority employee who was recently sacked for misappropriation of materials, equipment and manpower. Criminal charges could have been brought against this gentleman, but instead the Electricity Authority in Canberra settled for reimbursement. What happened in September after the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) intervened? The employee was reinstated at a demoted level. He was given back his job. What an absolute nonsense. Instead of criminal charges being brought against him, because the union used some muscle on Mr Uren the fellow got his job back.

On 3 November the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in the other place told the Parliament that in regard to legal costs incurred by the Transport Workers Union in defending itself against charges brought against it in the Federal Court by the Trade Practices Commission-the legal costs wre estimated to be about $10,000-the Government had agreed to step in and pay the $ 10,000. On the same day, 3 November-that day will probably go down in history in regard to this Government's industrial relations policies-Mr Willis confirmed that the Government had decided not to proceed with its claims for costs incurred in the prosecution of trade union officials in the Federal Court for refusing to answer questions before the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Senate will remember that those fellows absolutely defied the Costigan Commission. They refused to answer any questions. Ultimately they came before the Court and were fined a miserable $500.

I wonder what would happen if an ordinary citizen had come before the Court. He would probably be serving an 18-months gaol sentence or perhaps serving an indefinite period in gaol until he was prepared to go before the Costigan Commission and give evidence. That is the sort of thing that would happen to the ordinary citizen, but these fellows were members of the Builders Labourers Federation so they were fined $500. They also had costs awarded against them. Of course, everyone said: 'At least the costs will be substantial even if the fine is insignificant'. What happened was that the Government stepped in and said: ' We will no bother to recover the costs against the people who refused to go before Mr Costigan and give their evidence'. One wonders how the Government can possibly face Mr Costigan and ask him to continue with his commission in the light of that cop out. One wonders why the Government has copped out in relation to these people. I hope that when Senator Button responds to this speech he will give us some explanation for that cop out.

Again on the same day, 3 November-an infamous day-Mr Willis announced a deal with the Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labour Council in which the Government would drop 29 charges against Australian Capital Territory union officials involving trespass if the Trades and Labour Council would agree to abandon a program of bans and pickets it had initiated because it resented the police doing their duty and felt that there was not enough subsidised accommodation in Canberra. So 29 charges were dropped. It is all summed up very well in an editorial in the Canberra Times dated Monday, 14 November, headed ' Anything for a Quiet Life', which states:

As far as the Government, the ALP and the union officials are concerned, all this conciliation, capitulation and compromise is good industrial relations. Principle and morality are at a discount. What is disturbing to the rest of the community-or should be-is that the Government and the employers are doing the capitulating, and it is the rest of the community's interests that are being compromised. For the sake of the unions' social concience, of course. Recall the settlement of the recent mail strike. Obviously, trade unionists are 'in' under the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Public Service and Statutory Authority Amendment Bill 1983, the Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill 1983. The Bills deal with Commonwealth employees and employees of statutory authorities. I have listened with interest to the comments made by my colleagues Senator Hamer and Senator Lewis. I agree that industrial relations is a most important responsibility for government. Australia has suffered severely over the years because of strikes of one type or another. It seems that these days the types of strikes that are prevalent are those described by Senator Lewis and Senator Hamer. They are where key personnel withhold their services in an industry, causing great disruption and hardship for many other workers in the community who are innocent of any involvement in the dispute concerned. I for one have been appalled at how demarcation disputes can disrupt Australia's capacity to trade. Senator Hamer referred to that. At present our reputation overseas is miserable with respect to reliability. Can people expect to receive their goods from Australia on time? The international view is that we have become unreliable. It is very important that we repair that damage.
—I think you are overstating that.

—No, not at all. I was in Korea earlier this year. The industrial leaders to whom I spoke were very anxious to purchase more of our beef and our coal. I referred to uranium as well, because they have under way a massive expansion of their nuclear power station program in that country. Their main problem is whether they can rely on Australia to deliver the goods on time. For example, they have to have a stockpile of steaming coal of about two months supply. If we hold up these goods on our wharves for three months, it is clear that the purchasing countries will say: 'We can get our coal from Brazil, South Africa, Canada or some other country, where we can rely on the goods arriving on time'. That is a very serious problem for us to discuss and to solve. I do not think that the way in which we are going about it at present will help.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of repealing legislation which was in train with the former Government, such as no work as directed no pay, is reasonable. It makes people think before they take the sort of disastrous actions that have occurred in the past. I recall the occasion a few years ago when key workers withheld their services in the Latrobe Valley area. About five or six personnel were involved, but they were able to disrupt an incredibly large industrial sector and to cause about 400,000 workers, who were innocent of the dispute, to be stood down. I recall that at that time the Federal union concerned instructed those employees to return to work in the interests of the other workers of Australia, having discussed the matter and having been satisfied with the result. But these workers persisted. It was at that time that the Fraser Government introduced special legislation which enabled the Government to deal with a section of a particular Federal union. That action resulted in those workers returning to work, although at the time the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Hawke, claimed the responsibility for solving the problem.

I remember that when Mr Hawke took over the presidency of the ACTU, I was at Port Augusta. I was in the House of Representatives as the Federal member for Grey. Mr Hawke boasted that he could not abide the conciliatory approach that had been employed by his predecessor, Albert Monk, quite successfully. He said that he would get what he wanted by direct action. He certainly went about disrupting the industrial scene in Australia, because he presided over the greatest number of strikes which resulted in a greater loss of wages and working days than occurred during the time of any other president or union leader in our history. It is very serious when people are forced to go on strike. I agree that the figures are better now than they were in the three months of the quarter ended June 1982. There were then 306,800 working days lost, as compared with 759 ,900 in the June quarter 1981 and 760,900 in the June quarter 1980. So apparently some of the measures taken by the Fraser Government were reflected in fewer strikes over those three years. Nevertheless, although the working days lost were fewer, the total loss of working days was about 3,068,000 to the June quarter 1982, and the wages lost were about $18.25m, or about $75m in 12 months. That is an incredible amount.

I believe that the type of action that we are taking here will not discourage public servants from withholding their services to the public. Years ago the traditional ethnic was that public servants were quite proud of the fact that they would not strike. The suggestion made by Senator Lewis ought to be given very serious consideration. He suggested that public servants should be required to sign an agreement not to withhold their services from the people and that some traditional pride in the work that they are doing should be reintroduced. Mention has been made of the postal strike. That was an incredible strike. It disrupted local businesses not only in Canberra but interstate as well. It prevented superannuitants from receiving payments from funds with which they had superannuation arrangements in Sydney and other places. That was a regrettable state of affairs. I think that the workers were paid for three days of the week during which they went on the strike that resulted in that withholding or refusing to deliver mail in Canberra or to send mail out of this capital city.

Mention has been made of the scene in Japan. The Japanese have a different system altogether. Each industry has one union with which to deal. I visited a couple of large factories in Japan four or five years ago and talked to the managements and the workers. They have a system there in which they have a spring offensive, in which the union goes to management and demands increased wages and improvements in working conditions. They do that very effectively. The management lays the balance sheet on the table indicating the capacity of the industry to pay. That seems to be working exceptionally well in Japan. I did not think a few years ago that I would be saying that we should be aiming towards that system in Australia, where we have too many unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had your opportunity for seven years. You did nothing about it.

—I know. But Senator Button probably heard me say that the number of strikes had become less under the Fraser Administration. I should like to think that that had something to do with the changes to the arbitration system introduced during that period. When we came into government in 1975, we introduced compulsory voting for union official elections. We felt that that was a very important step because it gave responsible union people the opportunity to elect responsible union leaders. It has not worked in some unions. Some key unions still seem to have the extreme left wing entrenched. I would like to think that ultimately that left wing component will be changed and that more responsible leadership will prevail in some of the unions to which I refer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Relations Bureau was introduced in the first year or so after 1975. I was disappointed at the time because we drew the teeth of that legislation. I thought the initial Bill that was proposed was a good one, but because of the objections of the Australian Council of Trade Unions we backed down. I think that the result was a far less effective Bill. The time has come when Australia has to face the urgent need to deal with some of the matters to which I have referred, particularly demarcation disputes. Why should governments have to worry about them? The responsibility to determine what sort of work a particular person should carry out is quite properly the responsibility of the disputes council of the ACTU. It is the expert in these matters. It would be very helpful if we could get it to make these determinations so that demarcation disputes could then be avoided.

Under section 51 of the Constitution the Commonwealth Government has the responsibility to pass laws to ensure that interstate and overseas trading is carried out with a minimum amount of disruption. I for one have said for a long time, for about 12 years-one sometimes gets frustrated languishing on the back bench, but persistence will out-that we should consider the introduction of an essential services Act that would protect the workers of Australia in essential industrial areas, such as petroleum, communications, power generation and the waterfront. Any government which comes on to the treasury bench in Canberra has the responsibility to introduce laws for the benefit of the average Australian worker. We, as a Liberal Government, did that in a way different from that of the present Government. We believe that private enterprise ought to be encouraged. We believe that penalty rates ought to be re-examined, as should things like the 17 1/2 per cent holiday pay loading, which I was pleased to see Senator Button make some comment about not long ago. I support his concern in that respect and hope that he has the courage to re-examine the policies of the Government and that he will look at the wage structures of Australia so that we can profit by that.

I recall that on one occasion when Mr Hawke was the ACTU President and threatened to get his way by direct action, a key union official in Port Augusta at the time said to me that he disagreed with direct action. He believed that conciliation and negotiation were the ways to go about things and he cited the example of a recent achievement. He told me that, I think 18 months previously, his union went to the Electricity Trust of South Australia and the railways with a log of claims. I think there were six points in that log of claims. Four of them were agreed to after two or three hours discussion. One of the others took six months to resolve because it involved a policy change in the administration of the two organisations. The final claim took about 17 months to achieve because it involved the 17 1/2 per cent holiday pay loading. It took the union almost two years to achieve the result by persistent negotiation. I think that is the way we ought to go. Certainly, that particular union leader did not agree with Mr Hawke's initial statement that direct action was the answer to the union movement's problems. I think that Mr Hawke, in his latter days, has somewhat mellowed. I think he realises that the initial euphoria associated with the prominent position he held in those days has dissipated somewhat. Now he adopts a more sensible approach to these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pass that on to him, Senator. I am sure he will be pleased.

—I have always believed in paying some tribute. I think the consensus point he made was good. Drawing people together at the National Economic Summit Conference was also a good idea, but I have yet to see any real policies come out of that discussion. Perhaps the only thing I can say about Mr Hawke is that he has recognised that the election promises that he made were impossible to fulfil and he is now pursuing a course in many areas of administration that was set by the previous Fraser Government. I think that is probably why he is getting on reasonably well. But he is not getting on too well in the Caucus, I notice. There has been a lot of argument there in recent times. A very substantial number of Caucus members have a very poor view of the Government's attitude to uranium development. But I applaud the result of that Caucus meeting and I am sure that the Opposition will do all it can to ensure that the industry becomes established in Australia as soon as possible and that the action taken by the Government will be reflected in further uranium development being carried out in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am sure that we have all been fascinated by Senator Jessop's rather anecdotal speech, the industrial relations equivalent of a James Fitzpatrick travel talk. I am delighted to learn that he spoke to a union official in Port Augusta on some date or other, who told him this and to somebody else who told him something different. It is all very interesting, but it has no relevance to the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill which are now before the Senate. In a minute , I will come back to those Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I must say, however, on the general issue which has been dealt with by the last two speakers from the Opposition, speeches I had the benefit of hearing, that in pursuing this sort of anecdotal approach and talking about what might happen and what ought to happen and so forth, they have neglected the more important aspect of coming to grips with realities. There is not much point, for example, in trying to impose, or to suggest that there should be imposed, on Australia a Japanese industrial relations system. It might have very impressive results and I am sure it does, but we are talking about Australia where there is a different culture. Without hesitation, I say that the Japanese work harder than Australians whether they be people on the shop floor, managers or senators, or whoever. I suspect they work much harder than Australians. There is a cultural thing in Japan which is very much related to the Japanese view of nationhood and so on. We cannot just transpose to the Australian scene by the benefit of a speech in the Senate some of these things. Similarly, Senator Lewis made points about what he felt might be desirable, interspersed with his horror stories about the present Government and certain things that have happened in relation to the settlement of particular industrial disputes. I do not want to go into the details of all those comments that Senator Lewis made in his Edgar Allan Poe role; I simply say that half the information which he gave the Senate was incorrect or at least half-baked. On the basis of that, it is not very easy to build a persuasive thesis.

I make the point for the benefit of Senator Jessop who, having made his contribution, has left the chamber that he wants to argue that a particular system of industrial relations in Australia prescribed by legislation necessarily produces better results than another. He argued that by referring to the record of the Fraser Government which, I think, scarcely stands examination in terms of either industrial disputes or, certainly, wage fixation policies. If he examines the figures and looks at the level of industrial disputation, particularly in the last three years of the Fraser Government, and compares it with the level of industrial disputation in 1983, since this Government came to power, he will see that there is very strong evidence to suggest that the approach adopted by the present Government has been more successful than the approach adopted by the previous Government. I say that simply because in the period in which this Government has been in office the rate of unemployment and, the growth in the rate of unemployment have declined significantly. That is very relevant to the question of industrial disputation because there is a perfectly legitimate point that levels of employment have an influence on the levels of industrial disputation. So I do not think we can draw much comfort from all these things.

Senator Lewis said that the real solution to this country's problems is for there to be a reduction in wages generally. I do not shrink from the proposition that if that were to happen it might help the competitiveness of Australian industry, but of course we cannot take just one factor into account like that. All sorts of factors, including consumer demand, are very much related to the level of wages in a country. We in Australia have a relatively high wage structure. It is this Government's concern that as far as possible that level of wages, in terms of its effect on living standards, should be maintained. It is no help for Senator Jessop to suggest that a simple solution is the abolition of penalty rates because that is not only a simple solution, it is a simplistic solution-I might even go so far as to say it is a simple minded solution. We will not resolve problems by simple recourse to measures such as that.

The point I make about all these things is that the level of economic performance of a country is undoubtedly related to the level of industrial disputation. A country cannot perform successfully in an economic sense, as we ought to know from our own experience in this country-it was illustrated by numerous speakers on the other side-if the industrial relations system is not working or is not recognised as being of crucial importance to the economic system. It is in that context that there are differences of opinion between the Government and the Opposition about the particular proposals that these three Bills deal with.

I do not want to say much about the particular contributions that have been offered on these Bills; we have been through this debate in the Senate before. I simply refer the Senate to the first Bill, the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill, in which the essential ingredient is the question of the no work no pay provision. It appears that there is a difference of opinion between the Government and the Opposition as to the desirability of uniformity across the spectrum of employment in Australia, between the public sector and the private sector, on these sorts of conditions of employment. I simply assert that it has never been at traditional common law, except as effected by awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the right of employers effectively to suspend employees. They have always had the right to sack them but they have never at common law had the right to suspend them. Of course that situation has been altered by various provisions, both statutory and award. The fact of the matter is that the effects of this Bill in relation to the no work no pay provision will be to put the Public Service on a much more equitable basis with the private sector than it has been since the legislation now being amended was introduced.

The second Bill at issue, the Commonwealth Employees (Redployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill, deals with the question of whether the right to stand down, dismiss or, in the words of the legislation, redeploy a member of the Public Service or terminate his employment should be a right vested in the employer and carried out at the instigation of a Minister or should be exercised in a unilateral way without reference to an independent assessment of a factual situation. In essence, all the Government is saying in this legislation is that the question of whether an employee should be dismissed or redeployed is a question in respect of which there are always two sides to the argument. In that context, that question should be addressed by either the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the Public Service Arbitrator. The opportunity to be heard on such a matter should be there. That is a right which is accorded to employees in the private sector; it ought to be accorded to employees in the public sector.

Senator Lewis would blow all this away with a bit of huff and puff by saying that public servants have special entitlements of another kind, which is true, and that because they have those special entitlements of another kind they should be treated differently in respect of the basic and fundamental aspect of their employment-the right to terminate or redeploy. The Government's position in those circumstances is simply that the right to have the matter dealt with by the Public Service Arbitrator or the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be there. I am not dealing with all of the issues involved but am trying to isolate what seem to me to be the important ones which have been dealt with in the course of the debate.

The third piece of legislation concerns, of course, the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act, which currently provides for the suspension of Commonwealth employees engaging in industrial action, the standing down of employees affected by industrial action and the dismissal of Commonwealth employees who have been suspended. The legislation was introduced in 1977 and came into operation in 1979.

A lot of case histories have been put forward in the Senate about the application of these legislative provisions and their alleged success or otherwise. It is the Government's view that they have caused more industrial disruption than they have solved. Of course it is always attractive to see that an employer, or in this case the Government, has a weapon in its hands to deal with allegedly recalcitrant employees in the circumstances which have been discussed. But the Government's view is that the situation has not been well served by the presence of those provisions in the hands of government and we think, for a variety of reasons which have been debated ad infinitum in the Senate, that there should be a change. The CERR Act amendment is simply restoring the Arbitrator's jurisdiction. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has also announced a review of the legislation, which will be the subject of a report to the Government and the Parliament, presumably early next year.

In the course of the debate a number of comments were made about the Australian Public Service which I do not intend to deal with in any great detail. Senator Hamer, who is now in the chair, was one of the speakers. He drew attention to the possible use of section 66 of the Public Service Act in the sort of situation which we have been describing. Mr Deputy President, as I recall it that section of the Public Service Act has been there for a very long time. The view of that section, which I think has been around on both sides of politics, is that it is unworkable not only because of the requirement for formal hearings before a summary dismissal takes place, and all that goes with a formal hearing of that kind, but also because the industrial implications are potentially disastrous in terms of the additional attention which the use of those procedures attracts.

I do not think I need to comment on any of the remarks made by Senator Walters who made, if I may say so, with respect, a traditional contribution to the debate. I appreciate the spirit in which comments have been made generally by honourable senators. All they reveal, of course, is the fundamentally different approach to these matters of the Government as against the Opposition. Should we approach them on a consensual basis or should we try to use the various punitive weapons which have not been really effective, in our view, and are not likely to be effective, and which have been the subject of a considerable degree of criticism by bodies such as the International Labour Organisation? I think we should be aware of those criticisms. If Senator Lewis's direst predictions come true, the Government has to bear the consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all do.

—Yes, but no worse consequences than the former Government had to bear in the past. The point I am making is that there is a diference of opinion. By the works of each political party in government we shall all be judged. We are prepared to face up to that judgment on the basis of our own decision about the importance of this legislation which I commend to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 10 November 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I suggest that it might suit the convenience of the Senate if the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill 1983 and the Director of Public Prosecutions ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 are debated cognately.
—There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill 1983 and the Director of Public Prosecutions ( Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983. In fact, we believe they are very useful proposals and hope that they have a speedy passage and become law as soon as possible. The proposal to establish a Director of Public Prosecutions is one which has been under consideration for some considerable time. Of course, the original Office of Director of Public Prosecutions was established in England, I think in the last century. Certainly it has been a feature of the administration of criminal justice in the United Kingdom for many years. The nature of the Office there, of course, is somewhat different from the way it will work in the Commonwealth sphere because the prosecution system in England involves a multiplicity of prosecuting authorities around the country. The object of the role of Director of Public Prosecutions in the United Kingdom is simply to deal with major crime. The Director can take over the conduct of any prosecutions or commence his own prosecutions in regard to other matters, but in fact his practice is to confine himself to major crime. In the event, the Director of Public Prosecutions in England prosecutes only a very small proportion of indictable offences in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal before us in this legislation seems to be a more ambitious one, that is, that the Office of Director of Public Prosecutions should largely become the chief prosecutor for the Commonwealth of Commonwealth offences in Australia. However, as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) points out in his second reading speech, it may be desirable, for the time being in all events , to leave the role to be performed in some parts of Australia, as it has been traditionally, by the Deputy Crown Solicitor acting under the Judiciary Act on behalf of and with the authority of the Attorney-General.

The justification for the establishment of this office is due largely to the great increase in recent years in offences against Federal laws, not only in terms of quantity but also in terms of seriousness. I suppose the most dramatic has been the great problem of the enforcement of our laws against the importation of drugs of all kinds. There has been an increase in the number and seriousness of major crimes which in some cases have led to major conspiracy trials. There have also been quite a number of other major trials as a result of offences against Commonwealth laws. As I said earlier, the Deputy Crown Solicitors in the various parts of Australia, under the authority of the Attorney-General, have traditionally prosecuted these offences.

The Crown Solicitor's Division is a very old and important one and has been part of the Attorney-General's Department and under the Attorney-General's jurisdiction for many years. The work of the Crown Solicitor is spread across the whole range of legal work and litigation which comes within the responsibility of the Attorney-General. The Crown Solicitor's offices are almost overwhelmed by the volume of litigation of both a civil and criminal kind. As we know, a lot of that work is very important testing work of a civil and constitutional nature, and great expertise has been developed in these areas. On the other hand, a great deal of minor routine criminal work has to be attended to in regard to Federal crime. Nevertheless, because of the increase in the complexity and seriousness of crime in recent years it seems that the time really has arrived for a greater specialisation, at least within the Attorney- General's Department, in the conduct of criminal proceedings. Even apart altogether from the proposal for a directorate of public prosecutions, there would be a very strong case for the establishment of a special prosecuting arm of the Attorney-General's Department. The States have always had an office of crown prosecutor which is headed usually by an officer known as the Chief Crown Prosecutor. This is one of the most senior positions on the staff of the State departments of justice or Attorney-General, whatever they happen to be called. It is clear that the time has come at the Federal level for specialisation of that kind.

As I have said, this proposal goes further. It involves the establishment of an independent Office of Director of Public Prosecutions, which will have an expert staff. No doubt people who have specialised in this area in the Crown Solicitor' s Division of the Attorney-General's Department will be seeking to move to the Office of Director of Public Prosecutions. The Director therefore will have readily at his disposal a number of experts in the field. Also, he will be recruiting his own staff, and I think it will be a good thing that there will be an opportunity to bring in new blood, so to speak. No doubt positions will be created and people of high calibre will be attracted to work for the directorate .

I believe that a move in this direction was made at about this time last year with the creation of the Special Prosecutor. It was seen as desirable that an office of independent prosecutor should be created to deal with cases where criticism or concern was expressed about the role of the Attorney-General's Department or the Crown Solicitor's Division in cases of great complexity such as bottom of the harbour schemes. The Special Prosecutors Act and the appointments of two special prosecutors which were made under it last year in the wake of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union clearly established the need for an independent prosecuting arm for the Attorney-General. I am pleased to note that this legislation recognises that fact. It does not seek to remove or repeal the previous legislation. Indeed I think there will be very full justification for its use in the future as well as in regard to the two cases which led to special prosecutors being appointed under the legislation of a year ago.

The same thinking behind the establishment of the special prosecutors has led to the further step of having the general prosecutions of Commonwealth related crime in the hands of a specialist, a person who is independent and seen to be independent of the Attorney-General and of any political influence. As I have said, there are the considerations of that kind as well as the considerations of achieving more efficient and expert prosecutions at the Commonwealth level to which the creation of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions will give rise, and which the Opposition fully supports.

The question does arise as to the accountability of such an office. Under Victorian legislation, as I understand it, the Director of Public Prosecutions there has been granted complete independence and is not subject to direction from the Attorney-General. I understand that the situation is the same in regard to the Crown Advocate in Tasmania. However, that has never been the case with the Director of Public Prosecutions in England. He has always been subject to directions of the Attorney-General. I think it is appropriate that the Australian Attorney-General as a member of the Government and of the Parliament should retain ultimate responsibility for the administration and enforcement of the criminal law of the Commonwealth.

This Bill preserves that very high function of the Attorney-General. It enables him to conduct prosecutions in his own right, although, obviously, that would be done only in very rare cases, because he would have this major, prestigious and expert Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions to carry on the work of prosecutions for the Commonwealth in the great majority of cases. However, that political responsibility remains with the Attorney-General and directions can also be given by the Attorney-General to the Director of Public Prosecutions. As is appropriate any directions will have to be made known by being tabled in Parliament. However there is some qualification in that if such directions might prejudice a trial, they would not be tabled until the trial had concluded.

Another important aspect, although it may not be so obviously understood, is that the legislation does enable the Director of Public Prosecutions, and ultimtely the Attorney-General by direction to the Director of Public Prosecutions, to take over any prosecutions which have been commenced and to conduct committal proceedings or to take over the conduct of committal proceedings which have already been commenced. There has been some doubt as to the powers of the Attorney-General under the present law in that regard. I believe it is most desirable that that matter should be clarified. It is certainly desirable that in any prosecution for an offence against the Commonwealth laws, whether it be at the committal stage, in summary proceedings or on indictment, there should be this overall control by the most senior prosecuting official of the Commonwealth to take over and conduct such proceedings or to cease the prosecutions.

In this country under the Crimes Act prosecutions can in fact be commenced by private persons. It is also desirable that those prosecutions should be ultimately under the control of the senior prosecuting authority. In this case they will be under the Director of Public Prosecutions who is given the power, as I said, to take over, to carry on to withdraw from, or to cease, prosecutions in accordance with evidence he has been given and with his own judgment. All in all, I believe that this measure is a very important one. It is making a very sound contribution to the better administration of criminal justice at the Commonwealth level in the prosecution of Federal offences against Federal laws in this country and it has the full support of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am indebted to Senator Durack for the warm support that he has given the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill on behalf of the Opposition. This legislation is very important, and as I said in my second reading speech, it is a response to some very great difficulties which the Commonwealth process has got itself into in recent years with the mounting complexity of tax matters and other major criminal offences involving co-ordination of a number of different Commonwealth agencies. It is a long overdue reform. I appreciate the way in which Senator Durack on behalf of the Opposition has recognised the balances which are built into the particular model in the form in which it has been proposed. I am delighted that he should show so much confidence today in the position of the Attorney-General in relation to the powers of the Director of Public Prosecutions, given the rather conspicuous lack of confidence in my occupancy of that office that he and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) were demonstrating as recently as last week.
—The office.

—The office, yes, but these days the man and the office are indistinguishable and will remain so for a long while yet, I assure the honourable senator. So I do not think it is necessary to do anything more than to wish the Bills a speedy passage.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS BILL 1983DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the remaining stages of the passage through the Senate of the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill 1983 and the Director of Public Prosecutions (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 being put in one motion at each stage and of the consideration of the Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Second Readings
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSFER OF PRISONERS BILL 1983TRANSFER OF PRISONERS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Transfer of Prisoners Bill 1983 and the Transfer of Prisoners (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 which are the result of many years of discussion in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Certainly it was a proposal that was already on the agenda-I do not know how long it had been there-when I became Attorney- General over six years ago. It is perhaps rather surprising that these discussions take so long in that Committee. The Standing Committee of Attorneys- General is a body which comprises the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth and the Attorney-General of all the States and the Northern Territory. It has, by a slow but apparently reasonably effective process in regard to a number of matters, achieved worthwhile results. I remember a year or so ago recommending to the Parliament a uniform domicile Bill for Australia which had been the work of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General for a considerable period. The problem addressed by this legislation-as I have said, it is legislation that will be passing not only through this Parliament but also through the State parliaments-is that prisoners in State gaols cannot be transferred to another State.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Commonwealth Government does not have any prisons of its own, and under the Constitution the States are obliged to receive Federal offenders who are sentenced to a term of imprisonment, the State gaol system accommodates Federal prisoners. It accommodates them on the same basis as State prisoners. Therefore, any Commonwealth offender who is sentenced to a term of imprisonment in one State but who may come from another State cannot be transferred to his home State even though it may be much more suitable for the prisoner to serve the sentence in his own State. That may well apply to State offenders as well because they may be sentenced and imprisoned under the laws of a State other than their home State. So we have the problem arising that both Federal and State prisoners can be imprisoned away from their homes which presents very great and in many cases very harrowing circumstances not only for the prisoners but also for the families of the prisoners who were unable to visit them.

I am very conscious that over the years that I was Attorney-General I received many very distressing letters from wives, parents or children of prisoners who were imprisoned on the other side of Australia from their homes and from their relatives. This is the problem that these Bills seek to alleviate. The Bills also provide for a transfer of prisoners from one State where they are serving a sentence to another State where they may be charged with some other offence but which cannot be disposed of until they have served the term of imprisonment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we turn this building into a Commonwealth gaol in 1988?

—From what I hear about its security, we might need to spend a lot of money to make it a more secure place. The problem, of course, is that a prisoner can have a charge hanging over his head for a long period whereas in fact he might be acquitted or given a concurrent sentence which he cannot take advantage of because he cannot be transferred for that purpose. That is another justification for this measure. As I have said, this legislation meets a real need which has existed for many years. This legislation has been very well discussed and developed in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Perhaps the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his reply might tell us whether the States are proceeding expeditiously with their own legislation so that the scheme can come into operation as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Although it is not dealt with in this legislation, debate on the legislation also raises the question of the situation of foreigners who are imprisoned in Australia and Australians who are imprisoned overseas. There have been no agreements between Australia and other countries to provide for the transfer of prisoners between Australia and other countries. One of the problems in negotiating with other countries has been the difficulty I have mentioned of the transfer of prisoners within Australia. As I understand it, it is intended that, once this matter has been cleaned up, it will lead to expediting discussions between Australia and other countries to enable agreements to be entered into, or with the object of agreements being entered into, to facilitate transfer of prisoners between Australia and countries with which agreements can be reached. Perhaps also in responding, the Attorney-General will give some up to date indication of the policy of his Government or himself in relation to this matter , whether any progress has been made and what progress he expects to be able to make in these discussions.

Discussions have been held with some countries but, as I have said, it would be interesting to know what stage has been reached and what forecast the Attorney- General has for the progress and development of this facility for Australians imprisoned overseas and for foreigners imprisoned in Australia. In fact, an even worse situation occurs in the international arena than occurs in Australia despite the great distances involved in Australia. Even greater difficulties are being experienced by foreigners in Australia or by Australians who are imprisoned overseas. The Opposition welcomes these Bills and hopes that they will become part and parcel of an Australia-wide scheme as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again indebted to the Opposition for its support of these measures, which I trust will now have an appropriately speedy passage. Would that the spirit of amity and co-operation that has just been demonstrated by Senator Durack on the last couple of Bills prevailed more often in matters of, perhaps, more controversial moment. It may be that we would get a bit more constructive business done if it did. Nonetheless, I am indebted to him for such limited support as he feels able to offer out of the goodness of his heart from time to time and this is manifestly a matter--
—It is justification for cause; it has nothing to do with the state of my heart.

—I will not pursue that matter any further. The state of Senator Durack's heart is something about which I could wax quite lyrical at the moment, given some of the performances that have gone on in the last week. Be that as it may, the transfer of prisoners issue is one that manifestly deserves bipartisan support. It is a sensible and long overdue measure. It was buried for too many dark years in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. It has emerged, along with a number of other matters, into the light of the renaissance that has overcome that body in the last eight months. I hope this will be one of a stream of reformist measures involving co-operation of the States that will come forward in this new, sensitive to the Federal system, Administration that now prevails at the Commonwealth level.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the case that a national system of transfer of prisoners will now be very shortly in place. Senator Durack asked me to indicate the state of play. The situation is that all States, including the Northern Territory, have passed the legislation.
