They have not yet proclaimed it pending the passing of necessary regulations which are being finally settled now on a uniform basis. The Commonwealth now comes into line with the passage of this legislation. It is anticipated that around March next year, not June as has been mentioned in one or two Press reports, is now the target date for the commencement of this long overdue and highly desirable scheme. It is desirable from the point of view of both humanitarian considerations, advancing rehabilitation of prisoners and the welfare of their families by having better access to them, and advancing the efficient administration of justice to the extent that it will be possible to transfer prisoners from place to place on a more convenient basis to enable matters to be heard together that should be heard together.

The overseas transfer of prisoners will not be affected by the present measure. Obviously it is of a similar character. The overseas transfer issue is, in many ways, a much more complex one because not only does it involve a domestic Australian dimension involving negotiations and agreements between the Commonwealth and the States as to the housing arrangements for the prisoners thus transferred back to Australia from overseas, but also, of course, it involves international negotiations on a bilateral basis, primarily, I guess, if the model of existing prisoner transfer agreements is to be followed, but possibly also with some scope for multilateral negotiations. The present state of play is that the Commonwealth is finalising a negotiating position in relation to the international side of it and continuing, actively, at an officer level, discussions with the States that have now been going on for some time on a fairly desultory basis as to a possible basis for an agreement. I am not confident enough about the timetable here to be able to give a prediction as to when we might be able to move towards the first implementation of overseas prisoner transfers-again for both humanitarian, more particularly, and administration of justice reasons-but certainly I am aiming to have some major strides taken in this respect next year, with hopefully something in place in respect of at least one or two countries by the end of next year. But, again, that is not a projection I make with any great spirit of optimism, given the complexity involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which countries?

—I would prefer not to be specific at this stage. It can be as relatively simple as New Zealand and as relatively complex as some of the South East Asian countries. I would not care, at this stage, to foreshadow with any more precision where we might be going. It is something that is very much on the agenda. Senator Durack will be pleased to know that I have not as yet assigned it a priority rating, so he will not be in a position in 12 months' time to chastise me for having failed to meet my target. Normally I live in hope that some rationality will prevail on these matters and make possible the implementation of things that have been properly discussed. We will see tomorrow , in the context of the National Crime Authority Bill, whether that hope has any foundation. I rather suspect on present indications that irrationality and abtuseness are likely to prevail. But hope springs eternal in the legislator's breast, as it has to if we are not to all have nervous breakdowns in this place. I look forward, accordingly, to some movement quite soon on the international prisoner transfer front. I repeat that I am indebted to Senator Durack for his amiable co-operation in this matter, if not in others, and wish the Bills an appropriately speedy passage into legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY BILL 1983NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I do not want to disappoint the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans), I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 and the National Crime Authority (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report, on or before 30 April 1984, as to whether the Bills fulfil effectively the objective of investigating organised crime and official corruption.

(2) That the Committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Bills and associated policy matters, and not receive any evidence, or conduct any investigation, relating to any individual person or body.
(3) That, for the purpose of the inquiry, the membership of the Committee be increased to 8 Senators.
(4) That one of the 2 additional members be nominated by the Leader of the Government and the other be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, in response to the debate on the previous Bill the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) referred to the spirit of amiable co-operation that he had received from the Opposition. I rise to indicate that the Opposition will be giving co-operation, but of a little less amiable kind, on this particular Bill, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 1983, which seeks to amend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975. (Quorum formed) Passage of this Bill will enable the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to give effect to principles agreed between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments relating to the day-to-day management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The declaration of such large parts of the Marine Park is a matter of gratification, I believe, to all Australians. Speaking as a Queensland senator, I think it is of particular gratification to Queenslanders. Therefore I am very sorry that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) gave the mean-minded speech that he did in the House of Representatives when he introduced this Bill. The Opposition in that alone took exception to the content of the Bill and it was debated at quite some length. When the Bill came to the Senate and was introduced by Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, he gave a speech identical to that given by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in the House of Representatives. No attempt was made to alter that speech. I intend here, in the Senate, to put a few things on record.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has been very actively involved in the Great Barrier Reef and the Marine Park. Reference is made in the Minister's second reading speech-and it has been made at various times-to the risk of oil drilling on the Great Barrier Reef. A number of honourable senators over the years-it has been eight years since the passage of the first Bill-have been extremely active on the subject of the Great Barrier Reef. They have been working, both here and in other places, to ensure that there would be no drilling for oil on it. A number of those senators were members of the previous Government. I admit that there were occasions on which I addressed questions on the subject to Ministers of my own Government. I hasten to add that not one of those questions was a dorothy dixer; they were all asked without notice. Queensland senators from the then Fraser Government were active in that area, as were other senators. I call to mind former Senator Chris Puplick and Senator Allan Missen as two who were particularly active in pressing the Fraser Government to ensure that there would be no oil drilling on the Barrier Reef. Of course, those assurances were given over and over again. There has been no drilling, and I believe there never will be. So this is a matter that is dear to the hearts of both Government and Opposition alike. The Minister, Mr Cohen, said this in his second reading speech :

It was a Labor Government which put in place the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act in 1975. Since coming to power in March this year the government has given life to the provisions of that Act. Zoning plans for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections of the Marine Park were tabled in May 1983 and I expect them to come into operation later this month.
I interpose that this speech was made on 2 November. He continued:

In August three further sections of the Marine Park were proclaimed, with proclamations for two further sections coming into effect on 30 October 1983. The addition of these sections means that this Government has increased from 14 per cent to 98.5 per cent the portion of the Great Barrier Reef region included in the Marine Park.

When the Minister made his statement to the Press on this subject he said it was with some 'pride' that he made the announcement. Well, I can understand that a Minister for the Environment would have some pride in making that announcement but, frankly, the Minister spoke not so much with pride as with conceit. I reiterate his words. He said that a Labor government brought the original Act into place. That is so, but it was passed with bipartisan support through both Houses of this Parliament. It was passed without opposition. We, then in opposition, in 1975, welcomed it and supported it. Then he said:
Since coming to power in March this year the Government has given life to the provisions of that Act.

Those words seek to give the impression that the Fraser Government did nothing; that the Act languished for eight years and that in fact only the Whitlam Government and the Hawke Government can claim any credit at all for the declaration of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I direct the attention of the Senate to a document which all honourable senators have and which is headed: ' Communique-Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council Meeting-Townsville 3 June 1983 '. This was issued jointly by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), the Premier of Queensland and the Queensland Minister for Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts. It states in part:
The seventh meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council held in Townsville today was attended by:
the Hon. Barry Cohen, Commonwealth Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, as Convenor;
the Hon. John Brown, Commonwealth Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism;
the Hon. Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Premier of Queensland; and
the Hon. Tony Elliott, Queensland Minister for Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts.

Council reviewed previous agreements between the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments for co-ordination of policies and co-operative arrangements in respect of the Great Barrier Reef, and determined that these agreements provided a sound basis for the protection and management of the Reef, land and waters in the Region.

I explain to honourable senators who have not followed the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council meetings that this means that the Commonwealth Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Commonwealth Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, at their first meeting as part of the Council in June this year, affirmed that all the work that had been done over years by the Fraser Government and the Queensland Government was, as the communique states, 'a sound basis for the protection and management of the Reef, land and waters in the Region.' The document goes on to state:

It was agreed that the principles of these agreements should be embodied into a document to be signed by Governments, and that they would apply to all sections of the Marine Park, subject to annual review of expenditure.. . . .
. . . Council noted that zoning plans for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass Sections were recently tabled in the Commonwealth Parliament and that these plans were expected to be in place later this year.
Council observed that recent State legislation-
that is Queensland legislation--
contained similar provisions to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and that an effective mechanism for comprehensive protection of tidal waters between high and low water mark was now available.
It was effective because of actions of the Queensland Government as well as the Commonwealth Government. The communique continued:

Council noted that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority had submitted reports on declaring further sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in the Far North, offshore Central and offshore Southern areas of the Great Barrier Reef Region and that declaration of such Sections, which the Council endorsed, would bring to 80 per cent the proportion of the Region within the Marine Park.
They are the sections to which the Minister refers in his speech and for which he takes full credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful, as Senator Messner says. It is very clear, when one follows the progress of negotiations on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, that the process is slow. It is slow for a very good reason. This has been outlined many times in the Senate. It has been outlined in Estimates committees, under examination. The Minister himself in his speech on 2 November outlined the procedures a government must go through to achieve declaration of a section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, including public consultations and an opportunity for public input and certain expert input. It is not a quick procedure. Very clearly, the present Minister for Home Affairs and Environment did not by 3 June 1983, three months after the election of the Hawke Government, manage to get 80 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef approved as a marine park. This procedure has taken years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of pride, as the Minister said, that he as Minister has had the opportunity to announce these things. I deplore the fact that he has been allowed to appear conceited. I know the Minister and I do not think he is a conceited person. I urge Mr Cohen, the next time his officers put a speech in his hands on any subject-particularly the officers who prepared this speech-to take an objective look at the words. If he examines the second reading speech and realises what words flowed out of his mouth he will see what sort of position he has put himself into. I also urge the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), who represents him in the Senate, to look at the response in the second reading debate in the House of Representatives. It might have been appropriate to have made some sort of alterations to the Minister's second reading speech in the House of Representatives before the identical speech, which is equally offensive , was made in the Senate. It is particularly offensive, as I indicated earlier, given the number of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber who have worked very hard to see this day come. I conclude the quotations from the communique by reading the last sentence. Referring to Commonwealth and State Ministers, it states:

Ministers expressed great satisfaction with the progress that has been made co- operatively in the establishment and management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and Queensland marine and national parks in the region.

In that communique the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism on 3 June 1983 congratulated the Premier of Queensland and the Queensland Minister for Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts, and those two Queensland Ministers mutually congratulated the two Commonwealth Ministers. That is the spirit in which these meetings have been undertaken. It does not help to get a spirit of co-operation between the Commonwealth and the State, particularly when the governments are of different political colours, if all they get for their trouble is the sort of thing we got from Mr Cohen on 2 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pretty low politics.

—It is very low politics and very crass politics. As I said, I would have to give the Minister the benefit of the doubt thus far. I do not think he is that sort of low politician. I think he should be a little more careful in future when a speech is put into his hands. I want to give some indication of the words the Minister allowed to come out in his name and out of his mouth in the second reading speech, just to illustrate what I have been saying. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: In August three further sections of the Marine Park were proclaimed,
Those three sections were referred to in the communique of June-
with proclamations for two further sections coming into effect on 30 October 1983.
Those proclamations were made just before this Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives.
The addition of these sections means that this Government-
I emphasise the words 'this Government'-
has increased from 14 per cent to 98.5 per cent the portion of the Great Barrier Reef region included in the Marine Park.

I put it in simple terms: If, when this Government came into office on 5 March 1983, only 14 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef had been included in the Marine Park it would not have been humanly possible-it certainly would not have been legally possible under its own Bill, introduced in 1975-to have proceeded from 14 per cent to 98.5 per cent in six or seven months. If the Government wants that spirit of 'amiable co-operation' that the Attorney-General referred to in an earlier speech, this is not the way to get it. The Minister said:
This was just dropped into the middle of a speech on the reef-
the Great Barrier Reef was inscribed on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation World Heritage List--

I am expecting Senator Messner to ask me who was in power in 1981. Of course, it was the Fraser Government. In 1981 the Fraser Government had the Great Barrier Reef inscribed on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation World Heritage List and in the Minister's words:
thereby bringing international recognition to the importance and uniqueness of this vast complex of coral reefs and their associated life forms.

There was not one gracious word in this entire speech about the long-reaching actions of the previous Federal Government. It takes some time to get areas listed on the World Heritage List. Years of work went into that, yet not one word was spoken about it in the Minister's second reading speech. It seems as though there was a vacuum between the passage of this Bill in 1975, as though there was no government from 1975 until 5 March 1983. I think credit should be given to the Fraser Government for its actions in relation to this particular initiative. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:

Mr Deputy Speaker, it gave me great pleasure earlier this week to bring to fruition the initiatives taken by a previous Labor Government some eight years ago when the then Minister for the Environment, Dr Cass, introduced the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Bill.

The Minister should be asked to explain why he misled the Parliament. If he had brought this matter to fruition singlehandedly, then he would have been a magician. We hear a little more of the anonymous government which existed between 1975 and 1983 further on in the Minister's speech:
The first section of the Marine Park, the Capricornia section, was proclaimed in 1979, followed by the Cairns and Cormorant pass sections in 1981.

No government proclaimed them, apparently, those sections were just proclaimed. In fact, those sections were proclaimed by the Fraser Government, after consultation and in agreement with the Queensland Government. The Minister's speech goes on:
Proclamations were announced on 31 August 1983 of three further sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, namely the far northern, central and southern sections . . .

The Townsville and in-shore southern sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park were declared by proclamation of the Governor-General on 30 October 1983. These declarations now complete the establishment of Australia's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

That is wonderful, we all welcome it, but I hope that when the history books are written they are not written by whoever wrote Mr Cohen's speech. I hope that credit is given where it is due. At the conclusion of his speech Mr Cohen said:
In concluding, I wish to emphasise that while the Government has made the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park a reality, the tremendous task of managing the Marine Park lies before us.

The Government did indeed make it a reality because it was government action which formally led to the declaration of these sections. There is no suggestion, of course, that anything different would have happened if the Fraser Government had still been in power this year. I hope that the Minister can take on the considerable task in the future of injecting a little more good will in relation to this matter of the Marine Park. It is very important that there be a spirit of co-operation between the Commonwealth Government, whatever its political colour, and the Queensland Government, whatever its political colour, on the subject of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

This Bill, for example, implements procedures which were agreed to by the Ministerial Council. It gives to the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service the responsibility of carrying out the day to day management of the Marine Park, subject to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. It gives to the Commonwealth a responsibility to fund 100 per cent of an initial capital works program required to establish management of the Marine Park on a sound basis, with all other capital and recurrent costs of the management of the park being shared equally between the two governments. It gives to the Commonwealth and Queensland the responsibility to meet in equal shares the recurrent costs for management of Queensland national and marine parks within the outer boundaries of the Marine Park. It requires Queensland to fund 100 per cent of the cost of capital works required in the management of the Queensland national and marine parks within the Marine Park. It gives to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority the responsibility of administration of the funds provided by the Commonwealth and Queensland for the purposes I have mentioned. It also charges that expenditure programs be developed by Queensland in consultation with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and approved by that Authority for submission to the Commonwealth and Queensland governments for consideration in their Budget context.

In conclusion, on behalf of the Opposition, I say that we warmly welcome the declaration of these sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. We acknowledge the enormous amount of work that has been done by a very large number of people over the years. The procedure, as I mentioned earlier, for declaring sections of the Marine Park has involved public participation. It has involved a lot of work by many faceless people, people in the Queensland National Parks Division and people in the Environment Division of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. They have worked together well and with good will. I am sure that I would be reiterating the sentiments of every Queenslander and undoubtedly every Australian when I say that it is my earnest hope that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park will become one of the great national parks of the world. The natural resources are certainly there, and the will is there. It will remain the responsibility of people in this place and outside for generations to come to make sure that we treasure that great heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government acknowledges and appreciates the support given to this legislation by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats. It is an unusual and very heartening experience to present to the Commonwealth Parliament a piece of legislation which has such universal support. I am pleased to note that, concerning the contents of the Bill and the machinery that has been set up to protect the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, there has been from the Opposition no criticism and no proposed amendments. It is a unanimous piece of legislation. It is all the more important for that reason. I endorse Senator Martin's remarks about the importance of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, not only to all Queenslanders, as she has pointed out, but also to all Australians and, I might add, because of its significance in the World Heritage List, to all people throughout the world who are committed to protecting the great wonders of the natural environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I must comment on Senator Martin's criticisms of my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). Senator Martin severely criticised him for failing to acknowledge in his second reading the contribution to the declaration of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park by successive Commonwealth governments and by the Government of Queensland. I draw her attention to the fact that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, being a modest man, as Senator Martin implied in her comments--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not say that.
—Senator Martin suggested that he was not a vain man.
—Not conceited.

—I am happy to endorse that assessment of my colleague. Mr Cohen acknowledged that he was wrong in overlooking the contribution of other governments to this important step. If Senator Martin would address her attention to Hansard for 3 November, she would see that my colleague Barry Cohen acknowledged in his second reading speech that this was a defect, and he apologised for that and went on to acknowledge that the Queensland Government, as well as successive Commonwealth Liberal governments and Liberal-National Party coalition governments have made their contributions over a period to the step which we are now all welcoming. So I hope that Senator Martin will accept from me, placing on record on behalf of the Government, our acknowledgement that many governments, including the Government of Queensland and the Fraser Government, made a contribution to protecting the wonders of the Great Barrier Reef and ensuring by the declaration of this park that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park will be safe from oil drilling or any other kinds of destructive commercial incursions for all time. I thank the Opposition for its support.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 6.16 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were advised orally by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) of the program for the rest of the day. We were also issued with a red sheet and the two do not correspond. The Attorney made reference, I think, to the Representation Bill or some referendum Bill. I would appreciate some clarification from the Government as to precisely what the order of business will be for the rest of the evening.

—As I understand it, there is ample business to keep us going for well into the night. There was some confusion at the tail end of the piece of paper that was thrust into my hand before the suspension for dinner to settle the order of business. The Representation Bill was an optional extra. It is not, in fact, proposed for this evening. The order of business is in accordance with the red sheet, the supplementary order of business, that has now been circulated, namely the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, followed by the States Grants (Petroleum Products) package, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) the radiocommunications Bills and finally, the Sex Discrimination Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is about to debate the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. This involves amendments to the whole co-operative companies and securities scheme, namely, the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, or takeover code, the Companies Act, the National Companies and Securities Commission Act, the Securities Industry Act and the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act. The legislation before us is of some magnitude and many of the amendments proposed in this legislation are of great significance for the administration of companies and securities law. This may be somewhat surprising in view of the relative recency of the co-operative scheme and the codes under it, particularly as the Companies Act itself came into existence only a short time ago. In fact, the whole scheme came into existence only in 1978 as a result of the agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Successively, parts of the legislative package such as the National Companies and Securities Commission Act itself, followed by the Companies ( Acquisition of Shares) Act and the Securities Industries Act came into existence . Finally, the Companies Act itself, the major piece of companies legislation, was brought into operation only about a year ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us, as I have said, makes amendments to a number of pieces of legislation. It may seem surprising that one would have about 100 amendments proposed to a package of such recent origin. The Senate should be aware that we are faced with the prospect of legislation of this magnitude and complexity virtually on an annual basis. I think that should be one of the first matters to which we give consideration. I hasten to say that the Opposition will not oppose this Bill, but I think that we in this Parliament have a duty to consider it. We are the only Parliament in Australia that now gives consideration to these laws under the co-operative scheme. As one would appreciate, the volume and complexity of the scheme itself is somewhat forbidding. The prospect of this Parliament having to consider on an annual basis very sizable amendments to it is a pretty daunting prospect. It raises very serious questions about ministerial responsibility and parliamentary control of the whole scheme. We in this Parliament should be giving some thought now and in the near future to the way in which we are to exert any control over this great bureaucratic problem with which we are faced.

I think the problem would apply whether it was a co-operative scheme, that is, a scheme arising under an agreement between the Federal and State governments, or a national scheme of the Parliament alone, administered purely by a Minister responsible solely to this Parliament. The fact of the matter is that we have this huge volume of legislation of a very technical kind. It is administered largely by technocrats, whether they be government officials, lawyers or accountants. Of course, many other people are particularly interested in it in the business community, for example, directors, bankers and so on. We should really look at ways and means of more satisfactorily dealing with this legislation and the way it seems to be going. Under the scheme we are faced with decisions that are made by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, which is comprised of the Federal and State Ministers responsible for various parts of the national companies and securities code. The council has the responsibility of determining what amendmens are to be made to the code and what amendments are to be proposed under the scheme by the Commonwealth Minister, who happens at the moment to be the Attorney-General, but it is not necessary that he be the responsible Minister. Indeed, until the abolition of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, the Minister holding that portfolio was the responsible Minister.

So we are, as I said, faced with the situation in which legislation of this volume and complexity is approved by that group of Ministers and, under the agreement, is presented to this Parliament, it being the only Parliament which maintains the function of passing, rejecting or amending the legislation. So the whole central basis of our parliamentary democracy and our responsibilities under that principle of government rests on us in this Parliament and, I venture to say, primarily upon this Senate. Quite frankly, I do not think we are equipped during this second reading debate, nor will we be later in the Committee of the Whole, to give proper attention to the complexity of this legislation and, as I said, apparently the volume of it.

Consideration of this legislation will be an annual exercise. Based upon the experience that I have had in trying to cope with it, I believe it will be necessary for this Senate either to set up a special committee to cope with it or to set up a standing committee of the Senate to do so, which I think would be a preferable course of action because it is very important that we do have a group of senators who will take an on-going interest in the matter and develop some expertise in dealing with the matters contained in this type of legislation . As I said, I just do not think we are in any way equipped to handle it under the ordinary procedures we have embarked upon at the present moment. However, I am not suggesting that this legislation should be referred to a committee; I am simply speaking as a result of the experience I have had in recent weeks in trying to cope with it.

I believe that we should be giving some thought to the way in which we will handle this matter in the future and the best proposal I can make in order that we may sensibly handle this type of legislation-I am not moving any motions in this respect at the moment, but we should consider it-is to have a Senate committee, either one of the standing committees or a special standing committee such as the one we set up in relation to the scrutiny of Bills, deal with the legislation. Senators themselves do not have the opportunity to go through legislation with the fine tooth comb necessary to determine matters, so the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills looks at legislation and accepts responsibility for it. I think that in the future a committee of that kind should be set up for this purpose.

The other problem that I see involves the various interest groups concerned. As I said earlier, those groups are varied and include lawyers, accountants, bankers and many other people who are vitally concerned in their day to day business activities with the provisions of the company code, the takeovers code and the Securities Industry Act, as well as the policies and activities of the National companies and Securities Commission. These things have such a vast impact on the economic life of people in the community that the people concerned would normally expect to have at least some of their members of parliament taking an on-going interest in these matters and developing expertise in dealing with the problems presented by this package of legislation.

I turn to the provisions of this Bill. As I said, it does not simply deal with a number of technical amendments of a routine kind; it proposes a number of quite important changes to the codes. For instance, as far as the takeovers code is concerned, it gives the National Companies and Securities Commission a much wider power in relation to what may be unacceptable conduct in relation to an acquisition, and it gives the power to declare unacceptable conduct before the threshold of 20 per cent is reached. That is certainly an important qualification and amendment to the takeovers code. It also makes major changes to the traditional company law in relation to the doctrine of ultra vires. It gives companies the powers of a natural person unless those are restricted in the memorandum and articles of association. So that is a major change as well.

As far as shareholders' remedies are concerned, if a shareholder alleges that a company's affairs are being conducted in an oppressive manner there are only limited remedies under existing law, but under the provisions of this Bill a shareholder or the NCSC may apply to the Supreme Court for an order that a company be wound up or any other order it considers appropriate in the circumstances. The ground is that the affairs of the company are being conducted in a manner that is oppressive, unfairly prejudicial to or discriminatory against a member or members, or in a manner contrary to the interests of the members as a whole. I believe that is a very valuable and important amendment to the existing legislation.

The Bill also contains amendments in relation to the obligation of directors in relation to their statements and reports. For instance, directors will be obliged to attach to the accounts prior to the auditor's statement a statement as to whether the accounts reflect a true and accurate picture of the company's position at the time of the annual meeting. They have to be updated to reflect the changed circumstances since the lodgment of such accounts. Directors will be obliged to obtain a review of the operations of the company, expected results of those operations and so on. There were in the exposure draft of this legislation some additional obligations of directors which met with a great deal of criticism, and I am pleased to say that the system as we have it is that seemingly the body with ultimate control, the Ministerial Council, has taken note of that and has modified the obligations in a way which now seems to be, as far as I can ascertain, agreeable to the critics of those original proposals.

The legislation contains a number of other major changes which I do not propose to cover, except that which relates to accounting standards. The Bill does give legislative effect to proposals which have been in the system for some time. Those who have been taking a close interest in the matter will be aware of the proposal to establish an Accounting Standards Review Board which will have, as this legislation provides, the obligation of laying down accounting standards for the preparation of profit and loss accounts, balance sheets, group accounts and so on. In future these must be prepared in accordance with the standards laid down by that board, with the qualification that directors may prepare accounts in a form different from those standards if they certify that compliance with those standards would not give a fair and true view of the company's position.

Although that is a desirable course of action, I think the accounting profession may have some reservations about the notion of an Accounting Standards Review Board and a great deal depends upon the composition of that Board. I notice that in a submission made to the National Companies and Securities Commission in August last year the accountants indicated a belief that there should be legislative backing for accounting standards. They submitted that such backing would be most simply and economically achieved by regulations which endorsed standards produced by the accounting profession through its existing standards board. They said that a bureaucratic step of introducing a separate accounting standards review board would be justified only if it were considered to be essential towards achieving such legislative backing . Obviously, the judgment has been made by the National Companies and Securities Commission and by the Ministerial Council that it is desirable or necessary to set up this Board.

What is a matter of great concern-it ought to be a matter of great concern to the Senate-is the way in which the Board is being set up. This legislation certainly gives the legislative backing to the accounting standards, but it does not set up the Board. There is nothing in this legislation which actually sets up the Board. I thought we would have had some legislation to set up the Board. I thought it would be set up in this Bill or in separate legislation but that has not been done. This Board will not be a statutory board. It is to be set up by the Ministerial Council. The accounting standards that are to be determined by that Board are to be disallowable only by the Ministerial Council. If this Parliament is prepared to give an outside body-namely, this Ministerial Council- those sorts of powers, we might as well abdicate our role in this area completely. We should be realistic about the situation and simply say: 'Well, we will abdicate all legislative responsibility for this exercise. We will hand the matter over to the Ministerial Council and we will make no pretence that there is anything like parliamentary control over this whole scheme'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have it already with stock exchanges. What is the matter with you?
—It is a fair point, though.

—Historically, stock exchanges have been self-regulating bodies. It may well be necessary and desirable to have more parliamentary control over other aspects of this whole scheme. But I am dealing with a new proposal which has been brought forward to this Parliament in regard to the development of the scheme. I am saying that we should not allow parliamentary control and responsibility regarding this scheme to be further whittled away. What bothers me is that it has gone so far already that nobody sees the Parliament as exercising any control. It has already gone so far that those who are concerned with the legislation simply deal with officials, the NCSC or ultimately the Ministerial Council. We are being asked as a Parliament simply to rubber stamp this whole exercise. If that is what the Parliament wants, so be it, but let us be perfectly clear about it. Let us not go through the pretence which exists. This is the only Parliament which now has any control over this matter. I think that is the sensible part of the scheme. But as we are the only Parliament that is left with any control over the matter I believe it is our responsibility to take a close interest in what is done by all those who are part and parcel of the scheme, particularly the Ministerial Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I have circulated some amendments regarding the proposed Accounting Standards Review Board. I believe the standards at least should be tabled and should be subject to disallowance in the Parliament rather than by the Ministerial Council . As I said, this Board is not to be a statutory body. We propose that there should be a reporting by that body, as there would be in accordance with the reporting rules that are followed by statutory authorities. I do not propose to go further into the details of this scheme. A number of criticisms have been made about the details of it. I believe, in view of the present state of organisation and the inadequacy of parliamentary control regarding this matter, that it would be futile to seek to move detailed amendments to the scheme at this stage.

I hope that in the future the Senate will establish better institutions whereby meaningful discussion of amendments, even though they may be of a more technical character, will be possible in this chamber. At this stage I am concerned simply that we, as senators, should assert the ultimate responsibility that we have regarding this important new development of the Accounting Standards Review Board. We should at least assert our right to review those standards. We ought to be advised by that Accounting Standards Review Board of its activities on an annual basis. Apart from that, the Opposition does not propose to go into any detailed examination of the provisions. As I said, I hope this will be the last time the Parliament will review this matter in this very broad and general way. I hope that in the future we will develop some better way of handling the issue. At present the Opposition is prepared to give approval to the Ministerial Council's decisions in this regard, subject to the amendments that I have indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. We on this side of the House are indebted to the speech on this topic by my distinguished senior colleague Senator Durack, who has just resumed his seat. Senator Durack drew our attention to some very serious difficulties with this law, particulatly in relation to the way in which this Parliament operates in regard to it. I think we all know enough of the history of this legislation-it goes back to the time of the Whitlam Government-to understand its genesis and evolution to its present form. Basically, the parent legislation established a Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities which embraces the States. This Council considers amendments and various issues relating to company law. The Council, in effect, recommends changes to the law which more or less-as Senator Durack has pointed out-come to this Parliament to receive a rubber stamp. It is that issue about which I think we on this side of the House are concerned. The amendments are, of course, increasing in number and in complexity. While this occurs legislation will become increasingly difficult to administer and will be incapable of being changed by the Parliament of which we are members.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe we all have to have due regard to that issue. It is a matter which the Government ought to be considering in the course of its review of companies and securities law. I wish to mention several matters which illustrate the difficulties which exist in relation to this law. I note from the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that a Companies and Securities Law Review Committee and an accounting Standards Review Board will be established. Senator Durack has already drawn our attention to the need for that Committee. He also drew our attention to the very important point of the composition of that Committe. We should give very careful consideration to the people who will comprise that Committee and will actually undertake the review of the law. I think it is becoming increasingly obvious that we need practical people, people who have had a very long-standing involvement in the company law area. I am speaking not only of laywers, of course, but also of accountants and other practical people who deal in this area on a day to day business basis and who must be consulted widely in the course of the review. I hope that the Government will move very quickly and strongly to establish that Review Committee and get it under way as soon as possible so that we can get a better and, if one likes, comprehensive review of the law.

I should like to mention a few matters which this legislation seeks to amend. I refer to things which appear not to be part of any comprehensive review but rather have to be dealt with on a one-off basis and really are very difficult to piece together in terms of a comprehensive pattern in the law. The first matter to which I wish to refer is the amendment with regard to ultra vires. The Bill seeks to remove the need for a company to establish special objectives, a requirement which has existed for many many years, in fact probably well over 200 years. Probably that principle is anachronistic and it is time it was removed. However, having removed it and virtually attributed the rights of a natural person to an artificial corporation, we have to consider what are those rights and what are the limitations that should be imposed upon them in the special circumstances of corporations as they affect the directors, shareholders , creditors and other persons who are directly connected with corporations. For that reason I am a little concerned about this move, although on the whole I believe it is a good step and represents an updating of principles. However, the point has to be made that this kind of one off aproach to a reform, so-called, of company law perhaps introduces into the law other anomalies, other difficulties, other problems which have not been properly thought through and which I think require a most comprehensive approach.

The Minister in his second reading speech drew attention to the question of the lodgment of accounts by exempt proprietary companies. Perhaps this illustrates the kind of point I am trying to make. Indeed, I think the Attorney-General, when in opposition, acknowledged that there is a very distinct difference in the nature of the operations of exempt proprietary companies and those of public companies, which are controlled and regulated by very complex laws of the type we are now debating and, of course, by other legislation with regard to the National Companies and Securities Commission. The point here, of course, is that exempt proprietary companies in the main are organised to control the affairs of relatively small business undertakings, and mainly family operations. Yet, under the present law the requirements for lodging documents, compliance with accounting standards, the preparation of balance sheets and profit and loss accounts and other documentation are on the same basis as those in respect of major corporations with very significant assets. I think the time has come for us to consider that there is a very significant difference in the operations of those two different types of companies. Smaller operations simply do not have the kind of impact in the economy that a major corporation does, yet the smaller operations are loaded with considerable costs, difficulties and practical problems that arise directly out of the need to comply with the general law, which for them has very little application.

I think we need to think through the mode of such an exempt proprietary company , the style in which it is created, the kind of legal entity it represents, to see whether we can design a better system of operation in the community so that companies of this type are more effective, more efficient and contribute more to the community well-being. I think the Committee which is to be established by the Government to undertake the review ought to consider very carefully the basic question of the operation of relatively small companies. I think we can make the point that probably as many as 90 per cent of all corporations that are registered with the various corporate affairs commissions throughout the States are in the exempt proprietary company category. Yet they are probably representative of a very small part of the overall economy of Australia.

I should like to mention one or two other matters in relation to exempt proprietary companies. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the requirement to lodge accounts with the National Companies and Securities Commission, which may or may not be audited. Under the present law, there is no need to lodge financial statements with that body. The question arises as to whether or not accounts should be lodged and audited. I think this matter is referred to in the Minister's second reading speech. He made the point in the course of his remarks that the proposal to have accounts lodged with the NCSC and audited was brought forward by the Australian Society of Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia. I find that a very surprising statement. I do not seek to question the Minister's veracity, but I would like him to amplify whether or not that is so and whether or not he believes that it is a reasonable proposition. Perhaps he could give us his view as to whether or not he will be taking this matter to the Review Committee in order to obtain further opinions and submissions from the various interested bodies. I am fairly certain that bodies such as chambers of commerce and those which represent business interests as distinct from accounting interests would be particularly interested in this matter. I think this relates back to the earlier point I made that the very nature of the corporate entity as it applies to the relatively smaller proprietary companies is a question which should be examined very closely.

Senator Durack drew our attention, very properly, to the question of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and the capacity of this Parliament to amend laws that are proposed by that Council from time to time. He pointed out that we are virtually a rubber stamp in this area. I think the time has come for the Parliament to assert itself in this regard, to prove the capacity of the Council to be flexible in cases where need is demonstrated by the Parliament for the law to be amended. I am not proposing any major point here, I am merely pointing up the issue as being one of very great and increasing concern in the community. It is a matter which we as a Parliament ought to consider very deeply. I think it is something which does require very careful thought on the part of the Government when it considers further amendments. Perhaps it is not a matter which ought to be taken to the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. This is now proposed in the legislation.

I turn very briefly to one area which is encompassed by these amendments. It does highlight the need for a very specific review of the individual clauses and perhaps points up the lack of capacity of this Parliament to do much about it, given the nature of the arrangements with the States through the Ministerial Council. I will refer to the clauses of the Bill, starting at proposed new section 324A which relates to the affairs of receivers. To point up some of the more clear and obvious absurdities of these amendments, I direct attention to proposed new section 324A which sets out certain fairly standard powers which are said to be subject to any provisions of the court order under which a receiver is appointed or any instrument or debenture under which he was appointed in respect of a particular receivership. Surprisingly, proposed new section 324A (q) allows a receiver to appoint an agent to do any business that the receiver is unable to do or that can more conveniently be done by an agent. In fact previous common law cases and case law which have emanated from the courts have proven that a receiver can delegate only matters of a routine or ministerial nature. In one stroke the law is providing a far wider power of delegation to a receiver in a very difficult and fiduciary situation, which I do not think has had proper exposure in the literature, or among the accounting bodies or the various legal authorities.

I move now to the next proposed new section, 324B which deals with the duties of the receiver in respect of bank accounts and provides that failure to comply with that section will constitute an offence. Thus if a receiver fails to bank money within three business days of receiving it he will be guilty of an offence , but the section says nothing about the requirements of a receiver to enter and take possession of other assets of a corporation. We have the rather ludicrous situation wherein a receiver is required under penalty to lodge cash in a bank account and will suffer a penalty if he fails to do so. But if he fails to obtain the key to the yard in which the company's stock or its plant is located and if he fails to establish his possession of those goods, he is scot free; he is not under any charge, according to this law.

I think this kind of inconsistency reveals a situation which is starting to develop in the law following the arrangements which we have. It is the kind of issue which needs a means by which we can quickly attend to amendments to the law where necessary. As I pointed put earlier, it does cut across the point about liberalisation of a receiver's position in operating through an agent. Consequently, there appears to me to be an inconsistent approach in this area. I think that Senator Durack's point in regard to a Senate committee having power to examine these questions and to recommend changes which can be tested is a very worthwhile one and I support it very heavily.

On the question of receivers, proposed new section 324C mirrors the very heavy responsibility which is imposed on liquidators under section 418 of the Companies Act. It requires amongst other things that a receiver report to the Commission any apparent negligence, default, breach of duty, or breach of trust on the part of a person who has taken part in the formation, promotion, administration, management or winding up of the company. I make the point that that refers to a receiver. It probably is not a totally unfair requirement, but the fact that requires a receiver, whose duty it is to secure the repayment of his client's debt, to spend time and his client's money in carrying out a reporting function which has nothing to do with his client, and which should be undertaken by a liquidator at a later phase of the company's life, appears to be a rather inconsistent approach.

If the receiver fails to do his duty he will no doubt suffer the consequences imposed by the penalty sections in this regard, one which relates to the prosecution of delinquent officers, and proposed section 324E which refers to the supervision of receivers. So I think these areas do cause considerable concern to some people who are responsible for the practical administration of the law in the economy and who in fact do experience these difficulties which I have highlighted. I think it demonstrates the point that we need a means by which we can readily obtain change in this law without the massive requirements which are currently before us.

The final thing I wish to say relates to the Accounting Standards Review Board. Again I endorse the remarks of Senator Durack in this regard that there would appear to be some need for the establishment of such a board. By the same token a means is also required by which there can be rapid amendment of the standards which of necessity have to be amended from time to time as circumstances change. One only has to consider the economic circumstances as they have affected corporations over the last 10 years to understand the considerable changes which have arisen in the accounts of companies as a result of rapid inflation, rapid deflation, heavy recession, the demands upon the resources of companies arising from redundancy payments and matters of that kind. These are not properly accounted for under the current arrangements.

For that reason I believe that these amendments need to be effected in a ready, efficient and effective manner in order to maintain a very appropriate set of accounting standards for corporations generally. The establishment of the Review Board is, as Senator Durack has pointed out, to be undertaken by the Ministerial Council. Again it draws our attention to a fundamental issue which we discussed earlier. The honourable senator's solution through an amendment which has been proposed is indeed a worthwhile one. It demands the support of all honourable senators because it requires that any changes to accounting standards which have been determined by the Board be laid on the table in this Parliament and be debated here and that appropriate action be taken to amend them where required. I believe that is a very worthwhile suggestion and I commend the proposed amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the general thrust of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. I am very happy to see that there is general support for the Bill not just from all parties in this Parliament but also from other very vital bodies such as the stock exchanges, the accounting bodies and others which will be affected by the changes that this Bill will bring about. I want to speak only briefly about two or three aspects of the Bill because the debate has covered the main points. There is general unanimity on both the need for the Bill and the direction that the Bill is taking.

SPEECH.PARA: One factor that is vital is that the Bill adds to the responsibilities of directors. This has been an obvious need and one which has probably taken a lot of negotiating to achieve because there is a recognition of the need but there has not been general agreement as to the means of overcoming the problem of directors being able to avoid their responsibilities. It will also make it easier to trace beneficial ownership of shares, something which has become quite vital particularly, as we have seen, over the last 12 to 18 months.

Very importantly, the Bill advances the protection for minority shareholders. The gains that minority shareholders make in this legislation are considerable. One in particular which I think is a key is that a minority shareholder will no longer need to show detriment to his financial interests as a shareholder to obtain remedies for actions taken by the directors. I think that will change considerably the effects of decisions taken by directors which act to the detriment of minority shareholders. The foundation is here for the reform of accounting standards. That is quite significant. A body is established and the Accounting Standards Review Board will have a massive responsibility, but I believe that it will adopt that responsibility with a great deal of good will because of the recognition throughout the community of the need to review and reform the Australian accounting standards.

That brings us to the controversial point; that is, the proposed amendment as to how these accounting standards will be handled. It seems to me that the Government has come to this Parliament with an agreement reached between all of the Ministers from all of the States and the Commonwealth Government and, in bringing this agreement forward in legislative form, is putting down a formula which has been considered, has been tossed around, amended and adapted to suit the needs of all of the States and this Government and, finally, has come up with an acceptable formula. The amendment which the Liberal Party of Australia is planning to put forward in fact would have the benefit of giving the ultimate responsibility for any changes to this Parliament or, to be fair, to a parliament. I do not think that if it were practicable the Liberal Party would say that it needs to be just to this Parliament. If it were practicable it could even be possible for it to go to all of the parliaments but that is obviously not feasible and not acceptable and therefore it is not being proposed.

The factor that we need to take into account is the unwillingness of the Senate , as proposed by the Liberal Party, to delegate powers which are in effect legislative or regulation changes with serious penalties and consequences. I can accept that there is a very real hazard in the delegation of such powers to a ministerial committee which has no responsiblity to any parliament in this country. Therefore, there is a very persuasive argument to support the amendment being put forward by the Opposition.

The other side of that coin, though, is that we have the problem that the Ministers have reached agreement. This legislation is the result of that agreement and this amendment, desirable from some points of view though it may be, literally throws that agreement out of the window. The effect of it is that it goes back to the drawing board and the whole exercise starts again. If that were to happen, the States would, in my opinion, be quite entitled to demand similar powers to the powers that we wish to take unto ourselves. The result of that, as I indicated earlier, would be utter chaos because there is no way that we could ever get seven States to agree to the more controversial accounting standards that may come forward. I could see difficulties even if we did ultimately get agreement in that, if we wanted to make changes in a reasonable time, it would be impracticable to do so because of the nature and the way in which the various parliaments around this country work.

In my opinion we have in this legislation what amounts to an agreed federal system-a system, which is the result of discussion and ultimately consensus, ultimately unanimous approval, a system of accountability to a ministerial council as distinct from accountability to a parliament. I still wait to hear further debate here and the Australian Democrats at this stage are still willing to listen to the arguments pro and anti the legislation. But at the moment, rather than throw out the baby with the bath water, my inclination is to suggest that we should endeavour to make the system as proposed in the Bill work and to keep a very close eye on the way it is working. Admittedly, it will not be easy to have a review implemented once the legislation goes through; I acknowledge that. But we should give it the opportunity to work, rather than ensure that there is no possibility of it working because of the sheer impracticality of a system which would not be acceptable to the other States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies and Securities Legislation ( Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 is a most important Bill and I wish to join in this second reading debate. It includes many major revisions which in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) are called reforms to the Australian national companies and securities legislative scheme. I will commence with a few general comments. I am pleased that the Bill has had public exposure through the release of an exposure draft. I note that the Attorney has received in excess of 100 submissions, but I regret that the Parliament is in the dark about those submissions. We do not know how many have been taken up. We do not know what submissions have not been taken up. I understand that the Attorney-General is not prepared to give us access to those submissions and I find that surprising because it is not as if this is a government Bill in the normal sense; it is a Bill that has actually come to this Parliament from the--
—Have you sought access?
—We have sought access and been told that it is not available.
—Not by me, you haven't been told.
—By your Department.
—Come to me, for God's sake.
—We thought that your Department would provide it.
—Did you ask for the departmental briefing?

—What I am submitting to the Senate is that it is important that the Parliament has access to submissions in legislation of this kind. What I was going to say is that it is not a government Bill in the normal sense; it is a Bill that has come from a ministerial council and presumably this Federal Government would like to have the greatest input of the Senate as possible. The form of public exposure that the Bill therefore had is not a satifactory form. I commend the suggestion made by Senator Durack that in future a Bill of this type -we expect more Bills in the future-go to a Senate standing committee for examination and report. I regret that this Bill has not gone through that process. For all we know submissions may have related to one aspect which the Government has rejected on ideological grounds. Of course, the Minister will say : 'But it has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities'. But the Minister knows that, being an amendment, it need be approved by simply a majority of that Council. I do not know whether it was approved by simply a majority or whether it was approved unanimously. Unfortunately, in this country at the moment there is a majority of Labor governments, therefore we could find submissions rejected on purely ideological grounds.
—Will you allow me to interject and say that they were all unanimous in this instance.

—I am pleased to hear that on this occasion, they were all unanimous. I regret that that was not stated in the Minister's second reading speech. I note from the Minister's speech that the Ministerial Council is moving to the establishment of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. It will receive its references from the Ministerial Council and report to the Council. According to the Attorney-General, it will enable examination of fundamental issues of company law in a systematic fashion. But again, we do not know how it will operate. Will it call for submissions? Will it hold public hearings? Will it act purely as a secretariat for the Ministerial Council? Regrettably, we do not know the answers to these questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise these questions because the Attorney-General is, I understand, considering giving the Australian Law Reform Commission a reference on corporate insolvency. I believe that law relating to corporate insolvency is in need of reform. But why not give it to the new Companies and Securities Law Review Committee, in which case at least the States would be contributing to the cost of the review? I have read that the new Committee might be asked to look at such difficult questions as the minimum paid up capital for companies. In many ways that is a subject akin to insolvency and, again, clearly a subject requiring attention. I read also that it will look to the use or abuse of $2 companies. We have all read in recent reports, such as the Costigan report-the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-the McCabe-Lafranchi 'Report of Inspectors Appointed to Investigate the Particular Affairs of Navillus Pty Ltd and 922 Other Companies' and other reports on the use of such companies in a taxation evasion and white collar crime. So clearly this review committee will be involved in deep conceptual questions really going to the history of corporate law and the functions of companies. In fact, its charter is stated to be: 'To carry out research into and advise on law reform in relation to the tax legislation and regulations'. So why cannot the questions of corporate insolvency go to that Committee.

I read also that the Attorney-General has set up a working party to review the workings of the insider trading provisions of the Securities Industry Act. Why was it necessary for another body to be created for that purpose? What of the National Companies and Securities Commission? Its functions include power to make recommendations to the Ministerial Council for new laws or changes to existing laws. It may hold hearings for the performance of such functions. Again , its responsibility is for the entire area of policy as well as administration in respect of company law-of course, subject to directions of the Ministerial Council. I hope that when the Minister replies in due course he can inform the Senate on these matters.

I want to look specifically at some of the so-called reforms that have been dealt with in the Bill, some of which I applaud and some of which give me reason for considerable concern. The first matter I wanted to look at has been mentioned. It relates to amendments concerning the objects and powers of companies. These amendments will provide that it will be optional for companies to have stated objects. Unless otherwise provided in the memorandum or articles, a company is to have the powers of a natural person. The theory of this is to avoid the danger of the doctrine of ultra vires. The practice has grown up to avoid the danger of the doctrine of ultra vires to draw the memorandum with a long list of objects, more often becoming what Sir Owen Dixon once called:
A jumble of objects assembled from former precedents with a seeming disregard for symmetry, coherence and at times even orthography and correct transcription.

Of course, it includes wide powers for implementation of such objects. Activity in excess of such powers is void. But by section 68 of the existing code, the doctrine has already, in part, been abolished. That section provides:
No act of a company . . . is invalid by reason only of the fact that the company was without capacity or power to do such act.

So the purpose of that section is to provide protection to a third party dealing with a company outside its powers. The doctrine has been retained for internal purposes. It provides that shareholders and directors may restrain an ultra vires act or recover loss from offices resulting from action taken that has been ultra vires or petition for winding up if the company is acting ultra vires. But such internal remedies are, by this Bill, abolished with the repeal of section 68. If the memorandum and articles do not restrict objects or powers, shareholders and debenture holders know that is the basis of their investment or lending. But if the memorandum and articles do restrict, it appears that such remedies have been lost. In lieu, I know it is stated that the officer of a company commits an offence if he knowingly allows the company so to act. But that may not help shareholders or debenture holders. As I say, it appears that they have lost a remedy. I do not know whether this has been done on purpose, but irrespective of whether it has, I hope that we will hear from the Minister in due course as to whether that is so. Certainly it causes me concern.

The second area I wanted to look at is that part which deals with remedies for shareholders in cases of oppression. The current section 320 offers remedy to shareholders claiming that the affairs of the company are being conducted in a manner oppressive to certain shareholders, or that directors have acted in a manner unfair or unjust to one of the shareholders, or that the directors have acted in their own interests or not in the interests of the members as a whole. The section provides certain remedies. It provides remedies including that the company might be wound up, an order might be made for regulating the conduct of the company's affairs in future, an order might be made for the purchase of any share of any member and an order might be made for the purchase of shares by the company together with the necessary reduction in capital. The predecessor to that section was section 186 of the uniform Companies Act. The purpose has been to offer an alternative to the winding up provisions that are provided by section 211, that allow a company to be wound up on the just and equitable grounds. That is very difficult to substantiate in a court and is a very limited remedy. We can all understand the purposes of oppression provisions.

The courts have accepted the interpretation of oppressive as 'burdensome, harsh and wrongful'. The amendments purport to pick up some of the recommendations of the company law committee chaired by Lord Jenkins, which reported on section 210 , the English equivalent of our former section 186. It is true that, for obvious reasons, the courts have been fairly restrictive in their interpretation of section 186. These amendments first expand the categories of conduct which would give rise to a remedy. For example, it is no longer necessary to show detriment to financial interests. It would be sufficient to show harm to interests as a director or employee. That is quite a dramatic expansion. It is an expansion that really should be considered by the Parliament, because traditionally what the courts have looked to has been limited financial interests.

It is said by some that what is happening in fact is that directors and employees are being given an unnecessary second bite of the cherry. If an employee has his own rights under his contract of employment, why is it necessary to expand the provisions in this way? Secondly, the remedies will be allowed in respect of isolated acts. Formerly it was necessary that there be a course of conduct. Has it in fact been shown that such an expansion is necessary ? Thirdly-and I cannot find this in the report of Lord Jenkins-it applies also to anticipated conduct. That is quite a dramatic extension and I believe it should be justified. Fourthly, it is extended to cover cases where it is unfairly prejudicial or unfairly discriminatory as against simply oppressive. It is said that this is to extend the provision beyond illegality. But the interpretation of 'oppressive' has not been so limited. If one looks at the judgment in the Tivoli Freeholds case in Victoria in 1971 that is made quite apparent. It also appears to be the view of Lord Jenkins, who talked about conduct being simply of a reprehensible nature, which has familiar connotations in another area. So I wonder about the justification for these extensions.

I want to look briefly at the part dealing with accounting standards. It states that directors shall ensure that accounts are made out in accordance with applicable approved accounting standards. Approved accounting standards will be gazetted. They will basically be standards approved by the new Accounting Standards Review Board which is commencing operations at the beginning of next year. In general I believe that is a good reform, but I totally endorse the comments that were made by Senator Durack as to the wisdom of the standards receiving the normal parliamentary scrutiny. I must admit that I am quite astonished by the attitude of the Australian Democrats to this matter because their representative appeared to say that there is a responsibility and a need properly to scrutinise the provisions of this Act. Here is the classic case where provisions can come before the Parliament in the normal way that other prescribed provisions come before this Parliament for scrutiny yet the Australian Democrats are not prepared to support an amendment to have that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot amend this legislation. Whom are you trying to kid? You cannot amend this legislation without being in breach of the agreement. That is the whole problem with this legislation.
—It is interesting that the Attorney-General says that we cannot amend this legislation.
—I have said it in opposition; I say it in government.

—I want to make some comment on that subject a little later. I am sure that Senator Peter Rae is also going to pick up that subject enthusiastically in his contribution. The next part I want to look at briefly also is that dealing with directors' statements. Currently directors must attach a statement to the effect that the accounts reflect a true and fair view at the end of the financial year and that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the company is able to pay its debts as and when they fall due. That is of some value as far as it goes. But now directors will have to have regard to circumstances which have arisen and information which has become available since the end of the financial year. I believe that is an excellent reform. It is a difficulty that I have come across personally in professional practice and it appears to me to be open to abuse, and has been open to abuse. I am pleased to see that reform.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly I am pleased to see the part that deals with directors' reports. Section 280 of the Companies Act provides that directors must present to the annual general meeting a report which must cover matters contained in the Act. That report supplements the accounts. It becomes the public information upon which shareholders, creditors et cetera can assess the performance of the company.
