There has been very fair criticism that this list of prescribed statements and information is often not particularly helpful. The effect of this amendment largely is that it will become necessary for the report to contain a review of the operations of the company and the results of those operations. Directors will have to refer to likely developments in the operations and expected results of those operations in subsequent financial years. Again I think this is an excellent reform as far as it goes. But proposed new section 270 (3) provides that companies will not be required to disclose information which would, in the opinion of the directors, be prejudicial to the interests of the company. All they need to say is that they have not provided all the information. Now, I am not sure what that means, but what is obvious is that it makes a mockery of the whole of those provisions which, as I indicated, I thought were worthwhile reforms. I look forward to the explanation of the Attorney-General of that subsequent sub-section.

I will touch upon that part dealing with tracing beneficial interests in shares . Provisions contained in clause 76 of the Bill will put directors and shareholders in a better position to ascertain the identity of the persons whose voting power may affect the company's operation. Basically we are looking at listed public companies and the purpose is to complement the substantial shareholders disclosure provisions. So we are really looking at shareholders with less than 10 per cent. But again, although I can understand the merit of the provision, I am stunned in this instance by the powers that are given to the court. For example, if an answer comes in that information does not lie within the knowledge of the party receiving the notice, the court may vest the shares of the company in the corporation. I cannot understand why such draconian powers for the court are necessary in this regard. Also I am concerned that the whole series of provisions under that head does not get at second and third hand owners of shares and therefore may be deficient in that regard.

I want also to touch upon the duties and powers of receivers. This aspect was mentioned by Senator Messner in his contribution. I do not want to repeat the comments he made, but there are some additional points that I shall make. This is an absolutely critical part of the Bill. Unfortunately it gets but three lines in the Minister's second reading speech. Why could it not be referred also to this investigation into corporate insolvency to which, of course, it is related? It would have been a sound idea, I believe, to have the inquiry encompass this also. The Companies Act does not purport to provide a code for determining the power and duties of receivers or the manner in which their responsibility is to be supervised. However, we are told that the Government received representations that some matters should be set out in statutory form. Now, what representations did it receive? What did it accept and what did it reject? We do not know. The only representations I have seen from receivers suggest that the whole idea is unwise, and these are from highly reputable receivers and accounting organisations. What we have before us is a partial code . It is supposed to codify the existing law but, as Senator Messner indicated very accurately, it in fact in some areas goes considerably beyond existing law.

I would like briefly to look at a few of the specific provisions under this subject. Proposed section 324B, concerning duties with respect to bank accounts and accounting records, provides that any director, creditor or member of a corporation may inspect records. Is that feasible in large receiverships? Can it not therefore be used by a competitor when a company under receivership seeks again to establish its market? Proposed section 324A relates to the powers of a receiver. Should the receiver have the power to carry on the business of the corporation-this is mentioned in placitum (h) of that proposed section-if the security crystallises and the net should fall over the assets and not over the substratum of the company, thus making it a slave of the appointer? Placitum (n) refers to the power to use a seal of the corporation. Should not that be restricted to realisation of assets?

Proposed section 324E concerns the supervision of receivers. Complaint may be made to the court by any person with respect to the conduct of a receiver. Mr Deputy President, I am interested to hear from the Minister who 'any person' is. Is not this again a conflict with the role of receiver, as Senator Messner mentioned under another one of the sub-clauses of this part? Proposed new section 324E says that the court or commission may inquire and the court may take such action as it sees fit. What does that mean? Take action for the benefit of whom? Again it appears to be boundless. The Commission may report misfeasance, neglect or omission. I know that some receivers are concerned that this may be interpreted to include errors of judgment. Can we receive assurances in that regard? The Commission may order an inquiry if it decides that the receiver has not faithfully performed his duties or observed requirements of instruments under which he was appointed. Who is the Commission to decide if the receiver has been faithful? It is just another example of the encroaching bureaucracy and I look forward to the Attorney-General's attitude to that provision.

Proposed new section 324D deals with the prosecution of delinquent officers. It forces officers in a company to give assistance in connection with a prosecution -whatever assistance means in that regard, we do not know-at a penalty of $10, 000 or imprisonment for two years. I wonder what is wrong with the existing subpoena provisions. I query whether the reservation against self-incrimination is sufficient. There is an obligation to give evidence. The Bill says that it may not be used directly in a prosecution, but no doubt it would be valuable in providing leads to other evidence upon which to base a prosecution. It certainly is a watering down of the common law protection. We argued over it last year with regard to the crimes commission legislation and we find it again in this Bill.

Proposed new section 324C deals with reports by receivers. This clause turns receivers into law enforcement officers. They must report if they believe an officer or a former officer is guilty of an offence or guilty of any negligence. It is inconsistent with the role of the receiver, as Senator Messner indicated, whose primary responsibility is to secured creditors. They then shall furnish information to the Commission to support their case. Presumably, if they fail to do so they are committing an offence. Certainly, if they have not made such a report, the court may, on application of a person interested in the appointment of the receiver, direct the receiver to make the report. Who fits within that nebulous concept of a person interested in the appointment of a receiver?

I wish to look briefly at the provisions in relation to disqualification of directors, proposed new section 227A. If a company fails to comply with two provisions of the Companies Act, which could be quite possible with regard to minor provisions, and a director has failed to take reasonable steps to prevent that breach, whatever that may be, the court may for any period it specifies prohibit him from being in any way directly or indirectly concerned in the management of any corporation. In other words, it could strip him of his livelihood. That obviously is a dramatic extension on the current provision that a person needs leave from the court to act as a director if he has been convicted of certain offences. That matter was not even raised in the Minister's speech, and I look forward to his justification for that extension.

I want to touch on the penalty notice system dealt with in proposed new section 570A. This deals with the on-the-spot fines provision of the Bill. Proposed new section 570A sets up a system of prescribed offences and prescribed penalties. If one gets a notice and pays, no further action is taken. Why is this provision necessary? If we are talking about failure to lodge documents-we do not, unfortunately, know what offences are envisaged-there is already a system of severe monetary penalty. Again, regrettably, the subject of the extension of the corporate law into on-the-spot fines is not even mentioned in the Minister's speech.

I remind the Senate that the Senate's own Scrutiny of Bills Committee also has had reason for concern with regard to the Bill before us. I touch briefly upon the matters that caused it concern. Proposed new section 30H (3) concerns auditors disciplinary boards. It states:
A person shall not, at a hearing, give evidence that is false or misleading.

There is no question of guilty intent. Should it not rather provide that a person shall not knowingly at a hearing give evidence that is false or misleading? I look forward to the Minister's attitude on that. Clearly the government has had considerable time to consider it. Proposed new section 30H (4 ) undermines legal professional privilege by requiring a legal practitioner to provide the name and address of a person with whom the practitioner has had privileged communication. As an upholder of normal civil rights I look forward to the Minister's response in that regard.

Proposed new section 30H (5) removes the normal protection against self- incrimination. I do not have time to detail that, but it is set out in the 10th report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee dated 19 October 1983. Also, proposed new section 215C gives the Commission a wide power of exemption that I think calls for explanation. Powers have been inserted to protect the public interest. Why should the Commission then be given, by this Bill, wide powers of exemption? Where is the end to that principle? Proposed new section 261 (4) deals with injunctions which, according to the Scrutiny of Bills committee, abrogates a common law rule which has a sound legal footing. I look forward to the Minister' s response in that regard.

This Bill raises the whole subject of the co-operative companies and securities scheme and the method by which it can be amended in general. It is obviously not an appropriate time to go over the merits and demerits of a co-operative federal scheme vis-a-vis a national Act. We opted for the former but it must be said that it is an incredibly complex mish-mash of Commonwealth and State legislation and regulations. What do we do with regard to amendments? The Minister tells us that we cannot amend the Bill. The Senate is dealing with this Bill tonight but cannot amend it. Whilst I do not accept that that is so, there is certainly uncertainty as to what is to be the process if the Senate does amend. I trust that the Australian Democrats will see the error of their ways and support the amendment introduced by Senator Durack. It would appear that probably the Federal Government must return to the Ministerial Council and get the Ministerial Council's permission to alter the scheme and then bring it back to this Parliament. If that is necessary, that in fact should be what happens. If that is the role-

TALK.START.PARA: —It can be done without a physical meeting; it can be done by telex.

—Senator Rae says that it can be done without a physical meeting and, no doubt he will detail that to the Senate shortly. This is a most important Bill, Mr Deputy President, because it will bind the States and it is not even to be examined by State parliaments. What we are doing in relation to this Bill tonight is highly significant. It has not been well handled. It should have been through the committee process so that a committee could deal with it properly. I invite that course of action in the future. I think the Bill should be given public exposure through a Senate committee. I invite the Minister to hold over this Bill in order to consider the matters I have raised. I urge that the provision regarding receivers, which is particularly unsatisfactory, be withdrawn, that it be examined in a proper form, and that it be returned to the Ministerial Council. If it is considered that it should be proceeded with, it should then be returned to the Federal Parliament for examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The matters that have been dealt with in relation to the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 are probably best described as a further example of how to make complex that which was originally conceived to simplify. The original proposals which were put forward by a committee of this Senate in relation to the companies and securities law of Australia were partly occasioned by the complexity of what were 14 separate Acts governing the companies and securities law of Australia, as it was administered at that time, State by State and Territory by Territory. What we now have is an even more complex situation where there are more pieces of legislation, more pages of legislation and probably more complexities within the legislation than ever gave rise to the suggestion that it was costly, full of red tape and full of inconsistency to the degree where it was less effective than it ought to have been. I do not say that in criticism of any particular Minister. I certainly acknowledge that the present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has inherited a difficult situation. If I wished to lay blame, I would go back to his predecessor in a similar government and say that the person who created the fiasco was a former Attorney- General in a former Labor government. He introduced a draconian piece of legislation which created a reaction at a time when the States of Australia would have accepted something which was a reasonable approach to a piece of national legislation enacted by the Commonwealth using the Commonwealth's undoubted power to legislate in this field.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I have a different idea of co-operative federalism from that of some people. I have noted that there has been criticism of the approach which has been fairly generally forthcoming tonight in this debate in relation to the way in which the Ministerial Council has been operating and needs to operate under the Maroochydore agreement of 1978. In my view, co-operate federalism involves first the definition of responsibility as between the Commonwealth and the States, and secondly, the acceptance of the responsibility which has been defined as existing between the Commonwealth and the States. It does not mean the lowest common denominator of saying 'We cannot make up our minds as to who has the responsibility, so we shall require everyone to have a finger in the pie ' to the extent that we get everyone saying 'I want my little bit in' and 'I want my little bit in' so that we get everybody's little bit in and we get the most complex approach possible. As I have said on every occasion on which legislation on this subject has been before this chamber, that, I regret, is the product which we have.

However, I think that there is a possibility of starting to change that approach a little, and I am glad to support what has been put forward tonight by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack, in relation to two fundamental proposals which might restore a little parliamentary consideration and parliamentary involvement, instead of just a bureaucratic executive combination approach as to how to legislate in relation to this important matter. That is that if the Government would accept the amendments which have been put forward with regard to a new introduction into the scheme, approved accounting standards , this would enable the Parliament to consider those and, if necessary, to disallow them. I might add that if one goes back to the report of the Senate Committee, one finds that one of the proposals put forward by that Committee was : that there should be a rule making power with the power of revocation by the Parliament. There should also be something else, which another Senate Committee with which I have some familiarity has been most concerned, and that is the degree of accountability by bodies which are established by legislation. From this Accounting Review Standards Board a report should be presented to the Parliament which will at least give the Parliament some liaison and some prospect of ensuring what in its broadest sense-not just in its financial sense- is understood as accountability.

If the Government, the Australian Democrats and the Ministerial Council will not accept these two very basic, fundamental concepts, all that I can beleive is that there is an absolute abdication of the idea of parliamentary responsibility and parliamentary democracy. I should have thought that they were as simple and as fundamental as one could possible have. Whilst they involve a number of words as drafted and put forward by Senator Durack, they boil down to two very simple propositions. The first is that there should be an annual report. The second is that the accounting standards which are required are subject to review and revocation by the Parliament. If we cannot introduce that degree, I believe that the time has come to start to consider what I started saying when we first had the Maroochydore agreement and, in fact, earlier than that. That is that we would have to review very seriously whether this was a responsible approach at all, using the Ministerial Council approach, and eliminating parliamentary consideration and eliminating expedition.

If the answer given is that we cannot have any sort of amendment to this because it would delay the Bill, all I can do is to point to three things. First , there has been a past practice of enabling the considerations of the Ministerial Council to take place by telex communication rather than physical meeting. Secondly, it is a matter of principle which I should have thought could have been dealt with by telex without the necessity for a physical meeting, and is therefore capable of obtaining a response from the Ministerial Council very expeditiously. Thirdly, I point to the fact that it is no longer necessary that it be unanimous. A majority view could accept this amendment. Whilst I am prepared to accept for the time being only, for the purposes of this debate, that clause 46 and some other associated clauses of the Maroochydore agreement involve the Federal Government in reporting back to and obtaining the approval of the majority of the Ministerial Council for any amendment, I think that that can be easily achieved. But whether that is a proper interpretation of the Maroochydore agreement is a matter for debate on another occasion.

Having said that, I hope that we shall find a sympathetic and responsive attitude being adopted by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and by the Australian Democrats, who, I would expect, would be only too willing to support a means of obtaining, in a system which is virutally out of parliamentary control, a degree of parliamentary involvement and consideration. Secondly, I wholeheartedly support Senator Durack's suggestion that there ought to be some committee association. That is something which I said when the legislation was first before the chamber some years ago and have continued to say. I see no reason for departing from that view. I should have thought that it is a view which is obvious. Unless we can have some committee involvement of the Parliament which can ensure that this very complex and technical area is continually considered by and within the parliamentary process, all that we shall have is legislation by Executive and bureaucracy.

The Bill has had considerable exposure. In view of the points made very properly and effectively by Senator Hill, it is surprising that there has not been more representation about the exposure. I just wonder whether the whole of the Australian business and associated professional community has not been drowned in paper and words on this subject. I am beginning to wonder whether almost a sort of drowning man philosophy is being applied, by which people have said 'It is just too complex and too much beyond us, and the process is beyond our capacity to be able to involve ourselves with any likelihood of being heard and, therefore, there is no point other than simply relaxing to the extent of knowing that you will have to pay an increasing number of professionals an increasing fee to interpret the increasingly complex provisions' which, as I have said, were originally designed to simplify and expedite the process whilst making it more effective and efficient.

What we have had are some sorts of representations which have suggested that, for instance, the provisions in relation to nominee companies and disclosure-to mention some that have not been mentioned by Senator Messner or Senator Hill- will limit the depth of the Australian market, will be a disincentive to overseas investment, which has been an influence, although perhaps not as strongly as some of the people who have made the representations have suggested, on strengthening and deepening the Australian capital market, and that it may dissuade overseas investors from their continued participation and may adversely affect the operation of the Australian market. If that is so, I hope that there will be a very quick and responsive reaction from this Government and the Ministerial Council, because I am sure that that is not the intention of those who have proposed the legislation. It is one of the aspects on which I should like to think an eye will be kept.

A further point to which I refer, which was made recently by Senator Jack Evans , who was kind enough to send me a copy of the speech in which he referred to it , and which was also mentioned by Senator Messner tonight, is a matter to which I have endeavoured to draw attention for many years and that is what happened with the British review of the operation of their company law at the beginning of the 1970s. I think there has been a growing recognition of the difference in the requirements between major company law dealing with major companies and those things which have come into existence as a result merely or very substantially from the nature of our taxation laws rather than anything else, and that is the small proprietory company.

If we can find some different form of incorporation, perhaps through an arrangement negotiated with the States, whereby the States retained some form of legislative power with regard to limited partnerships or some form of proprietary company, and if the truly national companies-the listed companies and the other national companies-were subject to a law which was wholly the law of the Commonwealth and subject to a single regulatory definitional approach, I believe that we may have a more efficient and effective way of incorporation without unduly adversely affecting the revenue-gathering of the States and without increasing the complexity but rather decreasing it. Undoubtedly, as has been said by Senator Jack Evans, Senator Messner and, I think, by Senator Hill, the idea of applying to a small family company the largest part of the requirements of the incredibly complex and now incredibly detailed companies and securities industry law is reaching close to the height of absurdity.

In case anybody is offended by my use of the term 'regulation', I point out that one of the things I want to come to in a moment is that the most urgent need in this whole area is some consideration of deregulation. Let me start by saying that regulation is necessary because companies exist only as a result of law, which is regulation. We have to have regulation to be able to have companies at all. The debate centres around how extensive is the regulation and what form it takes. So in debating the matter one must talk about regulation and its nature. I am suggesting that we need to review some of the concepts of our regulatory approach, we need to review some of the concepts of our federalist approach; and we need to review some of the concepts of the efficiency approach in the whole of this area. I believe that all would be found to be wanting if examined at this stage. Therefore, the suggestion by my colleague Senator Durack that we should, first, start a little bit of parliamentary consideration by having the Accounting Standards Review Board operation subject to some Commonwealth parliamentary consideration is an excellent start. Secondly, I think it is highly desirable that there be a committee association of the Parliament to deal with this body of legislation. That committee may then be able to make some recommendations as to where we go from the mess that we are in . I imagine that there would be almost a universal support for the idea that what was, however genuinely, intended to be an approach to solve a whole lot of problems has become a complicated monster which is starting to add tremendously to cost, to economic inefficiency, and to the creation of opportunities for the very things that it was designed to prevent.

I hope that we can continue to have debate such as we have had tonight on the matter. I am sure the Attorney-General will accept that the debate has been a constructive approach to the further development of this area of law, to this area of the operation of our economy, to this very fundamental area. I do not think anyone would suggest that an economy such as ours can operate without company law, without corporate law, without law relating to both government and private or generally-owned corporations. In my belief, we need to redevelop our ideas as to how those corporations, both government-owned and privately-owned, will operate to the advantage of the community, to the advantage of individuals and to the advantage of their corporate enterprise, that which they have been established to pursue and achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Senate has before it tonight in the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill a very substantial piece of major reforming legislation running to some 150 clauses which cannot with any fairness be described as the lowest common denominator subject of agreement between the participating governments. Most of the matters dealt with represent substantial changes to the existing law . I believe they are changes that have been the subject of a great deal of thought and energy in their preparation and, of course, the subject of an enormous amount of public exposure and comment. It is not surprising, given the magnitude and complexity of the legislation before us and its importance, that the debate should have generated a show of learning in significant respects and also, on some occasions, a show of passion. It is to be regretted that the learning did not always coincide with the passion in every participant in the debate, but that is what we can expect, I suppose, in a debate of this kind. But I thank the speakers for their contributions to what has been an interesting debate which I believe, has generated a number of ideas and responses to this legislation that will require further comment and further thought certainly, by those of us responsible for the detailed working up of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The character of the legislation has also generated some complaints, not least from Senator Durack in opening the debate for the Opposition. He expressed himself somewhat overborne by the complexity of it all and wished that there were better mechanisms available to deal with this legislation and more assistance rendered to him in doing so. I fear he is experiencing in many respects simply the pains and penalties of being in opposition. In fact, he is being somewhat unfair to himself, given the amount of assistance that really has been available in the form of offers of departmental briefing which are quite standard in this area-whether they are availed of I am not sure-and given the fact that draft Bills were given significantly in advance and that the whole process has been one of exposure, as has been said by every speaker, of the basic propositions here for the best part of 12 months, going back to last December. The debate has not been brought on in any great hurry. The Bills were introduced on 5 October; it is now the middle of November. That debate was delayed at the Opposition's request to enable it to get over the top of what is readily conceded to be a complex affair. Even if not all Senator Durack's criticisms in this respect are justified, all is not lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —My criticisms were not directed at you at all.

—I did discern the beginnings of some wisdom in Senator Durack, shared by a number of his colleagues, so far as the character of this legislation is concerned and what, in fact, are its defects so far as any rational approach to it by a national parliament is concerned. I seem to recall even some of the same phrases echoing around the chamber that I used in opposition to demonstrate or describe my frustration on behalf of the Opposition at the inability to deal seriously with legislation of this character. The legislation comes forward as the product of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and of inter-governmental agreement and in the context of another more formal inter-government agreement which prohibits the participating governments and the Commonwealth, in particular, as the legislative leader, from doing anything in the legislative process which is contrary to the express riding instructions of the Ministerial Council. It is a frustrating business to be purporting to legislate against that background. That is why it is, of course, that in opposition I continued-and in government still continue-to express a very strong preference for unilateral Commonwealth legislation in the companies and securities area, rather than going through this Heath Robinsonian farce, as some have described it, fiasco or charade or other terms, to get an airing tonight of the co-operative arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: But honourable senators on the other side of this chamber simply cannot have it both ways. I think Senator Peter Rae is rather more honest than most of his colleagues in this respect because he has long indicated a quite overt and explicit preference for straightforward Commonwealth legislation. But that is not a position which has been shared by his colleagues. None of them, with the possible exception of Senator Hill who demonstrated some lurking tendencies towards backsliding in this respect, shared his position. Most of his colleagues who spoke tonight on this subject still wanted to perpetuate the framework of the co-operative agreement, still wanted to pretend that what we had was a co- operative arrangement involving the States in the full finery of federalism, but at the same time wanted to embark upon processes and amendments which are manifestly inconsistent with that particular approach. This was no more obvious than in the repeated references by various speakers to the proposed amendment for the disallowance by this particular Parliament solely, unilaterally, on the determinations that may be made by the Accounting Standards Review Board.

What is proposed in this particular amendment, let it be appreciated, is not simply an addition to the existing system in the legislation as proposed of disallowance by the Ministerial Council consistent with Stock Exchange regulation arrangements and so on; what is proposed is not merely some additional layer of disallowance capacity in the national parliament. What is proposed by this amendment is the replacement of the Ministerial Council disallowance power with a power vested in this Commonwealth Parliament alone. That simply ignores the procedural constraints which may to some extent, in relation to straightforward matters as Senator Rae has indicated, be overcome by telex votes taken in the course of an extended parliamentary debate. Not only do we have the procedural constraint of making an amendment of any kind to this legislation in running but also we have the obvious constraint posed by this really root and branch attack on the Federal character of this legislation. How on earth does Senator Durack, Senator Rae or any other one of the senators on the other side of this chamber who spoke on this matter think the Ministerial Council participating State governments will react to a suggestion that in the future they have no role at all in relation to the disallowance of ASRB determinations which they may find offensive but have to in fact vest this function entirely in the Commonwealth Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well they vested the legislative power there.

—That is not the way it operates. The Commonwealth Parliament may exercise the actual leading role in the putting of the legislation on to the statute book and the States may accede to that process being followed, but what we are talking about here is policy second guessing of the effective legislative determinations of the ASRB.
—That is disallowance.
—Disallowance, the second guessing by way of a disallowance procedure.
—But it is not the creation and that is the difference, surely .

—That is not the point. It is still the exercise of a legislative veto, a veto on what would otherwise have the force of law, to rule out that which would otherwise have the force of law and make it not a legal rule at all. It is in the nature of a legislative power that is being exercised and one cannot possibly expect any of the States, as long as they remain participants in this process, to willingly concede that power to the Commonwealth. I might have all sorts of sneaking desires for the Commonwealth to take over the whole companies and securities area and have it to itself because I appreciate the force of the argument for consistency, for rationality and for better accountability through a single parliament rather than the shared accountability process we have at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand all those arguments. I have expressed them myself on numerous occasions. But what hypocrisy it is to hear those arguments coming from the mouths of the self-confessed federalists, the self-confessed States righters on the other side of this Parliament-those who are quick to challenge the credentials of others, those who are quick to challenge the sincerity of others, those who are quick to assert the virtues of State powers and the Federal compact, the Federal role of this nation. What rubbish it is for them to advance the kind of propositions they are tonight because those propositions, attractive as I may find them, are utterly inconsistent with the whole philosophy that this new-born Liberal Party is supposed to be about. I find it not merely hypocritical but contemptible to see Senator Chaney chortling away with all the pompous hypocrisy of which he is capable on occasions such as this.

It must be appreciated by those on the other side of this chamber that they cannot with any honesty, with any integrity and with any consistency have it both ways. I think Senator Rae is being honest; he knows he cannot have it both ways. He tried to tippy-toe a metre or two down that particular path tonight but he knows perfectly well there is only one solution to this problem. If we want national regulation in this area, we have to do it solely through the Commonwealth Parliament. We cannot compromise in the unprincipled way which has been suggested by miscellaneous members of the Opposition here tonight. Most of the contributions to the debate were variations on one or other of these themes. Specific contributions were made, to a small extent by Senator Messner and to a much greater extent by Senator Hill. Let me mention at least one or two of the points that have come out of those contributions.

Senator Messner was particularly concerned about the question of the applicability of accounting standards in relation to exempt proprietary companies. He expressed puzzlement about what the position of the joint accounting bodies had been, and expressed a certain disbelief at the propositions contained in the second reading speech, in this respect. I simply remind him, for the record, that the joint accounting bodies initially put forward the proposal for all companies to lodge accounts and have them audited, but did not then proceed with that proposal simply because of the very strong public comments to the contrary effect which were received from individual accountants during the public exposure period. Senator Messner, like so many of his colleagues, seems simply not to have taken into account what occurred during that public exposure period and the quite extensive way in which the debate went backwards and forwards.

Some other aspects of Senator Messner's contribution simply represent a failure , I think, to appreciate the nature of the particular proposals that he was quick to criticise. For example, to take one other point in the area of receivership which occupied a good deal of his attention, he said that receivers should not have the duty of reporting possible offences. The point here, of course, is that the duty is not to look for possible offences, for receivers to be turned into some new kind of corporate policemen, but rather, simply, to create an obligation for a receiver if he comes across information that an officer of a company has committed an offence, to report that offence. Indeed, why should a receiver in such a situation not be obliged, like a liquidator, to report it to the National Companies and Securities Commission? That is simply what is being proposed there.

Senator Hill's contribution at least demonstrated the virtue of a very considerable amount of preparation and a very considerable amount of understanding of the subject area in question, as is only appropriate for a highly qualified and experienced professional in this area. But his preparation, he indicated, would have been much more substantial had he only had access to the submissions made during the evolutionary process involved in the preparation of this legislation. He suggested, I think, in response to an interjection, that submissions had been refused to the Opposition by my Department. I simply make the point, after consultation with my departmental officers who are now present, that we are not aware of any refusal by the Department to make the submissions available. We are not aware of any request having been made for such submissions , and I certainly would not have refused them. I am able to refuse them, under the freedom of information rules as they stand at the moment because of the interstate components involved, but I see absolutely no reason in what is intended to be an overt public debate on a matter of this kind for the retention of such submissions and I will certainly raise this question with the Ministerial Council and make it absolutely clear that I propose, unilaterally if necessary, to release these submissions in the future in order to encourage a proper and open debate. Of course the exception will be those submissions that are expressly sought to be kept confidential by those putting them in.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was past practice that they be made available.
—I understand it was past practice, but I assure Senator Rae that, as with so many other things, I am damn sure it will not be future practice as far as I am concerned.
—No, sorry; wrong way around. I was just saying that it was past practice that they be made available and I have no doubt that the Ministerial Council will continue to do so.

—I was not aware of anything to the contrary and I was surprised to hear that. I am grateful for that clarification. It is a pity, under those circumstances, that these rather wild and unfounded assertions were made about the unavailability of submissions. It was also suggested at one point by Senator Hill that there was reason for all sorts of suspicion about this legislation coming forward, it representing, as it probably did, some kind of ramp from the four Labor States which now exist, those States exercising their majority powers; that the Labor States were embarking on, what is more, to mix metaphors a bit, an ideological bandwagon of some kind. I remind him, as I did in response to his speech by way of interjection, that in fact every proposal that is in the legislation before us tonight is the product of unanimous agreement by the participating governments, including Tasmania and Queensland. If that occurs, anything is possible. It does demonstrate, I believe, the extent to which consultative processes have been worked through.

SPEECH.PARA: There was some disposition on the part of Senator Hill to challenge the creation of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. Indeed, he almost seemed to be questioning also the appropriateness of the Accounting Standards Review Board. Both bodies-again I remind him-were the products of specific heads of agreement at the Maroochydore conference in 1978 which produced this particular animal with which we are now confronted. He raised questions in this respect about the appropriateness of the CSLRC being denied the proposed insolvency reference. In this respect I point out to him that it is proposed that not that Committee but rather the Australian Law Reform Commission have the insolvency reference for the simple reason that the Commission has already accumulated a large store of experience and has already generated a substantial performance in this area in earlier related references. It is desired to treat for the future, so far as possible, corporate and non-corporate insolvencies under the same basic legislation. At least the possibility and desirability of that is being actively explored. Furthermore, the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee has a vast work load already set for it when it does get into gear early next year under the chairmanship of Professor Harold Ford. In all the circumstances, given the fact that it is anticipated that there will be a close co-operative relationship between the Law Reform Commission and the CSLRC, it seemed highly appropriate and sensible to vest this reference in the Law Reform Commission. Nothing is to be assumed about the irrelevance or otherwise of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee as a result of that policy decision.

Senator Hill drew our attention to many individual matters. The one he began with was an expression of concern about the deletion of the requirement of statement of objects in articles and memoranda of association, not so much in order to make the point that objects were desirable necessarily to be retained, as I understand him, but rather to make the point that the exercise had been incompletely carried out and that there were many clauses left in the legislation which seemed to presuppose the continued existence of company objects. He seemed to be making this point as one of a number of general attacks on the credibility of the legislative--

TALK.START.PARA: —Certain protections have been lost.

—I am not sure that certain protections have been lost in the process. It is the case that the exercise of stripping away all references to objects is not complete. At the moment we are not sure that it can be completed. For example, in the context of joint ventures, one may very specifically wish to confine the objects of the corporations created for joint venture purposes to the particular subject matter of that joint venture. That is one context in which objects remain alive and well, although for all other practical purposes, or all that I can think of, objects are essentially something of a charade, as is, similarly, the ultra vires doctrine that goes with it. It may be that this part of the reforming process needs to go a stage or two further than it has so far. But I do not believe any attack on the general credibility of the legislation can derive much nourishment from this section of the reforming legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: There was then from Senator Hill a really quite rapid fire succession of propositions advanced about alleged deficiencies in a variety of areas, particularly in the receivership area. I think it is very difficult and inappropriate to endeavour to reply to those propositions in the context of a second reading reply, even if it had been possible for me to write down the points as fast as he was making them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you volunteering to do it in Committee?

—What I am suggesting is that in the normal course of events it might be appropriate to spend some more time dealing with the issue at the Committee stage. Under the circumstances, and given that Senator Hill does not have sufficient confidence in the merits of his proposals to have framed them as amendments for the purpose of Ministerial Council consideration--
—You told me it is impossible to amend them.

—No. I added the rider for the purpose of Ministerial Council consideration at some future time. Since Senator Hill has not taken his enthusiasm quite that far, I think it would probably be appropriate and would be accepted by him if I undertook, firstly, to refer to Ministerial Council members the text of his speech tonight, which was a substantial and well-informed one, and, secondly, to produce an appropriate reply to him as soon as may be to the points he has made and to endeavour to see what we can do by way of producing amendments to those parts of the legislation which have attracted his indignation and where that indignation seems, on reflection, to be well founded. Given the task before us tonight with this legislation, I think that is probably as much as Senator Hill might reasonably want us to do.

SPEECH.PARA: From Senator Jack Evans we largely had a contribution about the Accounting Standards Review Board disallowance exercise. I guess the points he made will be picked up to the extent that they are still relevant in the context of the consideration of those amendments at the Committee stage.

Finally, from Senator Peter Rae we had the familar analysis which we are used to now, having heard it on many previous occasions, of the deficiencies of the present scheme. I think those deficiencies must be fairly acknowledged. Whether it is fair for him to blame what he describes as the fiasco of companies and securities legislation on so innocent a contributing party as a former Labor Attorney-General who was not even around at the time of Maroochydore is, I believe, another question. I think the basic point that has to be appreciated, arising from what Senator Rae has said, is that the only logical corollary of his contribution is not for him to be fiddling around with amendment processes. He acknowledged the difficulty. A telex vote procedure can only take one so far when many complex amendments are concerned. The only logical conclusion to derive from his approach to this legislation is to really tear it up and start again with the concept of unilateral Commonwealth legislation. I do not shrink from espousing that aspiration, not so much to tear it up but to move towards that concept if it proves to be the case-I repeat my Party's policy on this-that this legislative package simply does become unmanageable, that the procedures under it do prove to be insufficiently sensitive to the understandable demands for input, both from politicians and those affected by it. If there is a feeling that the whole process is insensitive to legitimate demands for amendment of the existing rules, I believe the way to go forward in this respect is to move towards the single concept of the Commonwealth legislation. Whether we can get there is one question. Whether we can get there while still--

TALK.START.PARA: —But is not the suggested use of a Senate committee as a means of getting there something which was quite legitimate for me to have put foward and for you to support?

—I do not shrink from the idea of a Senate committee dealing specifically with companies and securities matters on a regular and ongoing basis. If the membership of that committee can be found in this place- given competing demands on people's time in a small chamber such as this-and if interest and enthusiasm for it can be found, this may well constitute the vehicle through which, over time, we can evolve a bipartisan approach towards having national companies and securities law which would be more satisfactory than the arrangements that exist at the moment.
—So my remark was a positive one. My suggestion was positive.
—Senator Rae made numerous positive suggestions. I think I have been gracious enough to acknowledge them on this occasion, as on other occasions.
—I just wanted to make it complete. Thank you.

—Senator Rae and I can make marvellous music together on this subject, but tonight may not be the time. I simply end on the point that I really did begin with. Members of the Opposition simply cannot have it both ways . Either they espouse Senator Rae's manifest convictions on this point, take their courage in both hands and support an exercise in Commonwealth legislation, with all that goes with it in terms of proper legislative procedures and proper clear lines of accountability, or they accept the present system with all its difficulties, weaknesses and complexites. They cannot cut a swathe through the present system in the way that was proposed, for example, on the Accounting Standards Review Board disallowance issue. That is a classic example of this kind. Members of the Opposition cannot cut a swathe through the present system, ignoring the legitimate interests of the States, so long as that system is preserved, while at the same time pretending that what they are doing is espousing co-operative federalism. To say as much and to do as much, is, I am afraid, pure humbug, and humbug of the kind that has become all too familiar with the present Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 77-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to most of the debate on the blower in my room. I thought the contributions were sensible and considered and, to some extent, academic. I note that the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his customary way ended the debate by insulting everybody and describing it as humbug.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 78 and 79-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 57, clause 78, paragraph (a), lines 34 to 36, leave out all words after '266B (1)'.
(2) Page 59, clause 79, proposed new sub-section 266B (3), lines 27 to 35, leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-section:

'(3) Sections 48 (other than paragraphs (1) (a) and (b) and sub-sections (2), ( 6) and (7)), 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to accounting standards approved under sub-section (1) as if in those sections references to regulations were references to accounting standards and references to a regulation were references to an accounting standard.'.
(3) Pages 59 and 60, clause 79, proposed new sub-section 266B (5), line 38 ( page 59) to line 3 (page 60), leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-section:

'(5) Sections 48 (other than paragraphs (1) (a) and (b) and sub-sections (2), ( 6) and (7)), 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to revocations under sub-section (4) as if in those sections references to regulations were references to revocations and references to a regulation were references to a revocation.'.

(4) Page 60, clause 79, proposed new sub-section 266C (3), lines 31 and 32, leave out 'by reason that a copy of a notice stating that the accounting standard has been disallowed is published under paragraph 266B (3) (b)', insert 'under sub-section 266B (3)'.

(5) Page 61, clause 79, proposed new sub-section 266C (5), lines 12 to 14, leave out 'Where a copy of a notice stating that the revocation of an approved accounting standard has been disallowed is published under paragraph 266B (5) (b )', insert 'Where a revocation is disallowed, or is deemed to have been disallowed, under sub-section 266B (5)'.

All of these amendments give effect to the one point in relation to the disallowance of accounting standards. The purpose of the amendments has already been the subject of fairly extensive debate at the second reading stage and I do not propose to go over the ground again. The amendments seek to ensure that the accounting standards that are promulgated by the Accounting Standards Review Board, which is to be created not legislatively but by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, should be subject to the ordinary disallowance provisions of any other subordinate legislation. I think that principle would be accepted without question by almost every honourable senator in the chamber if it were not for the peculiar features of the co-operative arrangement between the Commonwealth and the States, the apex of which is the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. That body will determine the ultimate legislative proposals for amendments to the co-operative companies and securities scheme.

We should bear in mind, of course, that the Ministerial Council is not itself a legislative body and that the scheme recognises that it is this Parliament that has the legislative power under the scheme. In the light of that, I cannot understand this either/or, logic-chopping, lecturing approach of the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his response to the second reading stage of the Bill. It is not simply a question of either having a co-operative scheme or abandoning that and having a national scheme. The co-operative scheme depends upon the exercise of legislative power by this Parliament. It cannot do otherwise. That is fundamental to the scheme. It is an absolute nonsense for the Attorney-General to say that this Parliament cannot amend or reject the legislation which gives effect to the scheme. Admittedly, it presents a slight problem for the Attorney-General if the Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —More humbug. You rejected out of hand our amendments when we were in Opposition.

—That is because we did not think they were any good. If the Parliament rejects an amendment to the scheme, that would be a factor that the Ministerial Council would certainly have to consider. Whether it considers it by telex vote, as Senator Peter Rae has suggested, or whether it meets to considers it is a matter for the Ministerial Council to determine. No doubt that would be determined by the circumstances of the amendments. It is simply absurd to say that the Parliament cannot pass an amendment without threatening the scheme. As I have said, the scheme itself cannot work without being subject to amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the proposal that accounting standards should be dealt with in the same way as regulations and subject to disallowance in the same way as regulations, the Companies Act provides for the making of regulations by the Governor-General in accordance with the advice of the Ministerial Council. The Ministerial Council could suggest that it have some say in the determination of accounting standards, if that is what it wants. I am not taking any hard and fast attitude as to what the Ministerial Council may want to do. All we are saying is that where there is clearly going to be subordinate legislation, as there will be emanating from the Accounting Standards Review Board, there should be ordinary parliamentary control in relation to that subordinate legislation. I can understand that the Attorney-General is somewhat irritated by this. We know he is easily irritated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aggressively and increasingly so.

—The Attorney-General keeps talking about nonsense, humbug and all the rest of it. However, that sort of comment does not bear examination. I am exhibiting how little it bears examination. The fact of the matter is that there is no difference at all between this Parliament providing for an amendment and the Parliament rejecting some of these proposals. The Parliament could have rejected the whole proposal to establish the Accounting Standards Review Board. We could have rejected some of the other provisions that have been severely criticised by Senator Hill in particular. The honourable senator made very trenchant criticisms of some of the proposals. We might decide that there is nothing in this Bill of any value.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that the whole scheme would fall down, that the company law would fall down. Certainly the world would not fall down, the commerce of this country would not fall down, if we simply refused to pass this legislation. If we are to be confronted with 150 amendments every year the Parliament might well decide that the total burden of increasing regulation is so absurd in this area that the best thing we can do is to reject it. The more I hear the Attorney- General's reaction to this perfectly modest and reasonable proposal I am putting the more I am encouraged to think that that might be the best way of handling his legislation in this area in the future.

The fact is that the co-operative scheme recognises the responsibility of this Parliament. It is a nonsense and an absurdity to say that this Parliament cannot exercise this responsibility without destroying the scheme. Of course the scheme will not be destroyed. The States recognise the great value of the scheme and their participation in it. The scheme could be threatened only if there were some absolutely fundamental confrontation between the Ministerial Council and this Parliament on policy grounds. Apart from this, the scheme could not be possibly threatened even if this whole Bill were thrown out. It is quite unrealistic and totally academic for the Attorney-General to take the particular line he has taken. I can understand his attitude. As I said, it is a good first line of defence to take. I do not blame him for taking it. However, his passionate defence of every word and every minor provision of this legislation and his answering of the amendments in the way he has done, is totally unjustifiable and unrealistic. I do not think this approach does justice to the common sense that the Ministerial Council would show if the amendments were passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There appears to have been some misunderstanding on the part of Senator Durack as to what the nature of the objection is to the Commonwealth Parliament acquiring by virtue of his amendment a power of disallowance over the determinations of the Accounting Standards Review Board. If I could put it simply and not be accused of lecturing because there seem to be very slow learners on the opposite side, the objection is this: Under the present co-operative scheme the Commonwealth is no more and no less than the legislative agent of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. Parliament has legislative powers under the scheme to the extent that, and only to the extent that, it is reflecting the wishes of the Ministerial Council.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that the Commonwealth acts as a kind of legislative contractor for the Ministerial Council. The Ministerial Council decides what it wants legislated; the Commonwealth enacts it and the scheme of legislation is such that under those circumstances it then springs to life and becomes part of the law of the State. But in all cases the Commonwealth is not acting unilaterally only on the riding instructions of the Ministerial Council as a whole. That is fundamental to the whole concept of the scheme. What is proposed before us now is that the Commonwealth should be able to act in this one small area quite unilaterally, quite independently, quite remotely from any wish that may be expressed or not expressed by the Ministerial Council. That is what is being proposed-that the Commonwealth Parliament should exercise not in a positive way but in a negative way to actually veto determinations made, and veto subordinate regulation. True it is that it cannot exercise a constructive legislative role in this respect, but it can exercise, if this amendment gets up a destructive legislative role, and in doing so we would not be acting as the agent of the Ministerial Council. That is why this is manifestly incompatible with what the whole agreement is about, and that is why, however many telex votes honourable senators opposite might drum up over the next few days, it is manifestly and totally unlikely to be accepted by the State participants in the scheme.

I notice Senator Bjelke-Petersen listening very intently to this, because I think she appreciates the force of what I am saying. Senator Durack should ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen's husband what his reaction to this amendment would be. Mr Bjelke-Petersen's reaction would be very vociferous indeed, because it would represent a unilateral attempt by the Commonwealth to grab for itself some very significant policy making power, policy making in the sense that it would be denying the viability of the regulatory changes proposed by the ASRB. That is why, however much I might like the idea and think that the ultimate power should reside in this Parliament, it simply would be totally irresponsible of me to accept the amendment in the terms in which it is proposed. I cannot put it any more fairly or more simply than that. That is why, if I demonstrate some irritation, I have done so because the force of the point that I am making does not seem to be appreciated.

Let me go on from there. That is not the only line of defence. A number of other points can be made. The next point, I suppose, which could be made is this : It is a real question as to whether disallowance is even appropriate as a basic mechanism in this area. It is not a case of the Executive Government affecting individual rights, the usual case of tabling and disallowance- subordinate legislation. Rather it is a matter of an expert body determining the standards which apply across the board to all companies. These standards will often be about things like the valuation of assets, what would constitute satisfactory compliance with particular legislative obligation, rather than being about things like who has to disclose what, and other matters which do impinge upon individual or corporate rights. So there is a threshold question as to whether disallowance is even an appropriate mechanism at all in that context. But I acknowledge that there may well be overriding policy considerations, as there are with the existing disallowance mechanism in relation to subordinate legislation, which would make a parliament or a governing body want to have that power.

Let us move on to the next and, I think, the really most conclusive reason why this amendment just simply cannot hold up. It is a different reason again. That is the reason of commercial uncertainty. If we provide, as the present law does, for Ministerial Council disallowances, the uncertainty is over when 60 days elapse from the time of the promulgation of the original determination. If we are talking about disallowance by the Commonwealth Parliament, we are talking about something built around the concept of sitting days and about things which are manifestly uncertain in the context of recess periods and all the other vagaries that afflict parliamentary life. That might be tolerable when we are talking about a mechanism to cope with potential excesses of executive power within a particular parliamentary system; it is not tolerable in the kind of commercial context we are talking about here.

If we go further and say that if it is appropriate -as I am sure the State participants in this scheme would-not only for the Commonwealth to have this disallowance power, but also for any State so far as operations of the standards within that State are concerned, we are just multiplying the uncertainty of absurdity. It has to be part of the proposal, as Senator Jack Evans acknowledged , that this is something that is confined unilaterally to the Commonwealth if it is to work in practice at all. That turns us back full circle to the terms of the original objection. So it is not based simply on any procedural concern, although procedural reasons and the problems of telex votes and getting meetings and so on might well be a good ground for resisting large scale attempts at amendments in this place. It really goes, quite fundamentally, to the substance and to the rationale of this particular proposal that is put forward tonight. It is just unacceptable and it must be unacceptable so long as we have the kind of scheme we have at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to lengthen the debate on this matter by the possibility of descending from what I thought had been a relatively high plane to a somewhat lesser plane. I urge the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) to consider this point carefully: I am surprised that he put the argument that he did in relation to the question of the power of the Parliament to reject, refuse, disallow-whichever word one likes-delegated legislation which it has delegated. At the moment we have a situation where this Parliament, and in particular this House, has the power to refuse to pass any piece of legislation which comes in a proposed form from the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. In effect it has the power to refuse the request of the Ministerial Council to legislate on companies and securities. What the Attorney-General is arguing is that it should not have the power to refuse delegated legislation which comes as a request from a subordinate body of the Ministerial Council when it can refuse what the Ministerial Council requested it to do. That is a preposterous situation.
—In either event the scheme is destroyed because both are equally incompatible with the continued operation of the scheme. You cannot have it both ways.
—This Parliament has the power to refuse to pass any proposal which comes from the Ministerial Council.
—And if it does so the scheme is effectively torn up so far as this Parliament's participation is concerned.

—It is not. I will answer the interjection by simply saying that that does not effectively tear up the scheme. What it does do is to seek to have the Ministerial Council reconsider the matter as would the disallowance either by the Ministerial Council or by the Parliament of some delegated legislation which comes from the Accounting Standards Review Board. For the Attorney-General to suggest when the Parliament has the power to refuse to amend legislation that it does not have the power to refuse delegated legislation is really something which I did not expect to hear him arguing. I would have thought that was a reasonably fundamental sort of principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I will answer the second point that he made in relation to commercial uncertainty: If the Ministerial Council has 60 days in which to create a commercial uncertainty by not making up its mind as to whether it will allow or disallow the particular regulations of the Accounting Standards Review Board, why should not the Parliament have just the same time? The period of commercial uncertainty will not be extended and the degree of commercial uncertainty would presumably not be extended. I cannot think of that as a good reason. I accept that commercial uncertainty is a cosideration when this sort of system is introduced.

When we originally proposed in the debate on this matter some 10 years ago that there should be a rule-making power with a power to disallow and there was a debate as to whether it ought to be 44 days or some other period, there was quite a lot of consideration as to commercial uncertainty and the considerations arising out of that. They are inherent in this scheme. There are a number of aspects in which there are stop provisions available through the actions of the National Companies and Securities Commission. I would have thought that, if the time in which the Ministerial Council can act and in which the Parliament can act in relation to disallowance were exactly the same, the situation in relation to commercial uncertainty would be exactly the same, or to all intents and purposes exactly the same. So, in summary, neither of the points that have been raised by the Attorney-General amounts to a valid reason for not accepting the reconsideration of this aspect so that there can be the commencement of a parliamentary review role in relation to the operation of this whole scheme. I do not wish to swap insults in any way but I just invite the Attorney-General to consider those two points as being rather ones which in other circumstances he might advocate himself as good reason why a government should take back to the Ministerial Council this rather minor but very fundamental alteration to what is proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the trenches have well and truly been dug on this particular matter and there is little more I can offer by way of further reply other than what I did in interjection to the first leg of Senator Peter Rae's double. As to the second leg, it is a matter of judgment as to how much commercial uncertainty is tolerable when both sides concede that there will be an element of it. I simply note the failure of Senator Rae to address in any way, shape or form the argument I made which seems to me to be central to the whole issue about the nature of this Parliament's role as an agent merely of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. It does seem to me to be quite incompatible with that agency role for us to strike out on legislative adventures of our own of the kind that are implied here. However much he and I might think it appropriate that a national parliament have that role, it is inconsistent with the continued operation of the co-operative scheme on its present basis, as Senator Rae or whoever was representing the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs told me endlessly in the dark days of Labor Opposition. It is odd but understandable to hear the roles being reversed, as they so often are in this place. I can understand the frustration that honourable senators opposite feel with the present scheme. I share it in many ways but, so long as we have it, we are stuck with it and I urge that, if this matter has to be tested, we proceed to that test now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been invited to respond to what I thought I had responded to, that is, the suggestion that this Parliament is in a position of being merely a cypher for giving an imprimatur in legislative form to the decisions of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. That I refute. I challenge the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to find any basis of any statement by any person, in relation to the debate on this issue, who has been in a position of stating authoritatively-that is, the Maroochydore agreement, the statements that were made at the time of the Maroochydore agreement, the second reading speech or the debate formally on behalf of the government of the day in relation to the introduction of this scheme, or at any other time-that this Parliament's role was limited to that of a mere cypher to give an imprimatur to the decisions of a body created in the form of the Ministerial Council in this instance. I did not think it needed any more comment than I gave it when I first spoke. I have now responded to it. It has no basic validity in history. It has no basic validity in constitutional practice and, to use a Senator Chipp term, it would be an obscenity if it were to become part of the practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 62, clause 79, after proposed new section 266F, add the following section:
Annual Report
'' '266G (1) The Board shall, as soon as practicable after 30 June in each year , prepare and furnish to the Minister a report on its proceedings and activities pursuant to this Act.

'' '(2) The Minister shall cause a copy of a report furnished to him under sub- section (1) to be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which he receives the report.'.''.

This amendment provides that the Accounting Standards Review Board shall prepare and provide to the Parliament an annual report on its activities. I know it is an amendment to the scheme that Senator Evans says is unamendable by this Parliament. I would be interested to know whether he will--

TALK.START.PARA: —How is it that you can carry legislation but you cannot amend it?

—That is right, we have had that out before. Here we have a situation in which there is the most obvious, basic provision in legislation relating to statutory authorities that this Senate, in particular, and the Parliament in recent years has insisted upon time and again. This Board, as I said, will not even be created by a statute; it is to be created by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and, presumably, will be reporting to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. All this amendment provides is that it should report to this Parliament as well. If Senator Evans says that this amendment sets at risk, makes some sort of threat to, the co-operative scheme, that would be one of the most remarkable views that I have heard in this Senate because here is the most normal and basic requirement for accountability to this Parliament by anybody. This Parliament has established the scheme and it amends it. If it is not entitled to have a report of this kind from one of the key elements of this scheme, as it will be in the future, it might as well simply stop wasting its time in the future and confer on the Ministerial Council total legislative authority under the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While this amendment, unlike its predecessor, would not do any damage to the co-operative scheme by its acceptance, it demonstrates, nonetheless, quite a profound insensitivity to the co-operative scheme to the extent that it is drafted in such a way that the report is to be given only to the Commonwealth Parliament. Again, I think those honourable senators sitting opposite who profess to be so sensitive to States' rights will appreciate the weakness, conceptually, of this proposal to the exent that it does not make provision for simultaneous tabling in all parliaments because there is no way that this amendment, as it is couched at the moment, will have any effect other than to confine that obligation to the Commonwealth Parliament. Of course, it is quite unexceptionable to have simply a reporting requirement. It is something that I will undertake to strongly recommend to the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities at its next meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no reason in the world why the Accounting Standards Review Board report should not be tabled through the proper processes in all the parliaments of the competing governments. There is no reason why there should not be a statutory obligation for them to do so, but not a statutory obligation cast in this particular way and not one that obliges me to accept it on the run, although it is something, I am sure, there will be no difficulty at all about the Ministerial Council accepting. There will be no difficulty at all about an appropriate amendment coming forward before the first annual report is due at the end of 1984. There will be another Bill on this next year. I undertake, quite explicitly, to ensure that there are appropriate provisions in the legislation.

This amendment does not raise anything like the same policy objections as the previous one did, where the Commonwealth Parliament was unilaterally second- guessing the determinations of the Accounting Standards Review Board. Here we have a perfectly appropriate reporting requirement. I acknowledge the force of the points that have been made. I still suggest that it is inappropriate to proceed by way of amendment at this stage, because of the procedures employed but more particularly because of the inadequacies of the drafting. I hope that the shadow Minister will be happy to accept my undertaking to bring the appropriate matter forward in the next round of amending legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason this amendment is drafted in this way is that this is the Parliament that happens to pass the legislation relating to this scheme. If the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) wants to propose some other form of reporting, he may do so when he is faced with this amendment to the scheme or at some later time when he proposes amendments to the scheme. We believe that this provision should be provided for in the legislation at its very inception. As I said, when the Ministerial Council decides to produce a more appropriate form of amendment, naturally we will look at it. We believe it is absolutely essential that a reporting requirement be included in the legislation when the Accounting Standards Review Board is set up. We insist on this amendment being determined by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
