SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965 to enact the legislative changes to the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech.

The petroleum products freight subsidy scheme subsidises the cost of transporting certain petroleum products so that consumers in non-metropolitan areas pay no more than currently 1.1 cents per litre of the freight costs.

In this Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that the Government has decided to amend the scheme. Over the years the scheme has become complex, difficult to administer and more open to abuse. The proposals announced by the Treasurer emanate from a review of the scheme instituted by the previous Government. Proposals for which legislation is not required involve removing from eligibility for subsidy those locations where there is no retail site. Subsidy rates for these locations will then be based on the rate applicable at the nearest location with a retail site or, for locations at sea, at the port of loading.

Effective from 1 January 1984, this Bill proposes the removal of power kerosene from subsidy eligibility. The usage of this fuel has dropped considerably in recent years, and its removal will result in a small saving in subsidy payments. The other fuels, motor spirit, automotive distillate and aviation fuels, will remain eligible for subsidy.

Provision is also made in the Bill to recognise the need to include the Northern Territory under the Commonwealth Act, which was originally drafted to provide assistance to the States. In the early stages of the scheme, special financial arrangements were made to provide equivalent assistance to the Northern Territory, which enacted its own legislation along similar lines to the Commonwealth Act. With self-government now in place in the Northern Territory, it is appropriate to accord the Northern Territory Government the same level of recognition under this Act that applies to all the other States. Proclamation action of the Commonwealth amendments is proposed as soon as complementary State -type subsidy legislation is enacted by the Northern Territory Government. As an interim measure, the changes in this Bill relating to power kerosene will, by the operation of clause 10, extend the measures covered by this Bill to the Northern Territory pending the introduction of its new legislation.

Clause 5 of the Bill, also effective from 1 January 1984, will strengthen existing legislation to specify delivery to be a requirement which must be met before subsidy payments are made. This clause also includes a provision to assist in determining rates of subsidy for certain locations which would not automatically qualify for subsidy under the normal location listing criteria.
In this regard, the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority sets the freight differentials for each place. These are subsequently used to calculate the subsidy rates for those places.

The Authority does not, however, set differentials for all Australian places where a sale occurs. It is therefore necessary to have a mechanism to enable subsidy to be paid at those places. Under the provisions of the Bill, subsidy will, for example, be able to be based on the rate upon which sales occur at the nearest place. It will also enable a rate of subsidy to be set for remote farms and isolated communities where the rate of subsidy for the nearest place would not be appropriate.
The changes as announced by the Treasurer to the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme are estimated to save $2m in 1983-84 and $4m in a full year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Rae) adjourned.

The speeches read as follows-
Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to introduce new provisions into that Act which will have the effect of automatically indexing certain traditional excise duty rates at six monthly intervals.

The introduction of this procedure was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech on 23 August 1983. The first of the increases took effect from 8.00 pm Eastern Standard Time on that night and reflected the 4.3 per cent increase in the CPI during the March and June quarters of this year. This increase was effected by the introduction of Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 and Customs Tariff Proposals No. 10 tabled on Budget night.

The opportunity has been taken to incorporate Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 in this Bill and thus avoid the need for additional amending legislation. I will briefly outline the details of these and other proposals in a few moments.
The indexation provisions in this Bill will provide that from now on, the six monthly indexation increases will occur automatically in February and August of each financial year.

The Treasurer mentioned in his Budget Speech that past increases in nominal rates of excises have not been sufficiently frequent or, in aggregate, large enough to counteract the eroding effects of inflation on real rates of excise.
Between 1973-74 and 1982-83, annual revenue from the traditional excises, measured in constant 1982-83 dollar terms, fell from $4.3 billion to $3.3 billion.
Over the same period, the share of traditional excise collections in total budget receipts fell from 13 per cent to a little over 7 per cent.

Despite this trend, some of the past discretionary increases have occasionally proved disruptive, destabilising the sales patterns of the industries concerned and imposing sudden and large price increases on consumers.
The indexation arrangements contained in this Bill are designed to effectively eliminate these problems and will maintain the real value of excise collections.

The Government considers that this new system will afford a greater degree of stability for consumers and industry alike. The excises will rise gradually in line with inflation as wages and other incomes increase.
The Treasurer also mentioned that the new arrangements will effectively place excisable products on much the same basis as products subject to sales tax.

In Budget Statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1, it was estimated that the indexation of excise rates (including the new rates achieved by discretionary rate increases with effect from Budget night) will raise about $236m in 1983-84. Indexation of the excise equivalent component of like customs duties is estimated to raise a further $13m in 1983-84.
Full year revenue gains will be similar in magnitude to the 1983-84 gain.
Gains in future years will be heavily influenced by future inflation rates.
The indexation arrangements are considered to be straightforward and will not involve any additional staffing or administrative costs.
Nor are they expected to generate any significant compliance or administative costs for the excise-paying business community.
I now turn to the other provisions in this Bill.
Clause 4 of the Bill proposes to introduce a revised excise system for crude oil produced from fields discovered before 18 September 1975.

Prior to July 1983, the crude oil excise system contained a number of serious anomalies. In particular, returns to producers in some circumstances decreased as production increased, while in other circumstances these returns could increase while the import parity price fell.

When the Government came to office it saw a need to remove these anomalies. With the aim of achieving a more rational excise scale; one that did not contain disincentives to producers, and that protected the return to the community through a more predictable and stable pattern of crude oil excise revenues.
It is the Government's intention that these anomalies and other problems be eventually tackled through a resource rent tax but that approach will take some time to implement.
In the meantime the Government considers that there is an urgent need to revise the crude oil excise system.
The proposed revised system will be effective from 1 July 1983 and provides for increases in excise rates as the annual production from a field increases.
It has been operating on a provisional basis since 1 July 1983 under the established scheme of rebates provided for by section 77 of the Excise Act 1901.

The continued use of rebates is, however, unsatisfactory in a number of respects. The more important is that their use will become impractical should there be a change in the import parity price before the end of 1983-84.

The revised excise scheme, which has been the subject of extensive consultation with producers, will ensure the systematic collection of excise duty during a financial year (analogous to the PAYE provisions in the income tax legislation) and will minimise fluctuations in receipts of excise.
It caters for import parity price change in a financial year and for fields which commence production in a financial year.

An additional feature, consistent with the proposed 'automatic excise indexation scheme', is that provision has been made for the excise duty rates in respect of crude oil to adjust automatically in accordance with movements in the import parity price of Bass Strait crude.
It will also have a minimal impact on Government revenues.

Revenues in 1983-84 under the new scheme will approximate those under the previous scheme (about $3,400m in 1983-84). Additional revenues may accrue, however, to the producers and to the community from any increased crude oil production that may result from the removal of the anomalies.

I mentioned earlier that the opportunity has been taken to incorporate outstanding excise tariff proposals in this Bill. The proposals so incorporated are numbered 1 to 9 and are proposed to be enacted by clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Bill.

Clause 5 of the Bill, effective 1 July 1983, increases the rate of excise duty on AVGAS and AVTUR by two cents per litre and in expected to yield about $18m in 1983-84. This increase was announced by the Treasurer in his economic statement to the House on 19 May, 1983 and was made instead of an increase in air navigation charges. Alterations from that date also increase the excise duty on motor spirit and diesel fuel by one per cent per litre for the purpose of financing the Australian bicentennial road development program. The excise component of this program is now 2 cents and the estimated net gain to revenue for the program for 1983-84 is $410m.

Paragraph (a) of the clause alters the concessional excise tariff treatment available to goods for international organisations. This is a technical amendment involving no loss of concessions to the organisations.

Clause 6 of the Bill contains the alterations to the excise tariff to give effect to the excise measures outlined by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech on 23 August 1983. Briefly the alterations, which operate from 8.00 p.m. on Budget night increase the duty on beer, spirits, manufactured tobacco products and certain refined petroleum products. They also extend the excise base to include fortifying spirit, fuel oil, heating oil and power and lighting kerosenes and remove the duty on amylic alcohol and fuel oil, playing cards, cigarette tubes, paper and papers and matches. The tariff on tobacco products is also restructured.

I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that the rates, shown in clause 6 of the Bill, reflect the alterations made to the Budget excise rates in respect of fortifying spirit (a decrease from $2.61 per litre of alcohol to $1. 50 per litre of alcohol) and fuel oil, heating oil, an power and lighting kerosene (a decrease from $0.09027 per litre to $0.01872 per litre). These reductions were made following representations received by the Government that the Budget increases would impose severe hardship upon industry and households. The revised excise revenue gain on the petroleum products is now estimated at $ 47m in 1983-84, some $69m less than that contained in the Budget estimate. It is estimated that the taxation revenue from the lower excise on fortifying spirit may not be significantly different from the original $13m estimate contained in the Budget. This is for the reason that the effect upon the industry is now expected to be considerably less than under the excise imposed at Budget time.

Finally, clause 7 of the Bill abolishes with effect from 9 September 1983 the concessional excise tariff treatment available to goods for non-diplomatic trade commissioners following a review of these arrangements. The concessions are not required by any international agreement.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983
Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 which is now before the Senate proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982.

The Bill contains 11 schedules and is necessary to enact tariff changes which have been introduced into the Parliament in the 1983 autumn and Budget sittings by Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 2-14 (1983). The Bill also contains two changes which have not previously been introduced into the Parliament.

Amendments proposed in the Bill arise in the main from government decisions on the Temporary Assistance Authority report on fluorescent and filament lamps and the following Industries Assistance Commission reports:
gelatin (developing country preferences)
the Australian tobacco industry
the commercial by-law system
non-electrical absorption type refrigerators and freezers and parts
sodium alkylxanthates and potassium alkylxanthates (developing country preferences)
transformers (developing country preferences)
canning fruit
certain iron and steel products and certain alloy steel products
certain pigment dyestuffs and colour lakes (developing country preferences)
tableware and certain other goods, of pottery (developing country preferences)
stranded wire, cables, cordage, ropes, etc., of iron or steel wire (developing country preferences)
Other amendments contained in the Bill which have previously been introduced into the Parliament by customs tariff proposals provide for government decisions relating to:
an increase of 2 cents per litre in the rate of customs duty payable on imported aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel. This alteration is complementary to a change in the Excise Tariff Act;

an additional one cent per litre surcharge on imported motor spirit and diesel fuel in accordance with the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act. Again, this alteration is complementary to a change in the Excise Tariff Act;
duty free entry of certain imports required for approved Australian industry participation programs, including defence offsets programs;
Concessions available for goods imported by non-diplomatic trade commissioners, by international organisations and by visiting servicemen of the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand;
Quota provisions for certain footwear; and
A number of administrative changes to correctly reflect the intention, scope, or wording of various provisions of the Customs Tariff Act.
The Bill also includes two changes which have not previously been introduced into the Parliament.

The first change relates to a revision of section 24 of the Customs Tariff Act which provides for separate rates of duty for different components. Parts, ingredients or accessories contained in goods. The change enables the determination, under all circumstances, of the amount of customs duty payable on goods imported under certain tariff classifications in schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act.

The second change inserts section 26A into the Customs Tariff Act to implement the Government's Budget decision to automatically index, on a six-monthly basis, customs tariff rates which incorporate and excise component. Section 26A, as proposed, provides for the relevant customs tariff rates to be increased by the same amount as the increase in the equivalent item in the excise tariff. This change is complementary to changes proposed in the Excise Tariff Act.

The financial impact of those measures in this Bill which complement amendments to the Excise Tariff Act is outlined in my speech on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983. The measures in this category are:
The indexation on a six-monthly basis of Customs Tariff rates containing an excise component;
The two cents per litre increase on aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel ; and
The additional one cent per litre surcharge on imported motor spirit and diesel fuel.

Apart from measures implemented for budgetary and revenue-raising reasons. The Bill contains in the main changes whose principal function is to alter levels of assistance accorded to certain industries. Some of these changes have the secondary effect of increasing or decreasing revenues. The precise revenue effects are difficult to predict as levels of imports and, therefore, the level of customs duty collected, are expected to be affected by such industries assistance decisions. The exact trade impact of these decisions may also not become clear for several months after a tariff change is made. For these reasons , financial impact has been broadly estimated on the assumption of no trade diversion arising from the Government's decisions, as being $3.15m additional revenue in a full financial year. Administrative amendments contained in the Bill are expected to have little financial impact. There are no additional significant costs to the government associated with the Bill.
A summary of amendments for each schedule of the Bill has been prepared and copies are available from the Records and Table Office.
I commend the Bill.
Customs and Excise Amendment Bill 1983
The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 to introduce new provisions which emanate from the 1983 Budget.

In his Budget speech, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced an increase in the excise on diesel fuel. He said, however, that the rebate of excise on diesel fuel would not be increased when used off-road by the mining, forestry, farming and fishing industries, and by households, hospitals, nursing and aged persons' homes.
The excise increase on diesel fuel took effect from 8 p.m. on Budget night and from that time the rebate for eligible purposes will be pegged to 7.155 cents per litre.

By clause 6, this Bill proposes an amendment to section 164 of the Customs Act to give effect to the Budget decision, by providing for the rebate on diesel fuel used for eligible purposes to be prescribed by regulations. It is proposed that the appropriate regulations be made as soon as possible after this Bill receives the royal assent.
Similar consequential amendments are proposed to the excise act by clause 8 and 9 of the Bill.
The opportunity has been taken to include in the Bill a number of machinery amendments to the Customs Act and Excise Act.
In particular, clause 4 inserts a new provision into the Customs Act to enable additional criteria to be prescribed by regulation under which depot licences will not be granted under the act.
Clause 10 of the Bill repeals a now redundant part of the Excise Act as a consequence of the introduction of the new crude oil excise system proposed by the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983.
Finally clauses 11 and 12 contain amendments to the tariff proposal and by-law procedures in the Excise Act, to bring them into line with similar provisions in the Customs Act.

The measures in this Bill will have no direct financial implications. However, the consequential financial implications of pegging the rate of rebate on diesel fuel to 7.155 cents per litre will result in an expected net increase to revenue of $30m in 1983-84. This is because eligible consumers of the fuel have been required to pay a net excise of 1.872 cents per litre since Budget night. The figure also includes the expected net revenue gain from indexation proposed to occur on 1 February next year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose these Bills and proposes, subject to the objection of any other party in the chamber, that the Bills be dealt with immediately. I speak for the coalition Opposition parties but they are not the only non-government parties in the Senate. Nobody is here to object on behalf of other non-government Opposition members. These three Bills arise basically from the Budget. The Opposition's attitude is that the Government, having introduced the Budget, is entitled to introduce its revenue measures and can carry the can, the responsibility, for having done so. There are measures of which we do not approve but which we support because they are Government measures to raise revenue for its purposes, but we give no undertaking that in future we will act as this Government has acted.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the impact of the proposed increases in excise on a cross- section of items, including beer, spirits, manufactured tobacco products, motor spirit, diesel fuel, avgas, aviation kerosene, petroleum products and fortifying spirits will be particularly severe on the rural sector and on various industries which will have to pay more. The increases will have an inflationary effect and will do nothing to create more employment, which was one of the fundamental responsibilities undertaken by this Government during the last election campaign. These Bills introduce a concept which is relatively novel; that is, the automatic indexation of every excise for inflation or cost of living increases. The extra imposts of each increase will flow through to the next cost of living adjustment. The Opposition is concerned about the effect that will have.

Because we are not opposing the Bills, it should not be assumed that we are supporting such measures. However, to accommodate the Government's program for legislation to be passed to enable it to achieve those things which, as a Government elected by the Australian people it has a responsibility to achieve, we do not propose to hold up these Bills by debating them at length. We will, however, have comments to make at greater length in relation to an associated Bill, the States Grant (Petroleum Products) Bill. We may then make some of the comments we might otherwise have made in relation to the Bills now before us. The Opposition, therefore, whilst not having any enthusiasm for the items covered by the Bills, recognises that the Govenrment of the day is entitled to legislate to increase imposts on various sectors of the community. We particularly regret the fact that a number of industries, particularly rural, off-road and outback industries, are to be hit by them, but that is the Government's responsibility.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1983CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1983CUSTOMS AND EXCISE AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Peter Rae for his contribution to the debate. Brevity is the soul of wit, it was said, and Senator Peter Rae was generous in his contribution. I thank him for that.
—I raise a point of order. Am I to understand that this Bill is being taken through all its stages-the first reading, the second reading and the third reading stages-on this day?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Senate at the moment is: That the Bills be read a second time. I was about to put that question, the Leader of the Government replied to the debate. What happens from here on is matter for the Senate.

Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee report progress.
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it this Bill is being taken through-
—There are three Bills.

—I am sorry. These Bills are being taken through all of their stages on this day. I believe that that is not an appropriate precedent for this Senate to accept. I believe that debate on the Bills ought to be adjourned. If debate is not adjourned at the Committee stage than I think it should be adjourned when we report progress. The Bills should be passed, if necessary, tomorrow morning. I believe that we are setting a dangerous precedent by allowing the Bills to be passed through all their stages on this day.
—There can be no discussion on the motion to report progress. It is adopted without discussion, but it can be voted against.

—by leave-I think it may help Senator Haradine if I explain what has happened. Three Bills, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) , the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2), and the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill are before the Committee. There is also the States Grants ( Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill. All four Bills were introduced just a short time ago. It was proposed that three Bills would be dealt with tonight and that the fourth Bill, the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill, which may contain more controversial matters, be not dealt with tonight but rather be dealt with tomorrow or at some later date, when there is ample opportunity to debate it. When I said that the Liberal and National parties agreed to this course of action, I specifically said that it was subject to whether other non- government members of the chamber had any objection to it. If there is objection to that course being followed, I see no course but for the matter to be adjourned. I accept Senator Harradine's point that it is not the normal course of action. However, if it does not cause any major inconvenience to any honourable senators and if it facilitates the achievement of the legislative program of the Government through this chamber and enables longer debate on other matters of importance and controversy, the Opposition would like to facilitate that situation. If there is an objection, as far as the Opposition is concerned that is the end of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In respect of the three Bills in relation to which Senator Harradine has suggested that we report progress, the Standing Orders were suspended in order that a motion be moved to permit the matters being dealt with tonight. The spirit and understanding I certainly had with Senator Rae was that major issues which might be encompassed by this bracket of Bills could be dealt with in the context of the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill. In our view, no opportunity in any sense is being denied any honourable senator to speak in respect of that Bill on the issues central to these Bills. That is why that Bill is to be dealt with tomorrow when honourable senators will have had ample opportunity to consider it before they contribute to the debate. I believed that was a course which was convenient to everbody. I hope that it is convenient to Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Australian Citizens' Allegations: Drug Activities
Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I raised in the Senate a matter relating to some issues which had been raised with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and otherwise with the Government and its agencies . They related to a possible charge of drug running. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) at that time was able to give me a partial reply. He has advised me that he has further information which he can put on the record. His having given me some preview of what he is able to say this evening I formally request him to see whether he can arrange for me to have a briefing from the Federal Police on the matters I have raised on behalf of Mr Milgate and one other person so that I may satisfy myself in more detail about the action taken by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to detain the Senate for very long, but Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness raised serious questions about their treatment and the lack of support they received from the Department of Foreign Affairs.

Yesterday the Leader of the Government in the Senate was able to give me some detailed advice on that aspect of the matter. However, the questions of whether or not there had been any adequate follow-up of the concerns which this young couple had expressed about the possibility of large international drug connections and the use of a particular vessel for illegal purposes, and so on, is a matter on which the Leader of the Government was not able to be of very much assistance to me. He seemed to think that he would be able to be of a lot more help tonight, but perhaps I shall have to raise the matter at Question Time tomorrow. Perhaps we could deal with it by the Minister, who appears not to have his papers with him-I have often found myself in a similar position-undertaking to make a brief statement after Question Time tomorrow, and perhaps in the meantime he could ask his office to check with the Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police as to whether I would be able to get a briefing so that I might have the more detailed advice which I think is necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not prepared to give any undertakings about anything at the moment. Senator Chaney raised with me the question of Mr Milgate and his friend Ms McGuinness. I undertook to give him an answer about that matter tonight. I sent out for the papers, but they do not seem to be here. However, the matter has been investigated by the Australian Federal Police and regular reports have been made to Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness by the Federal Police, the last as recently as last week. I am quite happy to make a statement about this matter after Question Time tomorrow. I have had discussions with the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) about the matter. Senator Chaney sought a briefing from a senior officer of the Federal Police. I have had discussions with the Special Minister of State about that request.

SPEECH.PARA: But now, by some magic sleight of hand-I think it was Senator Eslstob's hand, and I am extremely grateful to him-I am able to provide a response to the matter about which Senator Chaney has been asking me for a couple of days. The response is as follows: Following the referral of representations made by Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness through Senator Chaney and the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking to the Australian Federal Police, both persons were interviewed by members of the Australian Federal Police located in Perth. The information given to the Australian Federal Police members by Mr Milgate concerned allegations of drug smuggling by Australian nationals resident in India. This information was provided through Interpol channels to the Indian authorities for action by the police in that country. Australian Federal Police inquiries so far have not established links with the persons named by Mr Milgage and Ms McGuinness with drug shipments into Australia. Checks with Customs and other agencies have not revealed any information which puts the vessel named during the interviews in Australian waters.

Following the report in the weekend's Western Mail, the Australian Federal Police has sought further information from United States authorities on the reported seizure of drugs. Members of the Australian Federal Police in Perth have kept Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness informed of the progress of their inquiries. As late as last Thursday Australian Federal Police officers were informed by Mr Milgate that he was satisfied with the action being taken by the Australian Federal Police.

That is the most up to date information that the Government has had. But insofar as the request for further details has been made to me by Senator Chaney , as I said earlier, the Special Minister of State, at my request, has arranged for Senator Chaney to be given a briefing by a senior officer of the Federal Police to elucidate any outstanding matters.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.15 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 15 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government fully think through the impact of its excises on fuel oil and kerosene on the tourist industry, in view of the anxiety they caused many Territorians, before backing away from the 9c per litre excise.
(2) Are the costs of diesel fuel for tourist operators in the outback as expensive as in the Queensland island tourist resorts, which have been provided with a $1m subsidy for diesel fuel.

(3) Will the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism review the impact of diesel fuel costs on Northern Territory tourist operators, with a view to opening a similar subsidy to that given to the Queensland island tourist resorts .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government did take into account the effect of its excise arrangements on industry, including the tourism industry.

(2) It is my understanding that, largely because of the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme, the wholesale price of diesel fuel in the Northern Territory would be similar to that of the Barrier Reef island resorts. Of course depending on discounting and retail margins the price would be more variable at the retail level.

(3) The Government was very critical of the decision by the Fraser Government to impose the diesel fuel excise on the tourism industry and in particular on the Barrier Reef island resorts. Recognising the importance of the reef area to tourism both in Queensland and in Australia generally, it undertook when elected to exempt these resorts from the excise. This commitment has effectively been met by the decision to provide a special grant to the off-coast Queensland islands to subsidise the cost of electricity generated from diesel fuel.

In the light of the very difficult 1983-84 budgetary situation, the Government felt it could not extend the subsidy at that time, however the effect of diesel fuel costs on the tourism industry including the industry in the Northern Territory will be kept under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will there be a real reduction in the allocation of funds for training purposes in the current year given the new additions of sports administered by the Australian Institute of Sport.
(2) To what extent will overseas competition be cut back.
(3) Will prospective new top class entrants to the Institute be discouraged.
(4) What action will be taken to ensure our athletes are not disadvantaged, particularly as the Olympic Games are scheduled for next year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The operational budget of the Institute has increased from $4.5047m in 1982-83 to $5.350m in 1983-84. Of this increase, only $200,000 will be required to fund a branch of the Institute in Perth for hockey.
(2) The Institute's 1982-83 expenditure on overseas competition was $517,122, and it has budgeted for an expenditure of $570,000 in 1983-84.

(3) No. In 1983 there were 188 scholarship positions at the Institute in Canberra. In 1984 it is expected that this number will be maintained in Canberra and in addition, 32 hockey students will be enrolled in Perth.

(4) As well as catering for resident sports, the Institute has budgeted $400, 000 in 1983-84 for the national training centre program. This program enables those not resident at the Institute to have access to the Institute's excellent services and facilities to assist in preparation for the Olympics and other major events.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1983 (Hansard, page 132), Senator Mason asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, a question in relation to Government policy on East Timor.

ANSWER.PARA: To that part of the honourable senator's question asking the Government to seek a guarantee from the Indonesian Government that no items of Australian military aid to Indonesia will be used in East Timor, the Minister for Defence has provided the following answer:

Australia's participation in the defence co-operation program represents a practical expression of our interest in regional security and promotes contacts with the governments and defence forces of countries with which we have shared strategic interests. By contributing to the security of neighbouring regions, these programs strengthen Australia's own security and thus constitute part of our national defence effort.

It has been the policy of successive governments not to seek to attach conditions on participation by the various countries in the program. The present Government accepts that participation in the DCP does not imply on the part of the countries involved endorsement of any or all of the policies of the other. When particular items of equipment are supplied the only condition imposed by Australia is that they not be sold or disposed of to a third country without prior Australian consent.

I should perhaps add that in the case of Indonesia the program does not normally involve the provision of ammunition or what might be described as ' lethal' equipment. The emphasis is on joint projects involving a package of some equipment supported by training and advisory assistance designed to transfer to Indonesia technical and specialist skills. Preference is given to projects which have application in the wider community. These have included:
Survey and mapping project-the production of cartographic maps of Indonesia which aid in civil and economic development.

Maritime patrol project-the provision of patrol boats and Nomad aircraft to assist the Indonesian Government in combating smuggling, illegal entry protection of fishing rights and search and rescue operations.
Nomad maintenance support project-to introduce a programmed maintenance system for Nomad aircraft, and the
English language project-to aid in the development of English language teaching in the Indonesian services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 18 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1634) Senator Sir John Carrick asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask firstly, how seriously does the Government view the threat by Iran to block the Strait of Hormuz? Secondly, have there been any discussions by the United States or United Kingdom governments with Australia towards any Australian commitment to a task force to act in the event of such a blockade? If so, what is their nature? Thirdly, what actions would be envisaged for such a task force? Fourthly, has the Australian Government taken any steps at all at the international or bilateral level to attempt to mitigate the possibility of the closure of the strait; and finally, and specifically, has the Government had any talks with the Iraqi Government particularly to urge that Government not to provoke this very serioues danger by the use of Exocet-type missiles?

In my response to the senator on 18 October, I provided answers to a number of these points, but advised that I would seek further advice from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information in response to the honourable senator's question:

Australia has not made a direct approach to Iraq in relation to its conduct of the war with Iran. The Government understands that Iraq has already used Exocet missiles in the war. Our present concern is mainly that the supply to Iraq of Super-Etendard aircraft (which can carry Exocet missiles) could create a climate in which they could be a dangerous escalation of the conflict.

Australia has maintained a scrupulously neutral position in relation to the war and has publicly expressed its concern about the possible escalation of the conflict. The Government continues to hope that both sides might be able to agree to a ceasefire and the negotiation of their differences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1846) Senator Walters asked Senator Grimes, in his capacity as Minister representing Senator Gietzelt who represents the Minister for Transport, a supplementary question without notice concerning the Bass Strait ferry service. Senator Grimes undertook to provide her with details regarding a reply by the Prime Minister to a letter from the Premier of Tasmania of 5 August on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Yes. I have responded to the correspondence from the Tasmanian Premier, including his letter of 5 August, on this matter. The Tasmanian Minister for Transport has since indicated that because of the limited time available to settle the necessary arrangements, including negotiations with relevant maritime unions and for the selection of a suitable vessel, the Tasmanian Government will not be pursuing the proposal at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Budget allocation for salaries for members of the Defence Force reserves, and is it expected to be more or less than that amount for the full year.
(2) What recovery is it expected to obtain by way of taxation on that amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1983-84 Defence budget allocation for pay and allowances in respect of the Defence Force reserves is $52.618m covering the Australian Naval Reserve, the Australian Army Reserve, the Regular Army Emergency Reserve and the Australian Air Force Reserve. This allocation is based on rates of pay and allowances prevailing at the time the Budget was prepared together with the average strengths endorsed for 1983-84. Actual achievement of that allocation will depend on a number of factors including changes to pay and allowance entitlements not foreseen at Budget time and any variations that may occur between expected and actual strengths.

(2) The savings to revenue in 1983-84 are expected to be $5m. As indicated in my joint statement with the Treasurer on 9 November 1983, the Government has decided not to proceed with the second stage of the removal of the tax exemption on pay and allowances of part time members of the reserve forces.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: In which year of the 1983-88 five year defence program is there provision for procurement of modern man-portable surface-to-air missiles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As noted in my recent statement, the Government approved the introduction of a new man-portable lightweight anti-aircraft missile system in the 1983-84 Budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2069), Senator Childs asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that ballot papers printed for a ballot conducted by the Australian Electoral Office for the New South Wales branch of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union have been printed by a leading computer manufacturer, Rank Xerox (Aust.) Pty. Ltd, a non-PKIU establishment? Did the Minister on 15 August assure the National Secretary of the PKIU that the facilities of the Government printing offices would be used unless there were real problems in those printeries meeting the deadlines required by the Electoral Office? Is it a fact that the Australian Government printing offices are currently not working to full capacity, particularly in New South Wales? If so, why were the ballot papers not printed at the New South Wales branch of the Government Printing Office where there are full security arrangements to protect the integrity of ballot papers?
The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 2 November the New South Wales Secretary of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union wrote to the Australian Electoral Office on the same subject as that raised by Senator Childs. A reply by the Electoral Office was sent on 7 November and as it is relevant to the honourable senator's question I will quote that reply in full:
'I refer to your telex of 2 November concerning the printing of ballot papers for the PKIU election.

It is true that the ballot papers in question were produced by Rank Xerox. This was under an Australian Government Printing Service contract No. SC82/DR-NSW1. As far as security is concerned, satisfactory arrangements were made, with the ballot papers being printed on fugitive print paper and with the paper being delivered by one of our officers who observed the entire printing operation. Upon completion of the printing the ballot papers, spoils and unused paper were returned to the Australian Electoral Office again under the supervision of our officer.

A large measure of your concern however I gather relates to the Australian Electoral Office's not using the New South Wales Government Printer for this exercise. In July, as you know, Mr C. Harvey, the Federal Secretary of your union, wrote to the Special Minister of State because he believed that industrial ballot material would no longer be printed at the Government Printing Office. In reply, Mr Beazley told Mr Harvey that the Australian Electoral Office policy was that the facilities of government printers were used unless those printers had real problems in meeting the deadlines required.
I can assure you that this is still the position. Indeed, following your complaint I have again drawn that policy to the attention of each of our State offices.

However, we have had problems for some years over the difficulties which the New South Wales Government Printer has had in meeting our deadlines. In the case of union ballots these deadlines of course are usually fixed by the relevant union's rules. We have had a number of talks with officers of the New South Wales Government Printing Office and I am sure that the printer is as keen as we are to overcome these difficulties and to be able to assure us of the service which he would want to provide and which we must have if, in turn, we are to meet the requirements placed on us. I would add that two orders-one for ballot papers and one for nomination notices-were placed with the Government Printer last week.
I can only repeat the earlier assurance, namely, 'that given that our requirements can be met the Government Printer will be our first choice'.
